talk.start.para: —I want to record my disappointment that I did not get an opportunity in the House to speak on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 2001-2002. I want to draw to the minister's attention one particular problem in my electorate, and I think it may be a much broader national problem, and that is the inflexibility of the Job Network system. In my area I have a high level of indigenous unemployment, which I am sure applies in many parts of Australia. I have people who work within the community—social workers, other providers, people who either are trying to give skills to these people who are unemployed or are actually placing them into jobs—who are not within the Job Network system and are therefore not recompensed for finding people work. They do not begrudge that fact, but there seems to be a system creeping in whereby people in the Job Network who are trying to find jobs for, say, indigenous unemployed people are struggling to do that so they are going outside and getting people in the community to actually find jobs for these people, but then the Job Network people reap the rewards.

speech.para: There seems to be inequity in the system when people can go into the Job Network system and be categorised very early. When they walk in that door they are categorised as `Easy to get a job', `Very difficult to get a job' or `Not interested.' The onus as to whether you have any hope of finding a job remains with the person at the reception desk when you walk into a Job Network agency. It is not just about how employable you are; it is about what hope you have of getting past that first person in the reception area. I think this is a really big problem that the minister needs to look at. Perhaps he can look at ways to make the system more flexible so it can address these issues.

Constituents have come to me and said, `Look, I am finding it hopeless going to Job Network providers because they are not interested in me. I don't fit into their neat categories of who might be easiest for them to make a profit from. Because I don't fit into those categories, I don't get looked after—there is nothing there for me.' I use the example of indigenous employment in particular but I am sure it is a wider problem. Perhaps the minister could look at this situation where outside agencies and other providers who are not part of the Job Network system are actually doing the hard yards, doing the work of trying to find jobs for people but who are then, at the end, finding that it is the Job Network providers who are actually picking up the money for placing those people into work.

talker.name: Abbott, Tony, MP
Mr ABBOTT
talker.role: Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business

talk.start.para: —I would like to begin by thanking the members opposite for their contributions. I think all the members opposite who have spoken in this debate have spoken with goodwill and great sincerity, and all of them have raised important and interesting points, which I will attempt to address as best I can in this response.

speech.para: I will begin with the comments made by the member for Newcastle. Essentially, he made three points. The first point he made was that Job Network members in his electorate were, he said, reluctant to speak out publicly about defects in the system. The second point he made was that people going into the Job Network did not have enough of an idea of the resources that might be available to them through the network. The third point he made was about Job Network allegedly breaching people.

I would like to make it very clear that, as far as I am concerned and, I am sure, as far as the government generally is concerned, there is no attempt whatsoever to limit debate nor to restrict people's contributions to building a better society. Obviously, the more that people who know the system speak about the system, the better. However, I think members opposite need to understand that every time a Job Network member damns the system, he or she runs the risk of damning his or her own operations and, if people are not as ready to criticise the system as members opposite might sometimes like, it is probably because they have, on balance, quite a good opinion of the system and they understand that, while simply running things down might make sense in a political context, it rarely makes sense in a context where people are out there trying to do the right thing as best they can under the ordinary difficulties that people face with the system that they have.

As members opposite should know by now, the Job Network is a result of a tender process, and the strict prices at which Job Network members are awarded contracts are commercial-in-confidence. However, generally speaking, if we are talking about intensive assistance, there is an up-front payment to the Job Network member of a little over $1,000, with an outcome payment of a little over $2,000 after 13 weeks and another outcome payment of about $1,000 after 26 weeks. Those amounts vary, depending upon the job seeker's degree of disadvantage and the particular bids that different Job Network members have put in, but that, broadly speaking, is what the average job seeker referred to a Job Network member for intensive assistance can expect will be available.

The idea that, just because someone has been categorised in a certain way, the Job Network member has no more than a particular amount to spend on them is misleading. Job Network members do not just deal with individuals on a one-off basis; they are also dealing with the collectivity of unemployed people in their area. There are some people who go into intensive assistance and quite quickly get work. The Job Network member gets paid outcome payments for those people which the Job Network member is then expected to invest in other job seekers. So some clients may well have far more spent on them than $4,000 or $8,000 or whatever the actual allocation for that client is. In the end, it is really up to the good faith of Job Network members and, while I am sure that there are some people in the Job Network, as there are in all other areas of life, who think a little bit too much of themselves and a little bit too little of others, by the same token the vast majority of people in the Job Network are extremely sincere and dedicated people. It is not easy to work with job seekers, particularly long-term job seekers, and I do not think there are too many grasping and avaricious capitalists out there in the Job Network.

Finally, on the question of breaching, Job Network members are expected to notify Centrelink if their clients are not playing by the rules, but no Job Network member actually breaches anyone. In the end, the enforcement role is the responsibility of Centrelink, the government agency, and that is the way it ought to be. (Extension of time granted) The member for Prospect has been a very long-term, distinguished and senior representative of her part of Western Sydney and I would not for a second doubt the member for Prospect's commitment to her people and her area. I do think that sometimes she rather exaggerates the difficulties that some people face. The member for Prospect does not quite seem to have appreciated, at least for the purposes of this debate, that the Job Network is not something which is micromanaged by the government. The government does not decide, for instance, that we need two Job Network members in Guildford and five Job Network members in Parramatta and three in Liverpool and four in Chatswood and one in Manly. That is not how the Job Network operates. The Job Network operates like this: different members or would-be members bid to provide services in particular sites and, on the basis of the way those bids conform with the tender conditions, we then award contracts. There are certainly more Job Network members in the electorate of Prospect now than there were CES officers in the old days.

Given the mobility in a metropolitan area such as Sydney, I understand the member for Prospect's point, but I think that Job Network members in Parramatta are quite capable of helping job seekers in Prospect, just as Job Network members in Prospect, for that matter, are quite capable of helping job seekers in Parramatta. That is the way it ought to work, and that is my understanding of the way it does normally work.

On the question of entitlements, congratulations to the member for Prospect for her long campaign on this subject, which I think actually began under the former government—a government which did not actually do anything for the entitlements of workers. This government has. I accept that there are many people who think that more should be done, but the fact is that this is what is being done. I do think it would help the workers of Prospect and other parts of Australia if the member for Prospect were just as eager to get the state government to do its bit under the existing national scheme as she is to promote the virtues of an alternative national scheme which might possibly be put into place one day, if her friends are ever put into government.

I was pleased to hear the contribution of the member for Calare. I was recently in the electorate of Calare as part of the Pollie Pedal. I am sorry that the member for Calare was a bit too busy to join us; nevertheless it is always a pleasure to be in that particularly magnificent part of central western New South Wales. It is always possible to get nods of agreement from any audience by telling them how tough life is. I do not accept the member for Calare's point that the tax burden on low-paid and badly off people has increased. The statistics certainly do not bear him out. Even conceding that it might be true in some instances, the fact is that that tax is being spent on government programs. You cannot on the one hand complain that taxes are going up and on the other hand that government programs have been cut, because the arithmetic simply does not work out.

Underemployment is not a recent phenomenon. The ABS has been running statistical surveys on this for a couple of decades now, I think. At the height of the last recession, when the Leader of the Opposition was the minister for employment and unemployment hit close to 11 per cent, the ABS underemployment statistics showed commensurate problems. If you were to add the numbers of underemployed people to the numbers of unemployed people then, in the way people want to do now, unemployment would not have been about 11 per cent—it would have been about 18 per cent. If you want more work, obviously it is frustrating when you do not have it, but sadly this is not a recent phenomenon. Certainly, the quantum of work appears to be greater now than at any time in the recent past.

On the subject of CDEP, I take the point that the member for Calare made. I was in Mossman Gorge in Far North Queensland the other week and they are proposing just that kind of thing—to run a CDEP scheme which will focus on guiding services to tourists in the national park which abuts their community. But CDEP, a little like Work for the Dole and the Job Network, is actually a ground up program. (Extension of time granted). It is driven by the grassroots. If indigenous communities wish to reorientate their CDEPs in this direction, there is nothing to stop them from doing so, and if indigenous communities would like to begin CDEPs along these lines, certainly there would be nothing to stop them putting in applications. I would do whatever I could to try to encourage communities to do that kind of thing, and I would do whatever I could within the constraints of funding to try to make sure it was allowed to happen.

Finally, the member for Oxley raised the issue of people who are attempting to help job seekers but outside the ambit of the Job Network. I understand this issue. It does not just happen with indigenous people. There are a number of labour hire companies, for instance, that are outside the Job Network and who believe that they are sometimes subjected to unfair competition from Job Network members. There is nothing to stop anyone or any institution or agency that thinks it is able to deliver employment services from bidding to provide those under the Job Network. There will be a new Job Network tender in about two years time—less, in fact; I think in about 18 months time—but this issue of job matching payments and how we try to ensure fairness is certainly one that I have under review, one on which I do not believe we have necessarily reached the last word on optimal outcomes. So he makes a fair point. It is something that I am conscious of and something I hope the Job Network can tackle better in the years to come.

I will finish with a remark that might apply to a number of the contributions that have been made by members opposite. I have a great deal of faith in the integrity of Job Network members. While they are only human and while it is true that junior Job Network member staff may well, life being what it is, sometimes get impatient with people, sometimes categorise people unfairly and sometimes perhaps write people off too soon, at the end of the day we have only a certain amount of resources and we need to invest them in the most sensible possible ways, and some job seekers are very hard to help. That does not mean that we should not do our absolute best, but it is right and proper that we should make intelligent decisions about the best way to invest those resources. I think that is best done at the local level by organisations that know the job seekers, know the communities and know the employment circumstances of those particular areas.

Certainly I say to the member for Oxley and to anyone else in the parliament who is concerned about this: if you honestly believe that a particular constituent of yours is not getting a fair go from the Job Network, talk to the relevant Job Network member, tell them that you think this individual is not getting a fair go and, if you do not think that the Job Network member has responded adequately, maybe talk to another Job Network member. If there is a problem with getting someone who is on Intensive Assistance with one institution, and is not getting on very well, transferred to a different agency, that is the sort of thing ministers can sometimes help with, and it is the sort of thing that departments can sometimes look at. Job seekers will do better and our society will be enriched if we have as much communication as possible. I accept that there will always be ideological and philosophical differences between governments and members of the opposition, but there is no reason whatsoever why we cannot come to good practical arrangements to the benefit of our own people. As I said, I would certainly encourage members opposite who believe that individuals are not getting a fair go to make contact with the Job Network, the department and, if necessary, my office and we will see what we can do to help.
Proposed expenditure agreed to.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of the Environment and Heritage

quote.para: Proposed expenditure, $743,095,000.

talk.start.para: —I rise this morning to bring to the attention of the parliamentarians sitting here and those who may be listening to this debate page 103 of Budget Paper No. 2. It covers the particular area I am interested in, and that is the Department of Environment and Heritage allocation in 2001-02 of $5 million. I quote the explanation:

quote.para: The Government will provide a grant of up to $5 million in 2001-02 to the Goondiwindi Town Council to develop a recreational facility at Serpentine Lagoon, Goondiwindi. The facility is needed because Boobera Lagoon is to be closed to current facilities as a result of a declaration of protection under the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act 1984. The new facility will satisfy relevant Commonwealth, state and local legislative requirements.

speech.para: I raise that and use it possibly as a vehicle for what I am going to say because I was very disturbed—not that I am denying these people the right to have this money allocated to them, even though I admit and acknowledge that it is in the seat of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, the Hon. Bruce Scott. I had an opportunity on Saturday, 9 June, with our council—the Fairfield City Council—and accompanied by the mayor, Councillor Robert Watkins, to launch a five-creek strategic plan in Fairfield. One may ask, `What are you doing launching a five-creek strategic plan in Fairfield City Council?' After all, it is a metropolitan council so how has it got five creeks? Well, within our area we happen to have the Prospect Creek Catchment area, which covers approximately 98 square kilometres and includes the following five creeks: Prospect Creek, Orphan School Creek, Clear Paddock Creek, Green Valley Creek, Burns Creek and even part of Long Creek. There are something like 2,500 flood affected properties, and I will speak in another area of debate about that. But they are looking at the waterways, the catchments, sewer outfalls and modified and affected fauna habitat.

I have brought it up because this council has been able to put a plan into place with no assistance whatsoever from this Commonwealth government. When we look at all the allocation of funds and all the uses for it, that one in particular, I believe, sticks out like a sore thumb. I am particularly proud of what the council have been able to do and I praise them for being such an innovative and progressive council, particularly where urban creek restoration is concerned. I was particularly pleased too that they brought in a cultural mapping group—a placebo art group—which is the first time it has ever been done, I understand, in an area such as ours. These people went to individual schools, factories, clubs or whatever that in any way, shape or form were involved in creeks and got the residents to come along and design with them what they, the residents, would like to see around the creeks in our area. That is what came to the forefront in the launching of the strategic plan—funding not provided by any government department but through the ratepayers and by the council itself.

The strategic plan launched on that Saturday is part of an evolving approach for those five creeks and it is being seen and treated by our community as what we would like to see in the future. The creeks, we know, are changing all the time, and I believe this plan will continue to evolve and change. But I then wonder—and bring to the attention of the House—how much more could be done. I am using my council as an example because they at least have taken the bit between the teeth and have gone ahead and said, `Look, we have got an environment problem here. We have got a problem that needs fixing. We certainly applied to the relevant government departments for funding; that hasn't been forthcoming, but our community is saying that more needs to be done.'

Possibly 100 years ago European settlers did all their boating and picnicking in this catchment creek area—and I should imagine that our first indigenous settlers used it as a lifeline to support themselves—and yet today we are seeing growth, pollutants and the degradation of a local environment area. A council is willing to start restoring it, but how much more could have been done if they had even a part of that $5 million that has been allocated to one lagoon. If we are realistically looking at allocating our taxpayers funds, let us look Australia wide as well. I could go on further about what is happening with the natural heritage allocations. People may ask, `Why didn't you get some of that money?' Well, that did not go too far in our area either, and there is certainly nothing I can point to in saying how great that is going to be as part of the contribution for an electorate like mine that probably has in the vicinity of 200,000 people and yet we are very limited as far as funds are concerned.

I say to the Fairfield City Council and to their mayor: keep up the good work. To the staff and all those people who were involved in putting the strategic plan together, I say: you are to be commended and congratulated. I believe that this is the beginning of what we are going to be so very proud of in the future. More importantly, we have finally seen a local government area get together in saying, `We have a concern; we have a problem; let's now start to rectify it and change it and, more importantly, change people's perceptions of what our creeks are all about.' (Time expired).

talk.start.para: —Much was made of the extra $1 billion set aside in this year's budget for an extension of the Natural Heritage Trust. I said at the time of the budget that it appeared to be a smoke and mirrors exercise which appeared to shift money from other, established environment programs and re-badge them as new initiatives. Apart from the interest generated from the minimum legislated balance of the trust—that is $300 million—it is just not enough to even begin to tackle the $60 billion price tag that the National Farmers' Federation and the Australian Conservation Council place on the repair bill for the Murray-Darling Basin alone. Unless we find alternative sources of funds to selling off Telstra, our environmental efforts are doomed to fail. I believe we need a levy such as that recently suggested by a committee of this parliament, as an environmental tax—let us be frank and call it what it is—and we need policies that seriously encourage investment in alternative energy. We cannot even commit to a Kyoto greenhouse target that we had already doubly exceeded by 1997-98. How absolutely pathetic is that, and what a betrayal of our future generations it is, if we do not put in place some meaningful targets and some meaningful long-term policies.

speech.para: I well remember in the debate during the sale of the first tranche of Telstra, the former shadow minister—later minister—Ian McLachlan was in the House, and I said then that the Murray-Darling Basin 2001 program was indeed a Murray-Darling Basin 2101 program, if we were going to be realistic about it. In a quiet chat afterwards with him he totally agreed. That is the dimension of the program, and the challenge that we have ahead of us, in that sector of the Australian environment alone. If we are to be a clever nation and an innovative one, then we have an opportunity to apply it to the most pressing crisis that faces the globe. It is the environment, and Australia is ideally placed to be the engine room, if you like, of innovation in terms of environmental studies and environmental options. We do not even know what our supposed carrying capacity is in this country, and while there are many anxious to say we have got enough in this country, that we need to protect our environment, we must remember those millions of people who are on the subcontinent and China. Imagine once all the Chinese put down their bikes and hop into motor cars—which many of them will do in the next few years—what an enormous impact on our greenhouse contribution that will be.

We really need to be quite objective about this. If it means that we do stretch our environmental capabilities in order to perhaps take pressure off elsewhere, we should look at that. We should look at what we need in terms of infrastructure to handle larger populations in regional Australia. But we should start doing it now, in a serious way, and not leave it for perhaps the next generation, the next term of parliament, the government after this or whatever it might be. Of course, the Australian public, not only us as legislators, as a parliament, have a role to play here. I notice in Ross Gittins's article in the Herald today that Australians say the environment is important, but they are not prepared to even commit to green energy.

I suggest part of this is a failure to understand how the existing industry can be a user of non-green resources and also be a promoter of green energy. It strikes me that there needs to be a completely separate supplier that the consumer can recognise as an independent broker of green energy and not one involved in chewing up our resources to create the non-green energy that we rely on. I know we rely on it, and we have to accept that. In my own small, modest way I am trying to encourage ADI in Lithgow. They assemble generators and equipment for wind power generation. (Extension of time granted) I know that ADI are involved in assembling wind power generators from overseas in one of their Victorian plants. I think it would be a very creative move for ADI, with government support and encouragement, to develop that technology in a place like Lithgow where we already have the beginnings of a wind power industry supported by the existing energy infrastructure in the area, to develop these alternative energies and the jobs, creativity and IT that go with them alongside our traditional energy sources—the coalmines. Then the children of the miners can move into the new energy that has to develop over the next couple of decades. If we do not do that, we will sit on our hands and leave our kids with an environment that I know my young fellow, at 19 or 20, agonises over—not as an activist or anything else—as to what we can do to turn the ship of old energy around and to really do something positive. He believes—and I certainly do—that Australia is in a prime position to create that expertise.

talk.start.para: —I spoke in the House on 26 March and again on 2 April on my concerns about the level of greenhouse gas emissions. I have spoken about climate change—in short, global warming—and the failure of the government to deal appropriately with the Kyoto protocol because of the position of the United States government, primarily President George Bush. It was very heartening for environmentalists to view the images which came to our screens last week, when President Bush travelled to Europe, and the outrage that was expressed by Europeans on behalf of all people on this planet who have grave concerns about the level of greenhouse gas emissions that are being spewed out on mother earth on a daily basis.

speech.para: The Australian government should be taking a greater stand against the position of the United States. I do not believe that Senator Hill is doing enough. It is just not good enough for us to blame the US. The US seems to have the view that the economy is far more important than the environment. Quite honestly, if you do not have an environment, you do not have an economy. Global warming is the most serious environmental issue facing us today and Australia should be showing greater leadership in speaking out against the behaviour of President Bush. I have wondered many times what would have happened had Al Gore won the last election. Al Gore is a very outspoken environmentalist who has grave concerns for the future of this planet. Unfortunately, he missed out on being elected as President of the United States of America. It seems that Mr Bush's cabinet is stacked with oil, lead and aluminium business executives who are motivated only by economic imperatives and not by the consequences of global warming on the environment.

I take this opportunity to send a strong message on behalf of the many constituents in my electorate of Lowe who have expressed grave reservations about the weak-kneed approach of Senator Hill in not standing up to President Bush. He should be encouraged to take a tougher stand. Unless more countries take on the United States in the interests of saving the planet, as obviously the Europeans are prepared to do, the United States of America will continue to be concerned only with economic imperatives and we would all pay a great price for that.

talker.name: Stone, Dr Sharman, MP
Dr STONE
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —In summing up the debate, I thank the members for Calare, Lowe and Prospect for their contributions. It is very important that we consider that this government's environmental credentials are under scrutiny, both domestically and internationally, just as all governments' environmental credentials and investments now are. We have a new consciousness that, for the first time in history, there are more environmental refugees around the globe than there are refugees created by war. That is the case for the first time in human history. We see water resources running down or being polluted across the globe, and we see issues like climate change through human intervention, which is a very serious issue and is now acknowledged to be something that all nations must address most urgently.

speech.para: I will come to the issue of climate change that the member for Lowe and the member for Calare addressed. To begin with the member for Prospect's contribution, she was concerned about the five-creek strategic plan in her electorate. It sounds like a very commendable plan, and I add my congratulations to hers for an effort well done by her councils. She was concerned that they were going it alone, so to speak—that they did not seem to have been tapping into Natural Heritage Trust funding. Let me say to her that we have been very conscious of urban environments and the degradation of water supplies, air quality and noise abatement. There is a whole range of urban environmental issues that the Natural Heritage Trust specifically identified and addressed. In the vast majority of cases the natural resource issues that we have to address are in regional and remote Australia, but there are, too, of course—

talk.start.para: —In marginal seats, more like it.

—No, I am sorry; that is a reality. There is a very significant program of urban funding, including urban Waterwatch, under the Living Cities program. The Commonwealth announced in the 2000-01 budget statement an amount of over $12 million over three years for the urban Waterwatch program in order to improve the health of urban waterways through community monitoring in urban areas. As a result of budget requirements, the urban Waterwatch component of the Living Cities program was reallocated.

speech.para: I say to the councils who are involved with the five-creek strategic plan that they should talk to Environment Australia and explore those specific NHT programs. They should also talk to Environment Australia, to me specifically or to DETYA about Green Corps. We have put $88.8 million into the Green Corps program across Australia. A significant number of those wonderful young Australians, aged between 17 and 20, who are involved in Green Corps work in urban catchments, just like the catchment the member for Prospect described. They are often from that region, so there is the advantage of young people working in a local area. Green Corps engages with other service groups or voluntary groups in the community. Green Corps is a magnificent program, one we are very pleased to see has been taken up very enthusiastically across the country. The budget for that Green Corps program is substantial.

I commend the Green Corps project to the member for Prospect to pursue, as well as the Work for the Dole programs, which have seen numbers of individuals and teams of people who have dedicated their efforts in a voluntary capacity to programs of renewal of urban streams or other open places. Again, it just might be that the councils in the member for Prospect's electorate are not fully aware of those opportunities, and I commend those to them. Let me assure you that our environmental budget does pay a very substantial amount of attention to urban issues, in terms of both climate—

talk.start.para: —We have knocked on every door, Parliamentary Secretary.

—Please come and knock on my door as well because, as parliamentary secretary, I am able to help people just like your five-creek plan group on very many occasions. Of course, the realities are that it is always a competitive process but, as you describe it, this is a very worthy project.

speech.para: I will refer to the member for Calare's contribution. (Extension of time granted) I agree that we certainly have had the NFF and the ACF make a substantial attempt to quantify just what a repair bill for the Australian environment could be. I think the NFF-ACF estimated $3.7 billion a year for 10 years as a minimum. The point of course is that this government have put more funding specifically into environmental repair and natural resource conservation and protection than any other government in the history of Australia. We began in 1996, needing to look at where to find those funds since we inherited a deficit, as the member for Calare would be only too aware, and we were able to have a win-win situation by partially privatising Telstra and using those funds to retire a lot of inherited debt and to invest in the Natural Heritage Trust. The good news is that, by very careful management of our economy, the Howard government are now able to go beyond simply relying on the proceeds of sale of some assets. With five years of surplus budgets we have now been able to draw our environmental funding from consolidated revenue. That is exactly how we hoped it would be, but we could not wait until we got the deficit down before we were able to commit billions of dollars. We could not wait for the surplus; hence, we began in 1996, as we did.

The member for Calare was concerned that, as he said, we do not even know what the carrying capacity of the country is. We could have waited five years for the National Land and Water Resources Audit to do that base study work—we are now beginning to get excellent outcomes from the investment in their research and development; they have just recently produced audits of salinity and water quality in our country—but we felt that we could not wait five years for that work to be done, so we commenced in 1996 understanding the scale of the problem and understanding the level of expenditure that needed to be undertaken as soon as possible. We are doing two things: we are investing in on-the-ground work to make sure our agricultural production is sustainable and our natural resources protected and, at the same time, we are doing that research and development work that is needed so we can monitor and assess what we have achieved and whether we are heading in the right direction so we can understand the scope and the scale of the problem that is with us now and which is going to continue as we continue to be naturally resource based in many parts of our economy.

The member for Lowe was understandably concerned, like most Australians, about the issue of climate change and how our government is responding to our responsibilities as one of the world's highest per capita emitters of carbon. He suggested, I think, that our Prime Minister, John Howard, had somehow not done enough. Then he went on to acknowledge that this is an issue that requires international cooperation, and the difficulty is now with a USA administration which does not share the same level of commitment to Kyoto that was exhibited in the previous administration.

Our country, Australia, leads the world in dedication of funds to greenhouse gas abatement. We have the world's first national greenhouse office. We have put over a billion dollars into long-term work which includes research into alternative energy sources and helping industry commercialise alternative energy technologies. The member for Calare will be interested in that too, because that was one of his concerns. We are very realistic and, as our minister has said in the Senate in response to questions about how we are going to cope with the fact that the United States is not as concerned about progressing the Kyoto agreement as the previous administration, we are acknowledging that it is going to be very difficult. We are continuing to support the Kyoto protocol moving forward and being accepted. (Extension of time granted) In particular, we are concerned that developing countries participate in identifying the issues and finding solutions to the problem because we know that in the very near future developing countries will have significantly more emissions than developed countries.

We are in the process of further negotiation on the implementation of the protocol. There is no go-slow; there is no sitting on our hands. We are pressing forward as hastily as we can, given the current political circumstances that are in the community of those addressing these problems. I am very proud that it was our government, the Australian government, that put on the table at Kyoto discussions on the issue of vegetation: the significance of carbon sequestration and carbon sinks using vegetation. That was one of the first serious discussions about the role of vegetation and its retention, in that global forum, and now Australia is very much respected for the work that we have done in that regard. I think Senator Hill needs to be commended for the work that he is doing. Certainly our government has put our money where our mouth is in terms of significant commitment to the Australian Greenhouse Office and the range of programs that go with that.

In conclusion, let me say that Australia has a very significant problem as a consequence of the last 250 or so years of management of our natural resources. They have not always led to the most sustainable outcomes. We understand that. We are learning, now, how to manage this country in a way so that our future generations are not going to inherit a degraded water supply or air pollution standards which leave many sick with asthma. We understand the needs of our Bureau of Meteorology. That has been significantly funded in an ongoing fashion. We understand our responsibilities in the Antarctic. We are one of the first countries in the world to have an oceans policy and to persist in making sure that our endangered species are protected. Therefore, I am proud to be a part of the Howard government that has been, as I said, the first in the history of Australia to commit the level of funding that now is dedicated to the environment. I am quite sure that the community of Australia is with us in understanding that this level of investment is essential for our futures.

talk.start.para: —I want to raise the issue of the Natural Heritage Trust and the Howard government's initiative in repairing the environment and how significant that has been in the electorate of Mitchell. I will mention some of the things that have flowed from the decisions for funding community organisations and the scope that the trust funds have used in sustainable development, in sustainable alternative agricultural techniques and in the retention of biodiversity in the plant and animal life of the huge area which surrounds the Hawkesbury-Nepean catchment areas. Community groups in the Blue Mountains, in the electorate of my colleague Kerry Bartlett, and in the electorates of Lindsay, Macarthur, Mitchell, Berowra and Robertson, have been most anxious to take up the advantages of further repairing and restoring the environment.

speech.para: As the development of Sydney presses out into the Hawkesbury valley, we are finding that there is increasing pressure on the environment. Greater care is needed to ensure the health of the Hawkesbury River, to make sure that the blue-green algae bloom that occurs on a fairly regular basis in that river is contained, that fish life is preserved and that the water quality in the Hawkesbury is retained. Unfortunately, a recent decision by Mr Amery, the state minister, to abandon the main funding mechanism, the Hawkesbury-Nepean Catchment Management Trust, means that there is no organisation that is capable of receiving the funds and making decisions on resource allocation as to how the federal government should apply the Natural Heritage Trust funds. I do not know how it is going to work. The decision by Amery to wipe out this organisation, which was established by my colleague Mr Kevin Rozzoli, was incredible. It is an organisation which has served the people of Western Sydney extremely well. It has focused on water quality retention and it drew together instrumentalities such as the water board and five or six local government bodies which have fought and failed to take action to retain or improve the health of the river. In fact, Mr Amery, with one stroke of the pen, dismissed this group.

talk.start.para: —The honourable member probably supports Amery's decision. You are talking about the destruction of the environment of the Hawkesbury and Nepean rivers. I stand alongside my colleagues in the state house who seek an inquiry as to why this organisation has been disbanded. You have left the Commonwealth without any mechanism to fund or make priorities in that area. The member who has interrupted is from Western Sydney. She knows jolly well there is no replacement body. She knows that to fund Penrith City Council, Hawkesbury City Council or those sorts of bodies is a piecemeal approach. She knows that the Hawkesbury-Nepean Catchment Management Trust was the only body capable of administering these funds and making the right priority decisions. It is a most appalling decision. I believe that there should be an upper house inquiry. I appeal to the parliamentary secretary to use her powers of persuasion with her state colleagues. We will certainly, from this level, be seeing what alternative funding processes can be used.

speech.para: I believe an inquiry should be conducted to assess the impact of the trust's closure on the environment, the effectiveness of the trust's work in improving the health of the catchment and whether government activities have affected the trust's functions. I suspect that the trust has been critical of the government's decision to expand development and housing on the former ADI site. The trust says this is environmental sacrilege and it should never happen. The trust has been sacked because it opposed the development policies of the New South Wales government.
Honourable members interjecting—

talk.start.para: (Mr Quick)—Order!
—Order! The honourable member for Mitchell has been asked to restrain himself.
—What about the member for Prospect? She is intimidating us.
—Order!
—Mr Deputy Speaker—
—Resume your seat. The member for Prospect—
—Would you like a hankie?
—Order! The member for Sturt!
—I have not heard you once call the member for Prospect to order; not once.
—I remind the member for Sturt that I have called him to order. I have called the member for Prospect to order. The parliamentary secretary now has the call.

talker.name: Stone, Dr Sharman, MP
Dr STONE
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —I thank the member for Mitchell for his final remarks. As you understand, I was closing the debate just before he spoke; he would not have realised that. Let me say that the member for Mitchell raised some significant issues. He highlighted the fact that in natural resource management we need cooperation between jurisdictions, whether it is local councils or state or federal governments. One of the problems of federation has been that the Commonwealth government alone does not have the ability to legislate across the country for setting national standards or requiring natural resource management activities to take place in states or territories.

speech.para: In fact, the Natural Heritage Trust has been groundbreaking in the bilateral agreements developed with the states and will continue to be groundbreaking as we develop state-Commonwealth bilateral agreements for our new national salinity action plan. Where something breaks down, as it seems to have done in the Hawkesbury River, we need to work very seriously with the state government again and, for the good of the environment, make sure we have the optimal outcome. I am sure that, with the local community understanding the impacts of what has gone on, we will get some of that cooperation back into the system quite quickly because otherwise the environment will be significantly damaged. I thank the member for Mitchell for his contribution and I am pleased to commend the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 2001-2002 to the House and particularly to the Department of the Environment and Heritage.
Proposed expenditure agreed to.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Transport and Regional Services

quote.para: Proposed expenditure, $503,678,000.

talk.start.para: —There are a number of issues I would like to raise under this area of responsibility. I am pleased the minister is here to hear them. First I would like to touch on the Western Sydney Orbital. I have had questions on notice—and I know a number of my other colleagues have as well—looking at classifications of national highways and tolls. At least the minister has acknowledged that no other national highway in Australia is going to have a toll on it as this one will. I am rather displeased about this. If you look at Western Sydney and where we are geographically located, you will see that we will now have something like four roads with tolls on them, and here is one that is going to be a so-called bypass. A lot of the traffic lights and signals are now in existence, particularly along the Cumberland Highway. But it is going to be at a cost to the residents that I represent.

speech.para: In fact, when I asked the minister, in a question without notice, what the cost would be, in his reply he indicated that electronic tolling is proposed, although not finally decided on—that is to be addressed in the tender process—but it is likely that a toll of about 25c per kilometre would be charged up to a maximum of about $5, in year 2000 dollars. This road will eventually be finished by about 2008 and 2010. I know the minister will probably get up and say that residents have a right to use other roads and they do not have to use this one. But, if they choose to use this one because they want to get to work quicker, they are going to have to pay in the vicinity of the equivalent of $5 in year 2000 dollars. When we look at expenditure reviews and costings of the future, they could be paying anything up to $10 a journey going each way. I think that is far more than they could afford to pay. More particularly, it is most unfair that a road that is going to be built in Western Sydney is going to have a toll while other so-called national highways do not.

Another area of concern with the orbital—I put a submission in on this because an environmental impact statement was issued—was Horsley Drive, which goes right through the centre of my electorate. That was originally classified as a road that was only going to be a feeder road in the future, but the traffic volumes indicated by the EIS show that when the orbital is built off Wallgrove Drive, Horsley Drive east of the proposal will have a 51 per cent increase in traffic over the volume of traffic now using it. If anyone cares to use that road during what is classified as a busy time, particularly coming to the Cumberland Highway—going east or then going west—they will find that between the hours of 7 a.m. to 9.30 a.m. and 4 p.m. to 5.30 or 6 p.m. it is actually a parking station: we cannot move on it now.

There is no money allocated or even a desire at this stage to make that a four-lane expressway to feed these tollways or orbital roads. This is a residential road and it is going to go right through an area where certainly the council does not have the responsibility but I know the state government does. I am not worrying so much about the funding for that but I am concerned about traffic volume. In fact, people have always been told that that was going to be an internal feeder road throughout the municipality, which is now the city, and that it certainly would not be affected by any future expansions. In the minister's own words, that is now going to happen.

I am also a little disturbed about the government's ownership of the Badgerys Creek site. In answer to my question on notice—and in answer to a question on notice from my colleague the member for Lowe, who, I am sure, will have more to say about it—the minister said:

quote.para: The Government has decided to retain ownership of the Badgerys Creek site and to legislate to protect the site from incompatible development in surrounding areas which may prejudice its future use as an airport. The Government will further review Sydney's airport needs in 2005. No site other than Badgerys Creek is currently being considered for a second major airport.

speech.para: That answer was given on 4 June 2001. I find that answer rather disconcerting when we realise now, when they are looking for the sale of Sydney airport, that they are going to have carte blanche as to whether they go ahead and build another airport, wherever it may be. Why aren't the government honest with the people of Western Sydney? They are saying, `We will not have further use for that site; therefore, we are not going to require that site,' but people in my electorate will not take that as an answer. As far as they are concerned, all we have done with Badgerys Creek is put it on hold. More importantly, we do not seem to be looking at the overall problem of what is happening in New South Wales as far as transport and transport studies go. I want to touch on that very briefly so I will come back to it later.

I also want to touch on the Roads to Recovery program again. I raised this in the House in December of last year when it was reported in the papers that money being allocated to Western Sydney—$13-odd million—was all going to the electorate of Prospect. (Extension of time granted) I must admit that when I read the $13.2 million was all going to go to the electorate of Prospect, I grabbed the paper and ran round the table. However, when I looked further, I saw that it was not going to the electorate of Prospect at all. It was going to be shared by the electorates of eight colleagues and about four different councils. So the one bit of money was being recorded in the electorates of the members for Chifley, Reid, Lindsay and Greenway, in my electorate and, dare I say, in part of Parramatta and Strathfield. So when we are talking about this $13.2 million from the Roads to Recovery program that was to be expended in Western Sydney, I can assure you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that there was very little we got of that.

In the allocation here today, I would also like to touch on flooding and flood mitigation programs. I want to bring up the flooding because of what we saw happen in 1996. When this government came to power, they set up a National Commission of Audit and used that as the excuse to cut $80 million out of all flood mitigation and urban, rural and regional communities' programming. I understand that after intensive lobbying, probably again from some of the marginal seats, a much weaker regional flood mitigation program was reintroduced in 1999. But you have to look a bit further than that. It was reintroduced in the rural areas with much fanfare but only $20 million was put back into it over three years, again into rural towns and regional centres.

I am not saying that the need is not great there, but not one penny has been allocated to urban flood mitigation programs in Western Sydney. I am glad the member for Parramatta is here, because he put out a press release stating that certain flood mitigation funding was coming to the seat of Parramatta. Of course, being ever observant, I was ready to scream, `Why is that money going to one particular urban area and not to the other?' only to find that it was just a misrepresentation on the member for Parramatta's behalf, that the money did not go there at all, that he was looking at all of this so-called extra funding coming in. Of course, it was not the case.

We had the member for Mitchell talking about what is happening to the Hawkesbury River and to the catchment program there. Of course, he did not want to acknowledge who actually set it up and how it was funded. Under the Keating government, the previous Labor government, we had flood mitigation programs going on what we called 2:2:1—in other words, for every $2 from the Commonwealth, $2 was supplied by the state and $1 by local councils. That has been completely wiped. Forget that many local councils and areas like mine have $30 million worth of flood mitigation work still outstanding.

I represent three particular council areas that are massively inundated when flooding occurs. Just recently, with the showers that we had, two schools had to close in my electorate. I am talking about the Patrician Brothers, which had to close its school and 1,500 kids were sent home. Shops were inundated and they had to close the doors. It all comes from urban flood mitigation problems.

Councils are continuing to work on this. They are still at least getting cooperation from the state government, but there is not one cent coming any more from this federal government. If we are talking about needs and responsibilities, with respect to the heritage funding, the parliamentary secretary who spoke previously talked about paving new ways of doing things and going in new directions. I say: what was wrong with some of the old directions? If you want a job done, what is wrong with bringing state and local government money into it? If you want a job done in the urban areas, then certainly it needs Commonwealth funding.

There are some tremendous problems happening now because of the residential build-up in areas. In fact, when I spoke previously about the environment and creeks, one of the reasons we are looking at using another method to clear floodways and clean up the creek system is to assist and help in flood mitigation programs. It boils down to the fact that flooding comes without warning. If we do not take action prior to flooding, then for the people who are going to be affected in the long term, it is going to be a lot more costly to overcome.

In our area we have been raising houses so that they are above the flood mitigation levels. People could say that in the fifties and sixties they should never have been given consent to build there, but try to tell that to people when they have bought their land in good faith and they have built their house on it. What we are doing there in regard to flood mitigation is to raise those houses so that at least people's lives and properties are not damaged when those creeks flood. This is part of the Georges River and Prospect Creek management.

We have not had one penny allocated by this government since they came to power in 1996, following that national audit excuse which was used to cut out the $80 million funding. It is all very well to have lobbying by rural and regional areas, even though they are getting a paltry amount of money—$20 million over three years is not going to fix one iota of the concerns and problems that rural and regional centres have. (Extension of time granted) More particularly, I say to the government: you have to look realistically at where we are going. They cannot stand here preaching on the one hand about how great they are on the environment, having regard to the Natural Heritage Trust, and selling off all the family silver by way of Telstra, without taking into account on the other hand programs that were in place, programs that were doing a good job, programs that were working, with the cooperation of the local and state governments, and at least putting the money in—

talk.start.para: (Mr Quick)—Order! I remind members of standing order 55—members should be heard in silence. Members have had the opportunity to have their say. In this debate, members have five minutes in which to speak. I ask people to refrain from interjecting.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order—
—The honourable member for Mitchell will resume his seat. There is no point of order.
—I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—There is no point of order.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, under standing order 80, any member may raise a point of order at any point in the debate, as you should well know. How can you determine that there is not a point of order until you have actually heard the point of order?
—I call the honourable member for Sturt on a point of order.

—I take my cue from the Manager of Opposition Business in the House, who does this on a regular basis. My point of order is that you have said that the member for Mitchell does not have a point of order and you sat him down before you even had the opportunity to hear his point of order. Under standing order 80, he has a perfect right to make his point of order and you have to listen to it. That is what the standing order requires.
—Does the honourable member for Mitchell have a point of order?

—Mr Deputy Speaker, you were not in the chair earlier in the day. I would like to see deputy speakers apply the rule of non-interruption consistently. I had consistent interruption from the member for Prospect when I was speaking. I did not interrupt her when I walked into the chamber, but she constantly interrupted me. If she is going to do that to us, we will respond.
—I call the honourable member for Prospect to continue her remarks.

—I also want to speak further to the point of order that has just been raised by the honourable member for Mitchell. I would like to have him and the House informed as to what part of the standing orders say that when he walks in and suddenly feels that I am going to interrupt him at some time in the future that he can take a point of order. That is an absolutely ridiculous statement. I think, with his experience and the number of years that he has been in this political process, he would know that there is no point of order.

speech.para: Mr Deputy Speaker, I will take on board what you were saying and be not the least bit disturbed. I will continue to talk on what I have been talking about, flood mitigation. I am glad the member for Mitchell has come into the Main Committee because I will be able to go to his councils and say that he got up and objected to my statement that the Commonwealth government needs to fund, through the state governments and local councils, further flood mitigation in Western Sydney. It will give me great delight to inform the councils that he represents that he objects to me stating that, if we are going to give consideration to adequate funding, we have to look not at the $20 million being spent over three years in rural and regional Australia but at what is happening with the flood mitigation program, where $80 million was wiped by the Howard government following that pretentious `national audit' in 1996.

Councils will be delighted to know that this is what the honourable member for Mitchell thinks of them and their attempts to get the flood mitigation program going—that he feels it is unjust for me to get up and bring to light during a budget debate that not one cent of the $80 million that was wiped in 1996 has been restored to this funding program. Not one cent from 1996 has been restored to urban flood mitigation. Not one cent in these budget papers or in the forward estimates for flood mitigation programs is going to be allocated in the future for Western Sydney.

As the honourable member for Mitchell knows—and we have been involved in a number of projects both with the Western Sydney Regional Organisation of Councils and with the councils that we represent—one of the largest cries from councils in Fairfield, Blacktown, Penrith, Baulkham Hills, Parramatta, Hawkesbury and Nepean is that this government wiped the flood mitigation program. How proud the member for Mitchell must be! He will not even get up and support a program in which the prime objective of all of the councils involved—the 10 councils that make up the Western Sydney Regional Organisation of Councils—is to put pressure on this government, to lobby this government through their local members of parliament, to have commonsense prevail and have part of that $80 million that was taken out of the program in 1996 restored. But that is fine, Mr Deputy Speaker, I will take on board what the honourable member has said. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Firstly, on a personal explanation. I have not said the things the member claimed.
—Order! The honourable member for Mitchell, we are debating the Department of Transport and Regional Services—
—Yes, I am aware of that. I was absolutely misrepresented.
—and I would ask the member to speak to the bill.

—I intend to. I am just saying that the member for Prospect completely misrepresented my statements. She feels that she has the right to interrupt other members but that she is not allowed to be interrupted herself. In fact, the point of order I took was about the way in which the rules of this chamber were being applied.

speech.para: I want to congratulate the Minister for Transport and Regional Services for the decision on the orbital road. I think that was a far-sighted decision and one that has been on the drawing board for many years. It was the Labor Party that first investigated it but did nothing towards it. They had a line on a map and that is as far as it got. It took the arrival of this government to do the environmental studies and to make the financial commitments. This was something the Australian Labor Party could not do because they were stony-broke and in debt. Therefore, there was no way they could make a commitment of the type—with the vision—that this government has made.

I congratulate the minister for the way in which he has launched this magnificent national project to build a highway of high quality around Sydney. I say to the minister—and I know the members for Robertson and Berowra would agree—that the areas we represent would be very keen to see the continuity of the project, and that there be no pause in the process. The people of our areas need to see a continuity of good management in government if they expect to see a process of bringing this to finality.

I say to the minister that the area that I represent, as well as the areas represented by the members for Robertson and Berowra, are very keen to see that the project continues and that there is no pause in the project. People in our areas need to see a continuity of good government management if this process is to be brought to finality.

talk.start.para: —It will only happen with cooperation from the RTA.

—It will indeed, and it will only happen with the cooperation of state governments and the continuation of a federal coalition government. The fact is that, if we were not in government, Carl Scully would call the shots over a federal Labor transport minister, and goodness knows where that would finish up. It would be a great crime to see the project half finished.

speech.para: With respect to transport issues, I also want to raise Sydney airport and the slot scheme discussion paper that has been put out. On behalf of residents in my area, I inform the minister that we have seen a very vocal group of people who are conscious of Sydney's airport needs and noise pollution, and who are based around the inner city suburbs. On behalf of the residents of outer suburbs, who are also affected, I would like to thank him for entering into this slot scheme discussion, because I think that the scheme has merits, and residents in the electorate of Mitchell see great merit in the proposals. They say that the enforcement of curfews and hourly capping is an advantage. They refer also to making more uniform in time the movements in and out of Sydney, and making sure that the number of aircraft will not increase, by encouraging larger aircraft to cater for the inevitable increase in passenger numbers and encouraging some regional flights to bypass Sydney.

However, they are seeking information about possible flight paths in and out of Bankstown and the way in which Bankstown may be used. They are also concerned that the handling of movements for Bankstown has not been made public at this point. I have informed them that, in my opinion, the Bankstown decision is certainly the best of those available. Certainly, Badgerys Creek was not an option, but moving towards the use of Bankstown is a very good decision in a long-term, measured way, with the proviso—and I know the Leader of the National Party of Australia understands this—that nobody in rural New South Wales should be disadvantaged. That is an absolutely golden proviso because people in regional areas have, I believe, equal rights to those of people living in urban areas, and they must be looked after in those terms. It is okay for people travelling between Sydney and Melbourne to say that they want to run the airlines their way, but the protection of regional services is vital. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I take this brief opportunity to talk about a road project in my electorate of Charlton which missed out on funding in this budget. Following the budget, the Australian Local Government Association put out a media release which criticised the Commonwealth for its failure to address the serious shortfall in national road funding. The President of the Local Government Association, Councillor Ross, stated:

quote.para: ... Australia's degraded road infrastructure still requires substantial and sustained additional funding, well beyond the measures ... announced over recent months.

speech.para: He was talking about the Roads to Recovery program. He continued:

quote.para: “The Government has missed this golden opportunity to build on last year's Roads toRecovery initiative. Indeed, the forward estimates released today show that by 2004-2005, total road funding will fall by 25% in real terms,” ...

speech.para: At the beginning of this year the Mayor of the City of Lake Macquarie wrote to me seeking my support for Commonwealth government funding approval for the integrated transport strategy, under the Roads to Recovery program. He stated:

quote.para: Lake Macquarie is the largest regional centre North of Sydney, and acts in a pivotal role as the gateway to the Hunter. This project will provide an important part of an essential arterial route, to improve connections from the Hunter Region's largest employment zone, to the National Highway and the Port of Newcastle. The Newcastle and Hunter Business Chamber views the project as one of regional significance within their regional infrastructure Strategic Plan, and therefore have endorsed the project.

speech.para: I wrote to the minister at the table supporting this proposal and the application for funding under the program. The council applied specifically for funding for a project under the Roads of National Importance program. The Lake Macquarie City Council has proposed an integrated transport strategy as an important infrastructure project for the Hunter region and is seeking Commonwealth funding assistance. It has also proposed that funding of $26 million will come from the New South Wales government and $1.4 million from council.

The funding for the planning of the new railway station and transport interchange was announced in the New South Wales state budget. The project is a major infrastructure development for the Hunter region and will generate job growth, improve access to public transport and provide environmental benefits for Lake Macquarie. In the past 10 years in excess of 1,000 new employment positions have been created in Lake Macquarie, most within the Cardiff Industrial Park in my electorate of Charlton. It is proposed that the estate be expanded and further developed. The industrial area houses major transport firms, such as John Farragher Transport and Logistics, and Powerdown Australia, a major manufacturer and exporter of bus chassis.

However, businesses are hindered by treacherous and inefficient road links to the F3 freeway. Lake Macquarie City Council's proposed integrated transport strategy will alleviate this problem. The Hunter region has suffered significantly following the closure of BHP and the downturn in our manufacturing industry. I believe this proposal will greatly assist the maintenance and extension of employment opportunities in the region. I supported the application for funding under the Roads to Recovery program for the Lake Macquarie integrated transport centre and I recommended it to the minister for his favourable consideration.

The City of Lake Macquarie is one of the fastest growing areas in New South Wales. It is centred on Australia's largest coastal lake and is flanked by both mountains and the Pacific Ocean. It has unique environmental and economic potential to become one of the most desirable areas in which to live in Australia. As the city's role as a major urban and tourism centre develops, our challenge is to realise this potential by providing and improving facilities to encourage and facilitate economic growth within the Hunter region. Today, its population of 185,000 and work force of 96,000 are major economic drivers in the Hunter region. The Lake Macquarie integrated transport centre is an infrastructure project that addresses job creation, improves road safety and increases public transport accessibility for a large proportion of Lake Macquarie and western Newcastle residents, and provides improved access to the national highway and the port of Newcastle. I understand that the mayor and the general manager of the city met with Senator Ian Macdonald earlier this year and held discussions with him. However, we are yet to get a response from the minister about the funding of this nationally important project.

talk.start.para: —I welcome the Roads to Recovery package and, in particular, the $80 million which has been allocated to the F3 freeway. I am very pleased that the Deputy Prime Minister is in the chamber today, and I record the thanks of the thousands of Central Coast commuters who regularly use the F3 freeway. It is the main road transport link between the Central Coast and Sydney. I heard the member opposite speaking about the rapidly expanding area of Lake Macquarie, and, of course, for that area the only main road transport link to Sydney is the F3.

speech.para: When I was first elected to parliament in 1996, I was shocked to hear that the previous Labor government had done absolutely no forward planning with regard to the F3, despite the fact that it was the most heavily trafficked road in New South Wales and that it was obvious that the surrounding areas were expanding rapidly. So I was behind the eight ball when I was elected. I made a commitment to the people of the Central Coast that I would do everything I could to ensure that funding was made available. Certainly, when the coalition government were elected we found that there was virtually no money in the bank. We had to address the huge deficit that the Labor Party had left us. We worked hard on that, and now we can start to return some of that money to the Australian community in the form of better roads through the Roads to Recovery program in projects such as the F3.

I have to record my anger with, and disgust at, some of the actions of the New South Wales government in relation to this funding. Firstly, their roads minister, Mr Scully, when we announced this money, said `Oh well, it's not enough; there should be more.' Then he had the audacity to say that the money was not available now and would not be available until 2004. The money is available today. If the RTA can get their act together, can get their planning done and can get their costings done, we can start widening the freeway by the end of the year. But the Labor Party continue this campaign of misinformation. Only today I have received a letter that a constituent received from the Labor Party candidate in Robertson who continues this myth that the money is not available and that it will not be available until 2002 or 2004. It is totally untrue. Already the Deputy Prime Minister has written to the New South Wales government assuring them that that money is available. In fact, on 24 May 2001 the Prime Minister wrote to the Premier of New South Wales, Bob Carr. I will read some of that letter into Hansard:

quote.para: My dear Premier
I am writing to you concerning Commonwealth funding for widening of the F3 Freeway between the Hawkesbury River and Calga.
It is reported that the NSW Minister for Transport, the Hon Carl Scully MP, has claimed that the Commonwealth Government is holding up funding for this project.

These reported statements by Mr Scully refer to the absence of Commonwealth allocation to the F3 for 2001-02. I am advised that the absence of an allocation in the coming year reflects advice from the NSW Roads and Traffic Authority that commencement of the widening project would need to await substantial planning and environmental assessment work.

In relation to this, I would point out that the Commonwealth has today received a request from the RTA for preconstruction funding of $2 million in 2001-02 and this has been approved pending submission of a formal project proposal report.

speech.para: The last paragraph of this letter could not be clearer. This is from the Prime Minister of Australia to Premier Carr:

quote.para: I wish to assure you that the Commonwealth funding of $80 million will flow as soon as construction starts. If it starts this year, funding will flow this year. I would ask therefore that you instruct your transport Minister to begin construction work by the end of this calendar year.

speech.para: That is very clear. It is very plain. It is what the commuters of the Central Coast of New South Wales want. It is what they are demanding. I am demanding that the RTA get their act together, that the minister makes sure that his department get their act together and that they get their planning in place so that they can start construction of that urgently needed widening of the F3 freeway between Calga and the Hawkesbury River so that the commuters of the Central Coast will not continue to suffer the constant delays that they now suffer simply because of traffic congestion. Every peak hour the traffic delays are considerable. Particularly on Friday evenings delays can be up to half an hour or an hour—not through any accident but just through the sheer volume of traffic coming down from three lanes to two lanes at Mount White. As a community we have worked hard for five years to secure this funding. The funding is there now. It is the responsibility of the New South Wales government and the RTA to start the construction, to start the widening, this year.

talk.start.para: —I want to move to an issue that was part of the speech I made in the longer debate which was somewhat truncated. This issue, the lack of an infrastructure program in this country, impacts greatly on regional Australia. I am disappointed to see that one key recommendation, recommendation 6 of the report called Time running out by this parliament's regional affairs and primary industry committee, of which I am a member, has yet to be acted upon. It calls for the establishment of a national infrastructure advisory council with expertise from public and private sectors to facilitate the efficient and equitable provision of national infrastructure. At the moment infrastructure planning is largely marked by short-term politics and adhocery. One only has to look at the Sydney-Canberra VFT project or, indeed, the Adelaide-Darwin rail line to see start-stop planning and ill-directed funding largely based on political considerations rather than nation building purposes.

speech.para: I am glad that the National Party now wants to own the Parkes Inland Marketing Corporation project. A few years back it did not even wish to honour a 1996 election undertaking to fund a feasibility study. Another issue that has received scant attention from the National Party is the plan jointly promoted by the Central Regional Organisation of Councils and the Institute of Chartered Accountants for regional enterprise zones. If there has been any movement on this front in the last few weeks I would be interested if the minister could bring that to my attention.

I attended a seminar organised by CENTROC in Cowra late last year. It detailed the potential for targeted assistance zones. We heard from a former aide to the Clinton administration about just how effectively the United States has used such a system to promote growth in many of its less naturally endowed rural areas. Declaration as an enterprise zone would be available to areas experiencing economic distress, particularly those experiencing high unemployment. The Commonwealth government would assist the zones through wage subsidies and tax concessions, and the institute assures me that the proposed arrangements are constitutionally valid.

The study, which was launched by CENTROC and the Institute of Chartered Accountants in April this year here in Parliament House, called for a parliamentary taskforce to develop targeted incentives for regional Australia, with this work to be completed by September this year. I would like to know whether that deadline has been acknowledged by the government, and whether any positive process has been put in place to address that call. I understand the opposition has indicated some sort of commitment to the concept, but I look forward to both the opposition and the government officially spelling out any commitment in the weeks and months ahead. Such a commitment would, I suggest, require a quantum shift from government about its role in economic development, and a recognition that the free market alone does not deliver opportunity and jobs equally across Australia. I live in hope, remembering my first meeting of the 1996 parliament's Primary Industries and Regional Services Committee. At that time, a senior Labor Party member seemed to suggest that regional development—and indeed rural development—inquiries should involve the committee examining the economic opportunities and problems of Newcastle, Wollongong and Geelong. It was quickly pointed out by those members from rural seats that the crisis then facing us was the future of rural and regional centres, meaning places like Tamworth, Dubbo and Lithgow.

The enterprise zones have been championed by the central organisation of councils, encompassing most of the council areas in the central west of New South Wales. The inspiration for the zones has been generated and driven by Cowra Shire Council's economic development manager, Graham Apthorpe. He recently provided me with some data from a company involved in the sad business of relocating Australian businesses offshore. In the 2000 calendar year, this company helped with the relocation of a dozen businesses to locations such as New Zealand, China, South Africa, Thailand and Sri Lanka. The businesses include a printed circuit board manufacturer, a textile manufacturer, a door manufacturer, a small electrical motor manufacturer, an air-conditioning maker and a plastics manufacturer. In recent weeks, the Canobolas wool top plant in Orange could have been added to that list. It has decided to close its doors at the end of this month becausesurprise, surprise!the production of wool tops and scoured wool can more economically be provided from a factory in China. (Extension of time granted)

People are asking how we can more proactively support that industry. I certainly have not got the answers.
