I know there are good examples around the country of successful wool topping and early stage value adding to wool, but it strikes me that we have a product which we are so ready to export so minutely value added that we are giving away a lot of the value of the product to people offshore, including people in Japan and, I guess, Italy. With the proper support mechanisms, we have the capacity, I think, to develop a supportable textile industry with a distinctly Australian product from paddock to coat hook.

Another issue needing urgent attention, and one that seems to be placed in the too-hard basket, is the provision of a proper transport corridor across the Blue Mountains. While spending on the Roads to Recovery program is very welcome, it is the road across the mountains which is the main economic stimulus that the west of the state needs to play its share in both business coming to the west and getting its product to the markets. Along with this, we need to be looking seriously at the north-south transport links into the ports of Newcastle and Wollongong. I would love to see the submission by councils and chambers of commerce for a feasibility study into the road across the mountains, because although it was declared a RONI prior to the last election—and that was welcome—it seems to me that we are creating a major urban arterial route through the mountains. I travel it regularly, and trying to get through there on a Sunday afternoon is no mean feat, I can tell you.

We have still got 60, 70 and 80 kilometres per hour zones through there and I presume we will always have them, because it is becoming a quicker route to Sydney. It seems to me that we will never have a national highway by upgrading that route. We will have an equivalent of Pennant Hills Road and probably, down the track, we will also have all of the daily commuter dramas that that road is creating in the northern suburbs of Sydney. I do not believe it is going to serve the purpose that one would hope it could, of being the major—and I think it should be national—highway through to the vast food bowl of inland New South Wales.

I certainly have not got the answers, but I think that, irrespective of the fact that we now have a wonderful new World Heritage park in the Blue Mountains and Wollemi and so on, there are environmental difficulties that have to be addressed. We need to look at how we can create a corridor through there—perhaps the Bell's Line of Road—and it really does need a commitment from the state government and the necessary support from the federal government. Rail should also be looked at as part of the transport corridor through there, and it should be upgraded so that we are not putting $300,000 rigs over the mountains all the time. Perhaps a lot of the transport operators say, `We would prefer it if we had a roll-on, roll-off process to do our transport.' I would be interested to hear what the minister is thinking along those lines about that particular route.

Recently, the Mount Panorama motor racing circuit has become the subject of much debate in the electorate. It is something that is going to be there as a national icon long after I depart this place. It really does need to be looked at as an international circuit needing to be brought up to international sporting standards. I know that a submission looking for some form of government assistance will be coming the way of the state and federal governments in the short term. I would hope that it is looked at with a long-term vision rather than a short-term political periscope, or whatever you look at these things with.

talk.start.para: —On Monday I spoke in the House during the grievance debate about the sale of Sydney airport and the failure of the government to deliver on its promises to fix Sydney's aircraft noise problems fairly. Mr Deputy Speaker, as you would be aware, I have made many speeches on those topics, in relation to the sale of the airport and also the long-term operating plan for Sydney airport. I have also moved many motions successfully at the Sydney airport community forum.

speech.para: I was pleased that the minister was here a moment ago. I notice that he has walked out of the chamber, but I presume he will be coming back. I would like to start on a positive note, because I have been very critical of the government on this issue since my first speech in this House on 12 November 1998. I have been critical of the government because it is the most important local issue for my electorate. There are approximately 1,300 people in my electorate who just happen to think that a 747 droning over their home at all times of the day and night is more important to them than some of the important national issues like the implementation of the GST, education, health and other issues.

In terms of this issue, I would like to start on a positive note, at least, and thank the minister for the courtesy that he has extended regarding the very numerous questions that I have placed on the Notice Paper in the time that I have been a member of this House—unlike his colleague the Minister for Health and Aged Care, who refuses to answer legitimate questions. I can say that he has answered my questions truthfully and honestly—and I am pleased the minister is walking in as I am saying this. Although, Minister, in the main I do not like the answers that you are giving me on behalf of my residents in terms of the sale of Sydney airport, the introduction of Bankstown, the shelving of Badgerys Creek and the failure to implement the long-term operating plan fairly—and I will talk about that in a moment—I do want to thank you most sincerely, on behalf of my constituents, for at least answering my questions. Please convey that to your staff, who obviously do quite a bit of researchas my staff do, and as I have done, because I have spent an inordinate amount of time representing my electorate on this issue. Why? Because on almost a daily basis I get complaints to my office about aircraft noise.

I would like briefly to go through the history of this issue, because under the coalition's aviation policy of 13 February 1996, titled Soaring into tomorrow, the then Howard opposition went to the people of Australia and said, `We're going to fix aircraft noise.' In those days, certainly, aircraft noise was a very hot issue in Sydney and particularly in my electorate of Lowe. The then sitting member, Mary Easson, who was a member of the previous government, explained the implications of what the coalition was promising to visit on the people of Lowe, should it be elected. That showed quite clearly what the flight paths would be. The candidate from the coalition, a member of the Liberal Party, said that this was not a Liberal Party policy—which has been shown to be false—and that the Liberal Party had the answers and that they would halve the number of planes flying over Lowe. We know that that is not the case.

Very shortly after the Howard government was elected in 1996, in August 1996, the Airports Bill went through parliament. There was bipartisan support for the future sale of Sydney airport, but that was conditional on fixing the problems associated with aircraft noise. (Extension of time granted) That meant the implementation of the long-term operating plan and also a decision to be made at a future time to build a second airport for Sydney, to take the pressure off Kingsford Smith Airport. When the bill was debated in the parliament, Minister Sharp, who was in the job at that time, promised to fix the aircraft noise problems associated with Kingsford Smith Airport, and also foreshadowed the future construction of a second airport for the people of Sydney.

We have subsequently learned that that debate was all about an expectation that whoever purchased that 50-year lease for Sydney airport would only have an option to build a second airport. The clear understanding, by all people who had been associated with the debate, was that the agreement to the sale of Sydney airport was on the clear understanding that a second airport would be built. That is what people effectively meant. It would appear, certainly from the campaign I have run by placing questions on the Notice Paper to try to get answers, that the government is in a position to effectively run away from the commitment to build a Sydney west airport—which is Badgerys Creek—in the foreseeable future.

Why are they doing this? They are doing it simply to maximise the sale price of Sydney airport. The lease sale price, as I understand it from various reports, is about $4 billion. If the government were to require the purchaser of that lease to also build a Sydney West airport, no doubt the sale price for Sydney airport would be significantly less than $4 billion. Obviously, in this whole debate about resolving the aircraft noise problem for the people of Sydney the government are more concerned with the economic imperatives of maximising the sale price for Sydney airport and accommodating the vested and sectional interests that want to see Sydney airport stay where it is.

The grave concern for my electorate, Minister, is that the expansion of Sydney airport by effectively making Bankstown airport an overflow airport—a de facto second airport, if you like—for the people of Sydney has disastrous consequences for people of the inner west, particularly my electorate. If you maximise Sydney airport you will slowly see a return to parallel runway operations and we know what the PRM is all about. The western end of my electorate will suffer because of the increased air traffic from Bankstown airport. It is a very serious issue for the people of Lowe. I asked you a question, Minister, on the notice paper on 28 March—and thank you for your reply of 7 June 2001. Inter alia, I asked you if there was now a satisfactory solution to the current aircraft noise problems in Sydney and, if so, upon what criteria this conclusion had been reached. The answer you provided was:

quote.para: The government has introduced the long-term operating plan to address Sydney airport's noise issues. The plan has been very successful in sharing the noise generated by the airport compared with the situation that existed immediately prior to March 1996.

speech.para: Today I have put a further question on notice in response to the reply that you gave me. I just want you to clearly understand, because I do not think the message is getting through to the people who are advising you, that we are getting 60 per cent more air traffic movements to the north than were foreshadowed in the long-term operating plan for the residents of Sydney. It is not truthful or fair for you to say to me that the long-term operating plan has been `very successful in sharing the noise', because that is not the truth. The people who are to the north and the north-west of Sydney airport are suffering the most and the planes that are flying over my electorate are avoiding the Prime Minister's electorate. (Extension of time granted) I would like to think that you could leave this chamber this morning and go back to your officers and insist that they get a reduction in the horrendous levels of aircraft noise. As I said, we are getting 60 per cent more air traffic movements than we were promised under the long-term operating plan. We, on our side of the House, think that the long-term operating plan can work but we also believe that we need a second airport for Sydney. We do not think that Bankstown is the option.

I would like to know from you, and it is foreshadowed in my questions on the Notice Paper today: when will the long-term operating plan be fully implemented? In other words, I would like to know when the people of Lowe are going to get only 17 per cent air traffic movements to the north. What is your long-term plan for building Sydney West airport at Badgerys Creek for the citizens of Sydney? What is the time frame for your agenda to sell Sydney airport? If I am not mistaken, I think I heard you on radio last week in Sydney saying that you wanted to have Sydney airport sold by the end of the year. If you want to have Sydney airport sold by the end of the year, Minister, the least that you can do for my constituents, who are concerned very much by this issue, is to have air traffic movements to the north at 17 per cent and some answer with regard to how soon we can start building Badgerys Creek. Thank you.

talk.start.para: —One of the great frustrations with transport—and it certainly must be for a minister, whether federal or state, or even for people involved in local government—is that the debate on road and rail investment in this country is appalling, and it has been appalling under all fashions of governments for far too long. Let us look at expenditure since 1996—and I am sure the Minister for Transport and Regional Services will correct me if I am wrong. We have spent about $8 billion on roads in this country but about $250 million has been committed to rail. That is an incredible imbalance. A country railroad in the electorate of, perhaps, the member for Hinkler loses a couple of million and everybody in this country goes ape. Yet we spend billions and billions of dollars subsidising roads and road transport companies in this country and we do not seem to blink one eyelid. The debate loses a considerable deal because we do not look at all the imperatives and all the impacts of funding for rail or road. For example, a recent German study showed quite clearly that if you invested a billion deutschmarks on rail, road or light rail there would be very different impacts in terms of an employment dividend. If you invest in roads, you get about 10,000 to 12,000 jobs; if you invest in heavy rail, you get about 22,000 jobs. If you invest in light rail, you get about 24,000 jobs. Maybe that is an issue that the minister ought to take on board—as should, particularly, his department, which has a particularly narrow view of anything other than road transport.

speech.para: I would like to make one comment about this budget: $600 million has gone towards company cars and subsidies for transport rigs. I think the minister's own group, the Australian Rail Track Corporation, has shown that, if you spent $500 million or $600 million on rail instead of transport rigs or company cars, you could shift two or three million tonnes of freight off our roads and onto rail. It would be far more efficient, with a better employment dividend, and much better for the country.

The subsidy for roads in this country amounts to billions and billions. It is a hidden subsidy, one that is forgotten in any debate—freight insurance, hospitalisation, road trauma, road maintenance, the list goes on and on and on. I am not suggesting that we should not invest in roads. That would be a stupid point of view to put forward. But the investment in and the balance between other forms of transport in this country is just simply appalling. As for the debate, I have to say that even when we were in power you never looked for any initiative or any creativity or any innovation from almost anyone in transport in this country. Professor Peter Newman, who was a transport expert in Western Australia, convinced the then Labor government to build a northern suburbs railway. It was a big investment, nearly $300 million, but it proved it worked. All the gurus who were here said that he was stupid, that the Labor government was wasting money. It was not a waste of money. That was not even a freight service, but a passenger service. Why is the debate so minimalist? Why is it so narrow? Why doesn't it look at a wider circle than just roads, such as rail, shipping and air?

Our investment in shipping in this country—and I will not go into that right now—is laughable for a trading nation, in the sense of the millions of jobs, or potential jobs, we lose because we send all our money in terms of insurance and shipping overseas. Absolute rubbish! Unfortunately, no government in this country has had the guts to take shipping seriously, but you have to say that no-one takes rail seriously either.

I notice that the member for Hinkler is here. He chaired a parliamentary committee which produced what I thought was an admirable report. The report suggested a whole lot of new investment in rail. Unfortunately, that has not been taken up. In this budget there is probably only $26 million for rail. When will governments take note of the findings of bipartisan committees—committees led by people with a bit of commonsense, like the member for Hinkler? But your government does not take any notice. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I was not going to speak in this debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 2001-2002, and it grieves me to disagree with my colleague the member for Port Adelaide, but—
—It's good to hear you grieving.
—I do grieve—he is one of the few people in this place whom I genuinely admire.
—What about me?
—You're all right. I think there is a bit of oversimplification here. This government has committed $250 million to rail.
—You recommended it.

—Yes. It is true that our committee recommended that $200 million a year should be spent for a decade. You are quite right that, in the great scheme of land transport, $200 million is a drop in the bucket. Nevertheless, it is not just a simplistic problem of rushing out and spending money on rail. There is a perception that, because we linked Melbourne to Adelaide back in the seventies or the eighties, we had this seamless corridor from Brisbane to Perth. It was not quite that simple. There were 23 operating standards and 14 different radio standards, so it was not a seamless corridor. In other words, for rail to achieve its full potential on that major trunk route from Brisbane to Perth—and I presume that that is what you are talking about—there are some other intermediate steps. Amongst them is the New South Wales government's inability to grant proper access through the ARTC.

speech.para: This government has put the ARTC in place, and it is the access organisation. If you can get clear and transparent access from Brisbane through to Perth, you are more likely to use rail, and there is then greater justification for the government to upgrade the track. It is true that along the east-west corridor 70 per cent of the freight task goes on rail. On the north-south corridor, it is 10 per cent. Part of the reason why is the access. I am a great believer in upgrading the track. If you get the below track operations right—and I see that the member for Lowe is here; he is another supporter of this committee—you will attract state rail authority trains or private trains and you will get greater utilisation of the track. But it is not a simplistic thing whereby the government just throws money at the track itself—much as I would like it to be that way.

The other thing you should recognise is that the government has also put money into Compton's ATEC proposal for a track from Melbourne to Darwin. A lot of people said, `That's pie in the sky—that'll never happen.' I have known Everald Compton for 30 years and he has never not made a success of something he has put his hand to—never. He has been in charge of rebuilding university colleges and things in England, and he is a master at putting major projects together. He is not saying that you should rush out and throw a lot of Commonwealth money at this thing; in fact, he wants only very modest amounts of Commonwealth money.

Everald Compton says that it can be done commercially if the government gives certain support, and the government has done so—it has funded a prefeasibility study from Melbourne to Brisbane and it has funded a freight study from Toowoomba to Gladstone, which proved positive. It said that if you got these new coalmines in the Serap Basin going then that was justified. The government has encouraged this organisation to prove each step of this thing. You do not build a train right through to Darwin and expect it to pay. You take it through the most productive part of Australia—central Victoria, central western New South Wales, southern Queensland to Toowoomba, with a branch down to Brisbane; that is feasible. The study says it is feasible onto Gladstone. Then a fortnight or three weeks ago, the minister gave another $250,000 to do the prefeasibility study for the section from Toowoomba to Gladstone.

I do not think that shows the government stepping away from it. I, like you, would like more spent on the below-track infrastructure. I firmly believe that that is where we can have a huge increase in usage. An example of this is the line from Brisbane to Rockhampton, which successive Queensland governments have done up to tilt rail standard, which has halved the travel time from Rockhampton to Brisbane. We could be doing this all over Australia. I agree with you in principle but I do not think it is necessarily fair to be bagging the government, because this minister has been quite supportive.

talk.start.para: —I do not want to put down the contribution of the member for Hinkler, but we have never spent big on rail in this country. There is a fallacious argument that gets put forward. I remember a fellow who used to advise our side of parliament in 1983, from New South Wales railways, a fellow called David Hill. I remember his contribution when the Adelaide-Darwin railway should have been built by us in that early period of the Hawke-Keating government, and was not—for all the wrong reasons. The wrong reasons were—and that was part of the fallacious argument put forward then—`You don't solve the problem by throwing money at it.' That is a pretty glib statement, because we have not thrown money at rail in this country for 50 or 60 years. So let us not talk that sort of nonsense, for goodness sake.

speech.para: I said I would be brief and I know there are other people who want to speak in this debate. I would like to say something of a positive nature. I understand, in the way government operates in this nation, that if you are the minister for transport, state or federal, you have a very difficult go because it is not part of an intellectual debate. The debate is far too narrow. No-one looks at the employment dividends. No-one looks at the dividends in terms of the trauma and the injuries that you see in Australia—the people who live all the rest of their lives crippled and maimed, unnecessarily, because of road accidents. I have just come back from New Zealand. It is just amazing the people you see on the street, young and old, who are crippled. When you talk to them they say how they were crippled: road accidents. They have one of the greatest rates of road accident trauma in the world, partly because of their road system and partly because, except in Wellington, they do not even have a commuter train system. It is only a country of 3.4 million people but they did have commuter train systems.

There are other impacts than just the road or rail debate. There is an employment dividend. There is a care of citizen duty that often never comes up in the road or rail or shipping debate. There are defence aspects, as well. I must say, even though I would have liked to have seen a far greater contribution—and I am sure the member for the Northern Territory supports this as well—that creating a north-south land bridge on the only island continent on earth, the Adelaide-Alice Springs-Darwin railway, is a great thing. I do not think, in the debate, anyone has explored the possibilities of what can be done not only for the eastern seaboard, on the eastern side of the Dividing Range—which so much debate in this country seems to boil down to—but for Australia.

The member for Hinkler mentioned that 70 per cent of the freight from Adelaide to Perth goes on the rail. It ought to be 100 per cent. There is no reason for any semitrailer, B-double or whatever, to go from Adelaide to Perth. There is a company in my electorate called Air-Ride. I am sure you are familiar with it; I am sure you have been there. You can load up 100 semitrailers on a train in two or three hours. Yet no-one has invested in that company. I say to the member for Hinkler that in the United States they have tens of thousands of these things on their freight systems. They are highly efficient and it gets the trucks off the road. We have trucks going from Adelaide to Brisbane on a daily basis. That is just stupid.

Under what conditions do those semitrailer drivers operate? Some of them are taking loads up there and hanging around so long, trying to get a job to get back, that over a period of time they are actually losing money because their margins have been pushed so hard by some of these so-called logistics companies. We need a new approach to transport. I am one of the few people on this side who actually has had a bit of time for you, right from the first time you came in here, Deputy Prime Minister. I actually think you have, in many ways, a sensible approach to problems. But I would like to see you, in this term of government—which might not be much longer—look at it in terms of much broader perspectives than you do now. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The railway issue is not the subject I intended to speak upon, but I will make some comments in passing. I am pleased to see that the government has lived up to its commitment to fund its portion of the Darwin to Alice Springs railway, which has bipartisan support. Kim Beazley committed the Labor Party to that funding prior to the last election. It is worth noting, however, that it would have been a lot cheaper if it had been built in 1984, when it was offered to the Northern Territory government on a 60-40 split but the then Northern Territory Chief Minister, Paul Everingham—who later became the member for the Northern Territory—refused the offer. That rests fairly and squarely in the lap of the Northern Territory government and the CLP, this government's partners in the Northern Territory.

speech.para: Having said that, I think the Darwin to Alice Springs railway can—and may—bring great benefits. I am certainly hopeful that it will. But there are some downsides which we ought to contemplate. I do not quite share the views of my colleague from Port Adelaide on the issue of road transport, because I think the road transport industry is a very efficient industry. Whilst the margins are being cut for a whole range of reasons, not the least of which is the GST, the fact is that it provides timely delivery of goods which cannot be provided by rail. It is not my intention to go into that debate. I want to make the observation, however, that the development of the Darwin to Alice Springs railway has started and, while even as we speak facilities are being developed in Tennant Creek and Katherine, there is some concern in Alice Springs that people in the communities there who are well equipped to do the work may not get the jobs that are available because the major contractors involved may be bringing their workers from interstate. To me that means that, whilst it adds substance to the Northern Territory economy in terms of money coming in, people in the Territory may be missing out. I think the focus of employment in this rail project should be on employing people locally, on training up people in the Northern Territory to do this work and on subcontracting to Northern Territory firms.

I come now to the main concern I want to express today. I do not share the view of my colleague about the Deputy Prime Minister. Unfortunately, I see him as being a very partisan person who has used the Roads to Recovery program to rort the Treasury of this country for his own political purposes. I would like him to explain to me how he could possibly get to the position where his own electorate could receive, I think, $43 million when the Northern Territory received only $20 million in road funding under the Roads to Recovery program—

talk.start.para: —Because we used the Labor Party's Grants Commission approach, that's why.

—Oh, did you? Let me just ask you this question. If you used the approach of the Labor Party you would have understood that, using state shares of local government grants, the Northern Territory traditionally receives $28.1 million. Under your formula it received $20 million. You are $8.1 million shy. What is the answer to that? Where did that go? Whose backyard did that fill in? Can you explain how you got $43 million?
(Mrs Gash)—Would you direct your questions through the chair, thank you.

—Through you, Madam Deputy Speaker, I say to the Deputy Prime Minister: be left in no doubt about how you are perceived in the Northern Territory, because you have used your position. I note that all of the 17 electorates receiving funding of more than $25 million are held by coalition government members—
—That's not surprising.

—No, it is not. Let me ask you this question. The seat of Gwydir is an area of 114,000 square kilometres. The seat of the Northern Territory is an area of 1.34 million square kilometres. The number of voters in Gwydir is 72,930. The number of voters in the Northern Territory is 105,048. The population at the 1996 census for Gwydir was 111,146. The population of the Northern Territory was 190,000. The amount of money given to the seat of Gwydir equates per voter to $581 per head. In the case of the Northern Territory it is $190 per head. Per square kilometre it is $372 in Gwydir and $15 in the Northern Territory. (Extension of time granted) Even if you use the formula which is used to allocate local government road funding, where I believe the Northern Territory is underfunded, we are still at least 25 per cent shy of what we should be entitled to. There can be no valid explanation as to why people in the Northern Territory should be robbed blind by the Deputy Prime Minister through the Roads to Recovery program while he allocates resources to his mates. Let us be clear about it.

speech.para: Another issue which needs to be comprehended here is that the Northern Territory has special needs. I note, Madam Deputy Speaker, that the Deputy Prime Minister will use the justification that money has been made available to local government areas. Of course he knows, as do his advisers, that large areas of the Northern Territory roads are on unincorporated lands. As I understand it, no substantial allocation has been made. Of the Northern Territory government total, less than $2 million has been allocated for unincorporated roads. The literally thousands and thousands of kilometres of roads in the Northern Territory on unincorporated land are not funded. What is the result of that? Let me tell you. There is one community—and this goes hand in glove with the issue of flood mitigation—at Robertson River, which is about 150 kilometres south of Borroloola, to which my colleague and I paid a visit earlier this year, that has been without road access to that community since November of last year, when it was flooded.

talk.start.para: —It would not be tolerated anywhere else.

—It would not be tolerated anywhere else in Australia. This happens to be an Aboriginal community. I rang them the other week to try to find out what the price of fuel was. They could not tell me. They said, `We can't tell you what the price of fuel here is because we do not have any. Why don't we have any? Because we can't get it delivered.' That would not be tolerated in the member for Gwydir's electorate. It would not be tolerated in the electorates of the members for Maranoa, Kalgoorlie, Wannon, Parkes, McEwen, Kennedy, Indi, Farrer, Mallee, New England, Flinders, Gippsland, Murray, Riverina or Ballarat. All these electorates will receive $25 million or more under the Roads to Recovery program.

speech.para: The most disadvantaged people in Australia, the poorest people in Australia, bar none, live in the Northern Territory. The most disadvantaged in terms of transport infrastructure live in the Northern Territory. What this government has done is to treat them with contempt. We will get some response from the Deputy Prime Minister no doubt trying to justify his position. Let me ask you, Mr Deputy Prime Minister: if you are not responsible for these roads, who is? If you are not prepared to provide the funding for these roads, who should? If you do not accept responsibility for every Australian citizen in terms of this government and road infrastructure, who should? I understand the Northern Territory government have got a responsibilitythere is no doubt about thatbut, if they have that responsibility, where do they get the money from? Should they get it from their own resources, or should you be reviewing the Grants Commission formula to ensure they get more money? There has got to be an answer to this, and thus far it has not been forthcoming. It is not only in this area, of course, that this is a question.

I am conscious of the fact that other people want to speak, but I do want to raise another issue that really compounds this question of roads infrastructure, and that is the question of the impact of the GST on fuel. Let me ask the Deputy Prime Minister: do you think it is appropriate that people who live in my electorate, or at least some of them—in this case the people who live in Milikapiti on Bathurst Island—should pay an extra 10.3c tax on a litre of fuel as a result of the GST, whereas people in the Prime Minister's own electorate pay 2.58c extra tax as a result of the GST? That comes about because of the price of fuel. When the price of fuel is $1.80 a litre and you are paying huge amounts of extra tax, there has got to be an answer. I recall vividly the former Deputy Prime Minister visiting my electorate prior to the last election, with his Akubra—hail fellow, well met—saying to everyone who wanted to listen to him that the price of fuel need not rise. We had the then Northern Territory Chief Minister, now President of the Liberal Party, saying that the price of fuel would fall by 7c a litre. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I would like to clear up two things. The first one is to do with rail. We spoke about going from Melbourne to Adelaide. When we were on that committee and examined that track, it was a disgrace. We saw strips 20 and 30 metres long where the rails sat in a permanent puddle of mud. The Hon. Ralph Willis was with us at the time and he was Treasurer. Even he was outraged, because he could remember the amounts of money that he had allocated to that. We went to a marshalling yard where there were literally thousands of concrete sleepers that had never been used. They actually put the new concrete sleepers on old ballastnot retamped, I might addand then put second-hand track on top of the new sleepers. What a shambles. I am not saying that to criticise any government. But, to take the point made by the member for Port Adelaide, it is not simply a matter of throwing money. I was not being glib when I said that you could not throw money at it. There has got to be a strategic plan.

speech.para: To get a strategic plan you have got to have the states cede a certain amount of their power, whether or not it be in access through the ARTC, so that people are going to use the track. That is the first thing. The second thing is that I believe the answer is—and it is a recommendation in the report—that the main trunk line from Brisbane to Perth, via both Broken Hill and Melbourne, should be treated like the national road highway. It should be ceded to and controlled by the Commonwealth, either through the ARTC or through another corporation. Then you would get some of the benefits that you have spoken about. I think that should be a long-term ambition and a bipartisan position of all parties in this parliament.

On the matter of the Roads to Recovery grant, the argument from the member for the Northern Territory is exactly the same argument that I get from some of my larger but small area cities against the shires. They say, `Why does the city of so-and-so get so little money, when the shire of so-and-so, with only a tenth of the population, gets so much more?' It is because the formula is based not just on population but on the distance of roads. It is not based on area. It works out at about 80 per cent of the council's federal assistance grants. Those federal assistance grants, which are Commonwealth money, are allocated by the states through their grants commissions. It is hardly fair to start blaming the Commonwealth. You control all the states in Australia now bar South Australia. How can the member for Northern Territory start blaming the Commonwealth government because of the formula? It should not be a surprise to him that electorates like Gwydir, Maranoa, Kennedy and Leichhardt—

talk.start.para: —It is no surprise. We know it is not a surprise.

—Yes, because within those electorates there are quite a few local authorities—I imagine 11 or 12 in each electorate—that have long distances of road. In fact, you rather selectively left out the electorate of Capricornia. I think you will find that your colleague the member for Capricornia was also treated very generously—not because it is a Labor electorate or a National Party electorate or a Liberal electorate, but because it has a population base for each of those shires and a length of roads that have to be attended to.

speech.para: Quite frankly, while I understand the member's concern for his area—and I do not quibble with that at all—this confected outrage because the formula—

talk.start.para: —Go to the Robertson River and tell them.

—If the unincorporated areas of the Northern Territory are a problem, then surely that is a matter for the Northern Territory government to take to the Grants Commission, or for you, as the local member—

—That would seem to be the answer. But certainly, Madam Deputy Speaker, the formula is fair. I have not found one shire, or even those cities that want a bit more, that has complained about having the money. It has made a huge difference to the shires, cities and towns of my electorate, and I am pleased to have it.

—There is no doubt that there would not be a community in Australia that would not welcome the money. Give people the resources and they will accept them—there is no question about that. However, this is not about whether or not they should accept the money. This is about the mal-distribution of resources. This is about the mis-allocation of government money. This is about understanding the need around Australia and allocating money so that it gets to where it ought to be going.
—It is based on a formula.

—Let's go to that argument. This document is from the minister's own adviser talking to the Senate estimates committee. He made it very clear that—and he provided a table which demonstrates it—the Northern Territory government, even if you use that formula, is $8 million shy.
—Why?

—Ask the man sitting over there, Madam Deputy Speaker. The government seems to believe that they can parade around the country, doing as they like, when they like, how they like and to whom they like, and no-one is going to say anything. That is wrong. Get the Deputy Prime Minister to come to some of these committees and explain why people cannot travel on their roads and why the roads are inaccessible for some months of the year—and not just because of the weather. There are some roads in communities in my electorate which heavy vehicles will not travel on because of the state of disrepair. That imposes a huge cost on those communities—the poorest communities in Australia. And yet the Deputy Prime Minister does not bat an eyelid.

speech.para: I was talking about fuel prices, and I was retelling a story about the former Deputy Prime Minister parading around Northern Australia saying how the price of fuel need not rise. Let me ask this question of the Deputy Prime Minister: as a result of the GST, people at Milikapiti pay—

talk.start.para: (Mrs Gash)—Order! You will direct your questions through the chair.

—As a result of the GST, the people of Milikapiti pay $1.80 a litre for fuel. The extra tax they pay within that $1.80 as a result of the GST is 10.37c. The good burghers of North Ryde, when the price of fuel was 94.9c a litre—which was only a couple of weeks ago; I am not sure what it is today—paid 2.61c a litre in extra tax. How do you explain to the people in my electorate—people who live in remote communities and pay anywhere between, in Darwin, $1.03 to, in some places, $2 a litre—that the GST is a major component of the final price of the good, and it is different for them than it is for people living in Sydney and Melbourne?

speech.para: Why should people in the Northern Territory who live in remote communities pay more tax on their fuel as a result of the GST than the Deputy Prime Minister does in his own electorate? Why should they? What possible justification is there for people in the Northern Territory paying more total tax on their fuel when you include the GST than any other Australians? These are the poorest Australians, and they get the double whammy: not only do they pay more for their fuel with the extra impost of the GST but they do not get the resources to fix the roads on which they drive their vehicles.

A cartoon was published in the Northern Territory News of 28 May—`Wicking's View'. I commend it to honourable members. The cartoon shows a male and a female sitting in a room. `Snowdon is calling on the government to spend more on roads,' says the woman to her husband. Outside the window is a motor vehicle. The male says, `That we can't afford to drive on.'

It is pretty true. If you live in the Northern Territory, you suffer because of what this government has done, and we have had no reasonable explanation as to why the people of the Northern Territory should be discriminated against and disadvantaged in the way in which they have been by this government. Whilst the member for Gwydir might believe that somehow he is doing himself a great favour in his own electorate, he is doing no favours for the people in my electorate, and no favours for the people of Northern Australia generally, because this is not only a question for the Northern Territory. One day he will come to understand the folly of what he has done and the malicious nature of the way in which he has distributed these resources to the disadvantage of the poorest and most vulnerable people in this country.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr ANDERSON
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —I thank those who have contributed to the debate. The member for Prospect raised the matter of the Western Sydney orbital. In an ideal world, roads would be free, I suppose—as should petrol—but they never will be. The approach that we took there, worked up in consultation with all of the stakeholders, enabled us to bring forward by many years the construction of this major piece of very badly needed infrastructure in Western Sydney. There will be real savings in time and energy, and there will be business and personal benefits from the construction of the road. Motorists will have the option of using other roads if they choose not to pay a toll, of course. On balance, it is a reasonable way forward. I was keen to see it brought forward; I believe Minister Scully in New South Wales was as well.

speech.para: There was quite a bit of talk about the airports and airport related matters in Sydney, not just by the member for Prospect but by other members as well. The government sought to take a balanced decision in the interests of the various sectors of the community which have a very real concern about Sydney's future airport needs. It became very apparent to me, as I looked at what had happened internationally and listened to the players here, that for commercial reasons—the aviation industry seeking to meet the needs of its customers—people would not use another airport for a very long time into the future. The airline companies would adopt what are euphemistically known in the industry as coping strategies, which is to say that they would rearrange their schedules so that some flights overflew Sydney, in other cases there would be a rationalisation of the number of small planes, running effectively shuttle services between Sydney and other capitals—all sorts of measures would be used to avoid having to use other airports for as long as possible into the future, at least for the next decade. There is little point engaging in spending a whole lot of money somewhere else on what would be a white elephant, and we will review the matter in 2005.

I make this commitment to the people of Sydney who are affected by noise—and I understand that it is a real issue. The member for Lowe raised this matter; I understand that he is perfectly sincere in that regard. The curfew will remain, the cap on movements per hour will remain, the regionals will remain—which, of course, is important for the residents. You understand that if many of the regionals pulled out, they would immediately be replaced by a noisy jet. That is not lacking in substance in terms of the issues that the member's constituents face, and I appreciate his concerns for them.

talk.start.para: —I've got no problems with the regionals.
—It is just that it has a spin-off benefit, as you would know.
—And that keeps 747s out of the area.

—Yes. The other point that I wanted to make, apart from the fact that the curfew will remain and the cap will remain—80 movements an hour—is that we will continue to strive to make LTOP work. We believe that we are effectively sharing the noise in a fairer way than in the past and that people are getting substantial periods of respite. I know full well that people will always have concerns about aircraft noise. I get complaints about aircraft noise from the most extraordinary airports in the country. Some of them only have a very limited number of planes flying in and out of them. But if it happens at the wrong time, people become concerned about it. And we try to strike a reasonable balance; we really sincerely do.

speech.para: The member for Prospect covered a number of other issues. The Roads to Recovery program has been mentioned by many members. It is a $1.2 billion program, and there was an additional $400 million for expansion of RONIs—although not exclusively RONIs—in the outer metropolitan areas. This recognised the built-up need for some extra funding for infrastructure on such projects as the F3, a project that the member for Robertson raised. There is $80 million for that and there is a contribution to the Scoresby Freeway coming out of that money, which will make a real difference. The Roads to Recovery program has been very widely welcomed. Most of our local roads were put down during the fifties and the sixties. They have now reached the end of their design lives—and are well past them in many cases. There are horror stories told by councils all around the country about how far behind the roads are. Of course, the distribution was based on the state's grants commission. (Extension of time granted) We actually did that quite deliberately, because we knew that there would be those who would say that we did not seek to be fair and reasonable. So we thought that we would find a formula that is pretty closely tied to one that has been used not only by us but also by previous governments. I just have to record my contempt, quite frankly, for the language used by the member for Northern Territory in this chamber.

talk.start.para: —Go to Robertson River and look them in the eye. Explain that to them.

—This is $1.2 billion, plus some extra money brought in for the unincorporated areas—which are the responsibility of the states and the territories anyway—to help them. That was never committed to by the ALP.
—That is not right.
—It was never committed to by the ALP.
—You cancelled a $15 million road project as soon as you got into office. Tell the truth.
(Mrs Gash)—Order! Member for the Northern Territory!
—I ask that that be withdrawn. I have not told an untruth.
—You have.
—Member for the Northern Territory, withdraw that remark.
—He accused me of speaking an untruth. I have not spoken an untruth.

—On a point of order, Madam Deputy Speaker, there is absolutely no precedent for requiring that a statement that somebody has told an untruth be withdrawn. It is both parliamentary and regular, and it is often used by government ministers at question time. If that precedent is to be established then we will enjoy it at question time and we will use it at question time. I think that skin is thinner than is warranted by proper parliamentary process. We ought to get on with the debate.
—The statement was not made through the chair. The statement was made directly to the minister. I ask that it be withdrawn.
—Hang on—
—Order! I have asked you to withdraw that statement.
—We'll have to close the committee down if you go on like this—
—Don't threaten me in the chair.
—I am just telling you the facts of the standing orders.
—Order! You will sit down whilst I get some advice.

—On a point of order, Madam Deputy Speaker, I think that the comment made was, `That's an untruth.' It was not an accusation; it was just, `That's an untruth.' To assist this chamber, I say to the minister: let us just continue the debate.

—I repeat that I made the point that Roads to Recovery was not a Labor program. It was a program that we instituted and put in place. The member for Northern Territory, in his own extraordinary style—in which there is room for no grace, no understanding, no legitimate debate, no legitimate exchange of views—accuses me of an untruth in relation to a matter that I have not covered. That is the point.
—Yes you did. Check the Hansard.

—I will not waste any more time on it except to say that one of the things that I suspect the community regards as unacceptable behaviour on the part of politicians is when they will never extend a willingness to acknowledge a valuable program and when one is twisted into something that it is not or into something that is distorted and corrupt, which is effectively what the member opposite accuses me of. It is really quite obvious that the formula is very closely related to that of the states grants commissions and it takes into account, across the nation, a combination of road distance and population. It is a valuable program and there have been many members of the Labor Party who have acknowledged that, including some in this chamber today, and I thank them for it.

speech.para: In relation to the Great Western Highway, which the member for Calare raised, I make the general comment that we have, as you know, made a contribution to the Great Western Highway of $100 million. It is a state road, it is not part of the national highway. We have expanded funding well beyond the Great Western Highway. (Extension of time granted) We have expanded road funding into a number of categories that were not previously funded—that is one—but the RONIs program, the resurrection of a Black Spots program and Roads to Recovery are all road programs that were, if you like, specifically excluded after the early 1990s agreement, under the previous government, whereby the funding of the national highway grid only would be undertaken by the Commonwealth government.

As funds have become available we have sought to work cooperatively with other levels of government on roads of strategic and other importance—that being one of them. I am aware of the calls to look at a second major highway over the mountains. I would have to say that there are very mixed views on whether it is wise to proceed with that but I acknowledge that you raise quite a concern. Traffic jams and the congestion on that transport link are very substantial.

Let me come to the member for Port Adelaide and to the more general issue that the member for Calare raised about transport planning and about rail. Let me return the compliment. I too have a regard for the member for Port Adelaide, a decent and fair parliamentarian who is always prepared to be gracious about people on the other side of the House and not to personalise his views, which makes it much easier to have a constructive and meaningful debate.

I would like to make some general comments. I understand your enthusiasm for rail and I believe too that we ought to be doing more to advance interstate rail competitiveness, if I can put it that way, across this nation. The points that the member for Hinkler was raising were very important and germane to this argument. Now, about 77 per cent of the freight that crosses the Nullarbor goes on rail.

talk.start.para: —It should be 100 per cent.

—That would be a nice target. It might interest members to know that it is actually the highest level of freight support of any similar rail length in the world today. It is actually the highest; it is much higher than it was. The cost has come down and the transport times have come down with a surprisingly modest investment in track. It is a good model and we ought to pursue it.

speech.para: As the member for Hinkler said, the next major step—it is really quite logical if you stop to think about it—is the north-south freight corridor between Melbourne and Brisbane and the points between and beyond. It has about 10 per cent of the freight task at the moment. An audit report by the ARTC was commissioned after the very valuable reports that had come from the private sector and from this place. They were valuable reports and I thank those responsible for them. We commissioned the audit report by the Australian Rail Track Corporation to have a close look at how we ought to rearrange these things. They again identified the need for more money but said that, until you get the management structures right and the management issues sorted out, you are not going to get the traffic volumes that you want. The key issue is unquestionably getting the New South Wales Carr government to get serious about track access, signalling and consistency of arrangements. I do not say that as a partisan remark because there are other governments of both persuasions that have helped us to secure seamless interstate track operations, but we need them on the north-south corridor. I urge those opposite, in the spirit of bipartisanship, to help us do everything we can to get the New South Wales government, which for various reasons is pretty focused on what is happening with its passenger transport network around Sydney, sorted out.

We have had money on the table now for a couple of years, for a dedicated freight line through Sydney, and nothing has happened. In the last budget I pulled that back, and we put it into Australian Rail Track Corporation instead, and said that they are to fund it only on the basis of improvements in management and access arrangements. I think there are all sorts of very sound reasons why we need to be rejuvenating rail. Energy conservation is one and greenhouse is another, but there are all sorts of other efficiencies: congestion in the capital city ports and what have you. All of those are very sound reasons for supporting the redevelopment and expansion of rail in this country.

I think that broadly covers the major issues that were raised. I notice fuel excise mentioned again—I always think that, if you want to enter the debate and make some critical comments, you have a lot more credibility if you acknowledge the good work that was done first, and in relation to fuel excise several things need to be acknowledged. One is that we have dramatically reduced the fuel excise on transport, including rail. It has all gone. We have actually taken the excise off rail, and that is a very worthwhile reform. (Extension of time granted) I think I heard the member for the Northern Territory say that he thought the trucking industry was an efficient and important industry, and he praised them up. They of course very much welcome what we have done in abolishing sales tax and indirect taxation burdens on their industry. It has made a very big difference, particularly in areas like the Northern Territory which are freight export oriented, and in which freight costs can impose real difficulties on local communities. In addition, it needs to be remembered that we have dedicated something like $900 million to rural and remote areas to offset the impact of the GST on petrol prices. All of us regret higher petrol prices—

talk.start.para: —Yes, 5c a litre more, thanks to the GST.

—I notice that extension of great graciousness again from the member for the Northern Territory—and he wonders why he is not given much credibility. We ought to remember that for every four barrels of oil we are using at the moment we are only discovering one new one, and that is something that Australia only has limited control over, but that ought to be of real concern to us all. In addition, I would point out that fuel excise rose by 500 per cent when the Labor Party was in power—I repeat, 500 per cent. By comparison it has slowed to a trickle under us, and we have now scrapped Labor's automatic indexation of fuel excise. So there is another side to the story that ought to be told. In conclusion, can I thank members opposite and members on this side for their contribution to the debate. If there are any further detailed questions that people would like to place on notice, I will happily seek to agree to handle those. I notice the member for Lowe has indicated he has some more detailed questions coming to me on notice. I again thank members.

—When you leave here today, Minister, could you focus on the threshold question I gave you about the 17 per cent air traffic movements to the north, which your long-term operating plan promises, but I remind you that we are getting 60 per cent more movements to the north. I am asking whether you have something in your power to reduce that level of noise.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr ANDERSON
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —I know the member for Lowe's constituents want to hear this. We have not succeeded in getting to the targets as often as I would have liked, and I understand that that is of concern. The only point I want to make, apart from saying, `Yes, I will look at it seriously,' is to say to you that we are sincere in seeking to give people decent respite periods, if I can put it that way—decent breaks from something that we understand does affect their lives.
—I want to make some comment on the gratuitous advice given to this place by the Deputy Prime Minister. I asked a very simple question—
—I allowed the member for Lowe to put his point of view across. The member for the Northern Territory now has the floor.

—The specific question I asked in relation to the GST in case you have forgotten or did not hear it related to the amount of extra tax paid as a result of the GST by fuel consumers of the Northern Territory. Just answer that question: why should the people in Milikapiti pay 397 per cent extra GST as a proportion of—
(Mrs Gash)—I assume the member for Northern Territory is directing that question through the chair?
—I am looking at you, Madam Chair.
—No, you weren't.
—Well, through you, Madam Chair—
—Thank you.

—Through you, Madam Chair, could you ask the Deputy Prime Minister if he would not mind responding to me—if that is the way I am supposed to ask this question—as to why the people in the Northern Territory, the people at Milikapiti, should expect to pay 397 per cent extra GST as a proportion of the price paid by the people at North Ryde. Why should the people of the Northern Territory be required—and I ask the Deputy Prime Minister through you, Madam Deputy Speaker, if he would bother responding to the people of the Northern Territory—to pay more GST on their fuel than any other Australians? Perhaps also the minister could explain to the people of the Northern Territory why they should believe anything that he or his party says, because you will recall that I started off my earlier contribution by making the observation that the then Deputy Prime Minister had said the price of fuel need not rise as a result of the GST. What is the answer, Deputy Prime Minister?

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr ANDERSON
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —As is my custom in these things, I will check the figures of the honourable member for the Northern Territory and I will seek to respond to him. I make the point again that his constituents ought to take note of the very real reductions in fuel excise in a number of areas that are of critical importance to people living in far-flung places like the Northern Territory, particularly in relation to transport fuels, and again I emphasise that a constructive debate always requires a degree of goodwill and recognition—by parties on all sides—of gains as well as losses.

—Just to enlighten the Deputy Prime Minister: at Milikapiti, under the old regime, excise was 44.137c a litre, which you will recall. Under the new regime it is 38.14c a litre currently, and extra GST is 10.37c. Whichever way the Deputy Prime Minister tries to portray it—I accept that fuel excise has come down, I accept that you have abolished indexation, I accept all of that; that is not my query—my query is why should people in the Northern Territory and people who live in high cost areas pay more as a result of the GST for goods and services than other Australians? In this case it happens to be fuel. Can you answer that question? Why should people in my electorate, who are, as I repeat, amongst the poorest of Australians with some of the highest costs of living, when they drive to and from work or into town, in a case such as that of Milikapiti be required to pay so much more for their fuel as a result of the GST than other people in Australia? That is a simple question; it should receive a simple answer.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr ANDERSON
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The thing has to be viewed in totality; that is the first point I would make. You mentioned they were paying something like 40c in excise per litre. I think you will find that about 32c of that was imposed by the Labor Party. I will check the figures and I will come back you, but you have to view taxation imposts and the burden in any specific area in the totality of the taxation and other financial frameworks that pertain to that community.

speech.para: Tax reform was very much needed in the interests of rural and regional Australia. I make no apologies for saying that. I believe that rural and regional Australia is better off for it. There is the reality that some types of taxes will accumulate a little more in some areas than in others, but I have noticed, on average, a closing of the country-city price differential in recent times. You can always find examples where it has gone the other way. If they are excessive, we can have them looked at, but I will respond in full when I have checked out the figures in the claims.
Proposed expenditure agreed to.

para.inline: Sitting suspended from 1.30 p.m. to 4.06 p.m.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

quote.para: Proposed expenditure, $2,101,107,000.

talk.start.para: —I want to speak particularly about the arts aspect of this budget allocation and raise a number of issues of concern. Because of the overlap some of my remarks will also deal with issues in the communications sector.

speech.para: This budget is very disappointing for the arts community. There is no new money for the arts in this budget. There are no new ideas in this budget about the arts. That might be disappointing for a lot of individuals who have a passion for and a commitment to the arts, either as participants or as consumers who enjoy the product produced by artists in the various areas of our society. I am in that category—I am not a participant because I do not have the talent, but I am an enthusiastic consumer.

My concern is that the knowledge nation of the 21st century requires not only those aspects that are commonly referred to, such as science, engineering and research and development; in the 21st century content is king. The countries which are producing the content that will drive the information technology and other products of the 21st century will be the countries which succeed. And that requires encouragement of the creative people in our community, protection of their intellectual property, incentive for them to produce, and a climate in which they feel respected, acknowledged, appreciated and encouraged. All of that is lacking in this budget. I have made those comments before but I repeat them because it is a source of great disappointment to me.

I want today to deal with some specific matters. I hope that the Minister for the Arts and the Centenary of Federation, when he arrives, will be able to respond to some of these specific matters. I want first to deal with the issue of contemporary music. I am extremely concerned that there is nothing in this budget for contemporary music except cuts. In 1998, the government was under pressure on the issue of contemporary music in the lead-up to the election because of its disastrous decision about parallel importation of CDs and its consequences for young artists and Australian recording companies. It was under pressure, the arts community was campaigning, and it responded by throwing in $10 million. It is very typical of this government, in the lead-up to an election, under pressure, to decide to provide taxpayers' funds to bail out problems it has created. So it provided a $10 million fund for contemporary music export, to assist business planning and market development, the development of an online strategy, specific programs for particular states, a contemporary music touring program and community broadcasting.

That $10 million program runs out on 30 June this year. To continue, it needed funding in this budget, and there was not one cent. It was an unannounced, unheralded $10 million cut in support for contemporary music, which is the art form of the young generation of creative Australians that young Australians listen to and enjoy. The most important loss to the contemporary music industry will be the touring program that used to be operated through Playing Australia. The disappointment that this program was not continued was best summed up by the Music Managers Forum, which labelled the abandonment of the contemporary music touring program with disappointment and regret and said:

quote.para: The government must acknowledge that despite a huge financial windfall from the music industry, its reciprocal reinvestment in the sector and its commitment to the development of a valid powerful youth culture is minimal.

speech.para: This industry faces the continuing impact of parallel importation, but the compensation package is gone. It is once again typical of this government. It is like the GST. The GST continues forever, but the compensation is only temporary. (Extension of time granted) The contemporary music industry will continue to be hit by this flawed policy with regard to parallel imports, but the compensation package has been eliminated. The cynics amongst us might suggest that the government's plan is to allow this to lapse so that, come the election, they can announce it again and it will be a new policy. It is called filling in the hole you dug for yourself and calling it progress. So they have dug a $10 million hole for the contemporary music industry. I would be pleased if they went to the election offering to fill it in again, but I am very doubtful. What I am really concerned about is the future of the contemporary music touring program. Will the government commit to it again? Am I right in assuming that it has been abolished? If it has been abolished, what assistance is there for the contemporary music industry? I await advice from the minister.

That example is being painfully followed by the book industry now. The book industry knows exactly the two problems the contemporary music industry faces: one, the threat of parallel imports; and, two, the risk that the damage to their industry will continue while the compensation package gets eroded. We are having a debate on a bill in this parliament at the moment about the extension of the parallel importation principles of the book industry. There have been some, not surprisingly, eloquent critiques of that by some of our great Australian writers, such as Frank Moorehouse, who appeared before the Senate committee and in a very devastating manner illustrated the flaws in the government's approach and the threat to young Australian writers and Australian publishers if this flawed policy is continued.

The book industry knows the nature of this government's attitude. It already feels threatened because of what it has seen happen to contemporary music. The industry is not being offered any compensation for the impact of parallel importation, but it is aware that it has already been severely hit by the GST. It was offered a compensation package in return for that, but just like the parallel importation effect, the GST is in forever but it is not sure how long the compensation package will last. There is no compensation for the book industry for the threat that it faces from parallel imports. So I am really concerned that this government continues to attack the arts. It attacks the fundamental basis of intellectual property protection and the capacity of creative Australians to earn income from their intellectual property. It does not just affect artists; it is also true in the software industry—but that is not my brief for today; I have spoken about that elsewhere. All of those people feel that their capacity to earn income from their creativity is under threat by this government. What is the 21st century about? It is about countries gaining income from their ideas, from their brainpower. So this government puts in place policies to make it impossible.

The third thing I want to talk about is the cynical exercise by the government with regard to the Young and Emerging Artists Initiative and the Major Festivals Initiative—two proposals introduced by the government in 1998 with great fanfare. In the budget, they announced renewed support for them. But, if you read the fine print for those two programs, this renewed support means they have got 12 months to live: they are on death row. They will be abolished straight after the election. They have not been abolished now because young Australians resent enough the attack on the contemporary music industry. They do not want to see their new and emerging artists program attacked as well. But they are under threat. The only salvation might be that same cynical view that the government are merely withdrawing funding in this budget so that nobody can plan—the major festivals are in crisis—so they can emerge and make an announcement at the election to say, `Aren't we clever? We are proposing to fill in the hole we just dug. We will renew these two programs if we are re-elected.' But major project planning takes longer than that and this is a disastrous approach. (Extension of time granted)

I assure others here that this will be my last extension because I know others wish to have a chance to speak. There are many other matters that I wish to raise but, having spoken about my concern about the general problem in the budget and with this government, of lack of commitment to the arts and creativity and my concern about contemporary music, the book industry, the Young and Emerging Artists Initiative and the Major Festivals Initiative, I want to turn briefly to the ABC.

Like many other Australians, I am extremely concerned about the lack of Australian drama on ABC Television. The amount of BBC reruns such as Yes, Minister, Fawlty Towers, One Foot in the Grave is now beyond a joke. As much as I may have enjoyed some of those programs when they were first run—and I quite enjoyed them the second, and I did not mind them even in the third—I really got a bit disappointed recently to see at the end of a Yes, Minister program, when they have the credits at the end that the copyright was dated 1975. A terrific program it wasvintage you might call itbut, in terms of showing Australians the stories told by their fellow Australians, creating jobs and opportunity for creative Australians to produce programs and participate in programs, write music, act, write scripts, produce, direct and provide their technical expertise, it produces nothing. Australians should be able to turn on the ABC and hear their own stories.

Of course, there are alarming allegations—and I would like the minister to assure the Main Committee that this is not true—that the ABC was bidding for the rights for The Weakest Link and that one of the reasons why Gail Jarvis was dismissed was that she was unsuccessful in winning the rights to The weakest link. We want to know if that is true. But I am more concerned about the decline in drama production on ABC television and, what is less noticed, the impact on ABC radio. The ABC radio drama on ABC-FM, Soundstage, which went for years and which was very successful, has now been undermined. Soundstage was on ABC-FM for 25 years and has now gone.

We have had cuts to artists' fees on ABC radio. I want to know where are the resources for drama production on TV and radio? In drama production I include documentary production—Australian new material with Australian stories told by Australians to Australians. That is why we provide money to the ABC. It is why it is such a great icon in this country, because it is how we see and hear our own stories, things that do not appear anywhere else. It is being cut, hacked and pulled back.

Since 1996 we have had substantial cuts to ABC funding, and this is a hole the government has not even filled in. The government is claiming great virtue in providing $17 million, which goes a very small part of the way to filling in the hole—and as best as we can tell none of that money is available for ABC drama production on TV and radio. Ostensibly it is available for any purpose but it appears that there are agreements between the government and the ABC that this money will be supplied for what seem to me to be very worthwhile purposes, of which I am not critical, but there seems to be nothing for drama production for TV and radio.

The last point I have time to make is that the minister has claimed in his media release that the ABC in Perth has been financed to purchase and construct a new office. That is quite a good thing, but what he neglects to mention is that, in the move, the ABC has sold the purpose-built home for the West Australian Symphony Orchestra and provided no new home. So we have the West Australian Symphony Orchestra—one of the great orchestras of this country and very important for the most isolated capital city in the world—with the threat of no home, a state government trying to come up with ways to rescue that terrible situation, and silence from the federal government. We have a budget that is disastrous for the arts and artists and for Australians who love the arts, and that flies in the face of what a knowledge nation in the 21st century should require.

talk.start.para: —I would like to begin by supporting the comments by the member for Fraser in his invaluable contribution to this debate, particularly regarding parallel imports in relation to the book industry, and his support for the ABC. The ABC is an important national institution and I am here this afternoon once again to support the ABC. Anyone who has any doubts about my credentials on this topic need look no further than the Hansard records of 21 June 1999, 9 August 1999, 22 November 1999, 31 October 2000 and 6 December 2000, when I participated in the MPI debate in respect of the funding cuts to the ABC and also questions on notice. I will get to that in a minute.

speech.para: My concern is that under this government over the last six years we have seen $66 million of cuts to the ABC budget. In some piecemeal approach the government has restored $17.78 million per year. If you want any indication of the significance of that against the background of the significant funding cuts over the life of the last two parliaments under the Howard government, you have only to refer to this question which we all heard the Leader of the Opposition ask the Prime Minister today:

quote.para: Prime Minister, how can you justify spending $20 million a month on government advertising when you were only prepared to give the ABC an extra $17 million a year? Why is spending $20 million a month to save your political skin a higher priority than adequately funding the national broadcaster?

speech.para: This is further evidence of the dishonesty of the Howard government in terms of its attack on the ABC, that the best that it can offer is a restoration of $17 million a year when it is quite happy to spend $20 million of your money, Australian taxpayers' money, to be re-elected. It is a very cynical exercise. What could be more important than maintenance of the national public broadcaster? Unfortunately, in Australia most of the public opinion is manipulated by the Murdoch group or the Packer group.

I have expressed concern on many occasions about our media laws. If we continue to erode the funding to the ABC, as has occurred under this government, we are going to be left, particularly in this digital age, with more of Mr Packer and more of Mr Murdoch. Clearly, that is not in the public interest. The greatest threat to our democracy is concentration of the media. If we do not get a further opinion—that is, an opinion from the public broadcaster—God help this country.

The criticism which is being levelled at the ABC at the moment—that it is biased and is presenting the views of, or running an agenda to support, the opposition—is not a fair criticism. You only have to look at the history of the ABC: the criticism was levelled at the ABC when we were in government, both in New South Wales under Premier Wran and more recently in federal government under Prime Minister Hawke and Prime Minister Keating. There was considerable criticism of the ABC from our side of politics. As I have said before in this chamber, if the ABC runs an editorial of the day which is against the interests of government, state or federal, people are going to cry that there is bias. We have to truly make the ABC independent and properly resourced. We have to fund the ABC.

I have a clear recollection of Minister Alston prior to the last federal election promising that he would preserve the funding and independence of the ABC. What have we seen of the behaviour of Minister Alston? More recently we had that fiasco in the Senate estimates hearing where he did not like the very rigorous scrutiny that was being visited by the committee on Managing Director Shier in terms of his accountability to the taxpayers of Australia for his management of the ABC. He attempted to shut down that committee. Senator Alston could not cop the heat and attempted to hijack that committee or even usurp the role of the chairman of that committee. That clearly shows the duplicity of Senator Alston because he promised to maintain funding and independence, and he attempted to shut down the committee. (Extension of time granted)
