In addition to the grave concerns that we all have with the management of the ABC at the moment, we also have concerns with the board of the ABC, as I have said on a number of occasions in this House. The board, for a very long period of time, has been stacked by supporters on both sides of the parliament, and clearly that affects the independence of the ABC. The time has definitely arrived to get a truly independent ABC. What could be a better time than the Prime Minister taking the bit—

talk.start.para: —It's time.

—Yes, it is time, as the member for Lilley has just chimed in, to give very serious consideration to not renewing the appointment of Donald McDonald. Donald McDonald, Chairman of the ABC, was present, as we all know, at a very prominent Liberal Party fundraiser and he cannot be seen or perceived as someone who is truly independent and who could truly have the interests of the independence and the future of the ABC at heart. Obviously, the chairman of the ABC is doing the work of the Prime Minister in trying to sabotage the ABC. The government should find another job for Mr McDonald or put him out to pasture—have him rusticate—because he is obviously only going to do irreparable damage if he stays in this job. He has a managing director who appears to be out of control, given all the dissatisfaction of the staff of the ABC and the low morale. I had just been reading Mr Shier's address to the Sydney Institute yesterday. This is a good read and, if one could live up to it, one would have some hope that the ABC would have a future. But, unfortunately, Mr Shier's track record is not terribly good. He is pretty good at mouthing the rhetoric but not at delivering. Hence, the mass resignations and the unrest in the ABC.

speech.para: One thing I have a real concern about in terms of the funding relates to a question that I put on notice to the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts on 2 November 2000. I asked the minister:

quote.para: Will the Minister allow the Australian Broadcasting Corporation to become a fully-fledged business in e-commerce, deriving advertising revenue from its web sites or associated web sites?

speech.para: What do you think his response was? He said:

quote.para: The ABC is an independent statutory corporation established under the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Act 1983. The Government has no role in programming or operational matters. Section 25 of the Act empowers the ABC to enter into contracts, acquire and dispose of property and do other things incidental to its powers. It is the responsibility of the ABC Board to ensure that any activities undertaken by the ABC, including any online activities, are consistent with the Act and do not in any way affect the ABC's editorial independence.

speech.para: What we have here in writing, enshrined in Hansard on 28 November 2000, is the minister's acquiescence with regard to the ABC being able to raise revenue to obviously plug the hole from the very savage budget cuts that the Howard government has visited on the ABC.

This is a very serious issue because I believe that the ABC should have a finite budget which is given to them at the start of the financial year so they know exactly what money they have to manage their full operations. They should not be reliant on raising revenue. The other thing that Mr Shier seems to be keen on is to raise the ratings of the ABC and to popularise the ABC. The member for Fraser mentioned here a moment ago that Gail Jarvis resigned because of Mr Shier's desire to put The Weakest Link on the ABC. It is outrageous that you would put such a program on the ABC. Do we ever want to see an ABC where there are programs such as The Weakest Link or The Footy Show? The ABC was never meant to have those sorts of programs. The ABC is supposed to provide news and information, education and science programs, entertainment and the arts. (Extension of time granted) I promise to wind up and give others a go because I am sure I am preaching to the converted.

talk.start.para: —On this side, John.

—I think even the member for Fairfax would agree with me. There should be a bipartisan approach to this. We have to stop politicising the ABC. We have to allow the ABC to be truly independent. We have to fully fund the ABC. We have to stop stacking the board of the ABC. For too long this has gone on under Labor governments and under coalition governments. I can see the member for Fairfax is in agreement with what I am saying. The time has arrived where we have to put all that behind us because of our concern for the public interest of Australia. As I alluded to earlier in this debate, if the ABC is allowed to wither on the vine we are going to get more of Mr Packer and more of Mr Murdoch, and that is clearly not in the public interest. If our media laws are such that there is further concentration and less opinion given by fewer masters, then that is going to be the greatest threat to democracy, the greatest threat to the future of Australia.

speech.para: On the subject of media laws, I am all for opening the media laws to allow other players in and for Mr Packer and Mr Murdoch to go and find interests in industries other than communications. They truly have an enormous amount of power and influence in Australia. I have no problem with media proprietors from Europe or from North America controlling parts of our media. We have seen in the history of the Fairfax group of papers that the Herald flourished under Brierley and under Conrad Black, and can be properly managed. We do not need Mr Packer sticking his nose in and buying the Fairfax group of papers, nor do we need Mr Murdoch buying Channel 7. We must all support the ABC. I will stand here in this parliament—until I am voted out—defending the ABC and imploring both sides of the House to get together and ensure that we truly support an independent and properly funded ABC. Thank you.

talk.start.para: —While I sympathise with many of the comments from the member for Lowe, I certainly do not see the answer to our localism and media diversity in the hands of the offshore operators of our media, given the sorts of things that are happening in regional radio at the moment, which I will mention in a moment. Talking of the budget allocation to the ABC, from a regional perspective one can only welcome the commitment of $17½ million per annum to regional ABC, but I suspect it has been targeted for political rather than cultural reasons. I hope it enables the local ABC to generate truly local programming and inject local regional items into national radio and television on a more regular basis.

speech.para: I remember the enthusiasm of the launch of ABC Online here at Parliament House several years ago when Brian Johns, the then chairman, unveiled the sorts of things that he hoped the ABC would be able to do on a regional basis, with local video inserts into web sites showing not only the local headlines but in vision the sorts of events that had been happening around there. This was far removed from the reality of the situation, where there have been cameras sitting in regional ABC offices for some time with no expertise there to operate them. I hope that, finally, we might see a move towards the ABC generating some video as well as more broadcast material from the regions.

I endorse the comments of the member for Fraser about the demise of new Australian material on the ABC and his allusion to repeats of repeats of repeats of Fawlty Towers,et cetera. I must admit I cannot get much of a laugh from Fawlty Towers these days.With a 2,500-strong local petition delivered to my office calling for, among other things, funding to be restored to 1995 levels, I do not think that is an unreasonable request, given the demand for new technologies—the online, the digital and so on—that have developed since those quite savage budget cuts of the mid-1990s.

The need for a strong, independent ABC is quite obvious now in a regional sense. In recent times, we have seen a serious decline in localism in both commercial radio and commercial television in regional areas. As one with a long background in regional radio and television, I feel more than competent to speak on it. An inquiry has almost been completed into the decline of localism in regional radio, where long-standing AM licences have been turned into slave stations of a city-based network. FM licences—too many of them—were introduced into most regional centres under the name of competition. What we have in many cases is a monopolisation of the market by similar interests—and I refer here particularly to the Daily Mail group—and a reduction of local content to bare, minimal proportions.

In television, the demise of Prime Television news services in three major centres after years of cutbacks and the forcing of generic material onto others has so diluted localism in all markets as to make an absolute joke of the reasons for the Labor government's aggregation policies of the late 1980s. Aggregation was never going to work other than to deliver an advertising market to absentee owners and to sacrifice local employment and content for half-hour strip network programming. Might I say, along with this, we see the demise of quality training of young journalists, broadcasters and announcers who once were the source of talent for the city stations. They are not taking on their responsibilities for training people. They are relying on the Charles Sturts of this world to train their young journalists, who in turn have fewer and fewer opportunities to do their work experience at the regional stations where their training was honed, if you like. WIN Television and the other Nine Network affiliates are the only operators consistently providing local news services to all their markets. However, even that is a long way short of the varied news, sport and entertainment that localism once provided under the licence requirements in the former incumbent regional station markets. (Extension of time granted)

I remember preparing details for licence renewal hearings that would require a listing of towns and shires, and the number of stories, the number of information programs and so on that you had provided for all of those. It was a very worthwhile exercise—time consuming, but one that constantly reminded the licensee of his or her responsibility to that market. That sort of thing does not occur any more, and I ask: why?

Members of the former government may want to promote the virtues of aggregation and say that this government is now standing mutely by while TV and radio services are delocalised, but there was never any intention to do other than maximise returns from licence sales and let the media operators do as they wish. The Ten Network affiliates were at least quite honest about what they regarded aggregation as—simply a licence to print money, with nothing by way of localism returned. They have never provided a news service in anything other than their incumbent market.

The taxpayer should be informed that the Prime Network alone received $32 million of public funds to help it gear up for aggregation and will receive a $56 million subsidy, as far as I can ascertain, to ease it into the digital world. Also, it can ride on the back of the Seven Network's signal in those markets where it was not the incumbent. The Ten Network affiliates in similar circumstances have taken similar public funding and run, with no regulatory framework to insist on localism.

What we need, but no government is inclined to take on the media owners, are regulations requiring adequate and comprehensive localism from each licensee in each market; not contributing to but providing localism—and that is the key point. Anything else, any other inquiry recommendation from the radio inquiry now under way, would be, to use the Prime Minister's current favourite term, pure humbug.

I want to move quickly on to Telstra and rural communications. I opened the Telstra Countrywide office last week in Orange. While it is good to have people on the ground who can listen to the problems and see the frustration and delays in connections and repairs, it is but a reincarnation of Telecom local offices, minus the corporate knowledge of that network. That is what they are lacking, Minister: the corporate knowledge. If you pick up the phone and ring Gavin Priestley, the manager in Orange, and have a chat to him, I think he would quite frankly admit that they came in there not knowing the extent of the network or how many repairs they had. They had contractors coming in to dig the trench and they found that they did not have enough capacity on the line. That is in suburbs of Bathurst; it is not at Tibooburra. Gavin Priestley knows the extent of the problem now but he does not have the resources to do the job. Local subcontractors are being kept on a drip, fed by major contractors such as Lucas and Thiess, who are giving them unsustainable rates. Telstra continues to be top heavy and is only just beginning to come to grips with the work needed to bring rural telecommunications up to speed. That includes areas within 25 kilometres of the Bathurst Post Office.

talk.start.para: —In the short time available to me to address the issues within this portfolio, I would like to talk about Telstra, and emphasise the fact that the budget still includes the proceeds from the sale of Telstra in aggregate form in the headline cash balance from 2002-03. Previously the proceeds were included from 2000-01. Estimated proceeds from the sale have never been disclosed in any detail. Although still unsatisfactory, Budget Paper No. 1 does provide some information about the estimated net impact of revisions since the mid-year economic forecasts on the fiscal and underlying cash balances. The bottom line is that the government is trying to have its cake and eat it too. On the one hand it says that Telstra will only be sold after satisfactory implementation of the Besley measures, but on the other hand it is keen to keep it in the budget, potentially to use the estimated proceeds in the election campaign.

speech.para: Back in July 1999 Brian Toohey writing in the Sydney Morning Herald forecast this when he said:

quote.para: With the telecommunications giant valued on the sharemarket at more than $110 billion, Telstra could easily be capitalised at well over $120 billion by the time the next election is due in 2001.

speech.para: Brian Toohey on that occasion had it right. Two years down the track, that is exactly what this government is doing. This is a double standard and, should this mean and tricky government be re-elected, it surely will push ahead with the sale of Telstra.

I am sure members will be aware that in recent days Telstra announced planned changes to its local call zones. It is astonishing that the minister, Senator Alston, has claimed credit on behalf of the government for Telstra's response to Telstra's own call zone review. Surely, any benefit that this government can claim for Telstra's response can only have come about because of the government's majority ownership of Telstra, and remember that, in the unfortunate circumstance that the government is returned at the next federal election and it goes through with the full privatisation of Telstra, this ability to encourage or influence Telstra to improve its services to the people of Australia will be lost.

Senator Alston has also claimed that it would be a recipe for disaster for a majority government owned Telstra to play a nation building role as advocated by the Leader of the Opposition. Again, it is interesting to note that the minister advocated such a role for Telstra recently. He said the government certainly sees telcos as having a crucial role to play in nation building. What extraordinary hypocrisy from the minister.

However, there is another example that I would like to raise of this government's attitude to the government ownership of Telstra. Recently, Cable and Wireless announced the sale of Optus to SingTel, a company with majority ownership by the Singaporean government. It seems that it is all right for a telco to be owned by a government as long as it is not the Australian government. SingTel and Telstra are both excellent examples amongst others around the world of very effective telecommunications carriers partially owned by the public.

In March this year, we saw the dividend that has been paid to the government by Telstra. When Telstra cemented its position as Australia's biggest earning company, reporting a record $2.6 billion after-tax profit for the six months to December 2000, a $500 million dividend cheque went to the government as Telstra's 50.1 per cent majority owner. But at that stage, the Prime Minister backed away from full privatisation saying that the government would not sell its stake until services in the bush were fixed, and in March he said, `I am not satisfied at present.' However, in May it is there in the budget papers. The Prime Minister, if he is re-elected, will sell Telstra at any cost.

Despite this government's blatant and shameless hypocrisy, the full privatisation of Telstra will be a reality in the final year of the next parliament, should the Howard government be re-elected. The government had decided to put the sensitive issue of privatisation on the backburner, but the public remains committed and the Labor Party remains committed to the preservation of the remainder of Telstra under public control as the only guarantee of quality service.

talk.start.para: —In rising to make my very brief comments, I am sure that the minister will be enthralled with my contribution and will give me the assurances that I need.
—Keep it simple for him.

—I will keep it simple, yes. I very briefly want to say that I was extremely disappointed with the treatment that the ABC received in the budget. I feel that it behoves the government to properly fund the ABC and to ensure its independence. Since it was elected, it has continually attacked the ABC and eroded its funding base.

speech.para: The other aspect of the ABC that I really want to raise—and I am very pleased that the minister is here—is the attack on the independence of the ABC. I think that there is nothing more important than that we have an independent public broadcaster, a broadcaster that is equally critical of the government and the opposition, a broadcaster that says things that upset both sides of politics. My argument is that you do not censor those sort of comments, because I really believe that they are very important in a democratic society. The government's action in stacking the board and giving jobs to its mates, who in turn give jobs to their mates, has really attacked the independence of the ABC. I ask the minister and the government to look at that and return the ABC to its independence and the status that we should have in a national broadcaster.

I would quickly like to touch on the subject of commercial television. This has been brought to my attention over the last week or so particularly, with Prime removing its local news services from Newcastle, Canberra and Illawarra. This is a real blow for our community, because this was the one source of competition between news services within our areas. We have NBN, which provides an excellent service, but to get a truly local service you need some sort of competition and you need to have different views being put to the public.

I have written to the minister, Senator Alston, asking him to launch an urgent public inquiry into the cessation of Prime's local news service and the effect that this will have on their licensing. It is my understanding that, when they were granted the licence, there was some obligation that they would provide a local news service. This is very disappointing for the people of the Hunter—and, I know, for those in Canberra and Illawarra as well—so I urge the minister to do what he can to try to ensure that there is competition and that an alternative news is being broadcast by local news services in regional areas. This is a government that pays lip-service, I am sure, to providing services in the regions. If they are really serious about it, they will get in there and ensure that the regional areas of Australia have strong local news services.

Finally, I would like to touch on Telstra. I welcome the changes to the zones but, in doing so—and as somebody who called for the government to look at those zones because the Central Coast area, part of which falls within the electorate of Shortland and has been disadvantaged by those zones, as have people living in the Lake Macquarie and Swansea areas who have not been able to call other areas of Newcastle and the Hunter—I am disappointed because the changes are so selective. The people who are in the Central Coast part of the Shortland electorate will still not be able to enjoy the benefits enjoyed by the people living in Robertson. I question whether that may be because Robertson is held by a member of the government and the government is trying to shore up that seat for itself in the next election. I also quickly add that I am disappointed that the zone changes only apply to Telstra: subscribers who have their services with Optus, AAPT and other providers will miss out.

talk.start.para: —There are a couple of issues which I would like to address this afternoon. Firstly, I would like to make a brief comment on the announcement made at question time by the Prime Minister that the ABC would be given $15 million annually—for a number of years, as I understand it—to re-establish Australian television to Asia.
—No, to take it over: it already exists.
—No, no, understand: it is not operating.
—Yes, sure.

—Yes. Look, mate, I was there when we launched Australian television to Asia from the ABC studios in Darwin. It was terrific. You mugs came into office in 1996, and what did you do? You got rid of it. Not only that: you sold off the Radio Australia antenna at Cox Peninsula. Now, what have we had over the last little while? Renegotiations by the ABC on behalf of Radio Australia to get access to the Cox Peninsula antenna, so that they can broadcast back into Asia. Secondly, we now have an announcement this afternoon—writ large—that the government has made a terrible mistake by not allowing the ABC to continue Australian television when it should have been doing it from 1996 onwards. As a result of the stupidity of this government, there has been huge embarrassment for Australia in terms of our relationship with South-East Asia and in terms of the community's need to know.

speech.para: What have they done? This outfit is very progressive. The only person who supported this position, Shane Stone, who was Chief Minister of the Northern Territory when the ABC was given the responsibility for running Australian television, bagged it. He is the progressive who is now the President of the Liberal Party, which gives you some commentary on where the Liberal Party is coming from—

talk.start.para: —And I was minister for territories.

—And he was the minister for territories—poor thing! It is very clear that we have seen again this afternoon how the government has recycled Labor Party initiatives because it is unable to sustain the initiatives it put in place itself. I have mentioned a number of them this afternoon, but this is very important. At least now we will get a quality service back into Asia.
—Used they to get one?
—They did. They used to get one.
—Did they? It went broke.
—No, it did not go broke. Channel 7 went broke; the ABC did not.
(Mr Mossfield)—Order! I remind both the minister and the member speaking to make your remarks through the chair.

—Through you, Mr Deputy Speaker: he does not know what he is talking about. What I want to pay particular attention to this afternoon is the Remote Air Services Subsidy, RASS, for Australia Post. An issue on which I hope the Minister for the Arts and the Centenary of Federation can respond—and if he cannot respond I would like him to get back to me about it—is the question of remote communities who are currently receiving the RASS and what happens to them when the company providing the air service pulls out.

speech.para: I have in mind a particular circumstance, the community of Kaltukatjarra, in the south-western corner of the Northern Territory. They have been informed recently by Ngaanyatjarra Air, who have been providing them with Australia Post services twice a week, that they will no longer be provided with an air service. As a consequence, at the end of June they will no longer have access to mail. I hope the minister is listening, because potentially we are seeing, at the end of next week, a remote community in the Northern Territory no longer getting access to their mail by air.

The difficulty we have here is that although RASS applies to the region there is no carrier. There is no carrier currently flying into this community. I would ask the minister to ascertain how we can ensure that this community will not, as of the end of June, be denied a mail service, the right of every Australian. We are talking about a community of some 300 or 400 people. In the past—and this goes over into another portfolio area—Ngaanyatjarra Air have supplied the service on the basis that they could carry passengers, and they carried those passengers and delivered mail to remote communities. What has happened subsequently is they have been denied the right to carry passengers on these services unless the planes become regular passenger planes on regular service schedules. They cannot do that because of the state of the airstrips. (Extension of time granted) This issue, which has been raised with the Department of Transport and Regional Services, is significant because not only will it affect Kaltukatjarra but it could affect other communities in the very near future.

The bottom line is that we as a community have a responsibility to ensure that communities, wherever they might be, have access to a mail service. If there is no ability to fly the mail into this community some 900 kilometres south-west of Alice Springs, it seems to me incumbent on the government and Australia Post to ensure that the people there get their regular mail services in some way. I am happy to provide the minister with appropriate information about that if he requires it. In fact, I will write him a note and ensure he gets a copy of it tomorrow. I would like a response as soon as possible because, clearly, this community will be affected as of the end of next week.

The other issue which I want to raise and which I have raised in this place on a number of occasions is in the area of telecommunications. I am a great supporter of Telstra and Telstra Countrywide. But I am not a great supporter of some of the decisions which have been made by the Telstra board, one of those decisions being to sell off its Commander phone system.

You will recall, Mr Deputy Speaker, that I have raised this in the parliament before. What it meant was that, by selling off a portion of its business to a company of which it owned 30 per cent, it effectively privatised the business and started to charge people the full cost of providing a service. I will give you an example. The Ngadunggay Homelands Resource Centre was quoted a purchase price for a new Commander phone system of $2,582 plus an estimated $300 service fee for installation. Then there was to be a discount of $120 for the old equipment, and then travel costs for the installation, of $2,450.

This has arisen because Telstra personnel can no longer put in place these services. This not only affects remote Aboriginal communities but also businesses in remote parts of Australia. PlesTel and PlesTel's agents are only in Darwin and Katherine and Alice Springs in the Northern Territory. For the travel from Darwin or Katherine or Alice Springs to wherever the community might be, they are charging the travel time, the cost of the travel, plus the time on the job. Remember, these people previously had a contract with Telstra. Telstra put in place the systems. Now we are in a situation where these people are being penalised for the fact that Telstra has sold a part of its business.

I am advised, Mr Deputy Speaker, and through you to the minister, that it is possible that the PABX system may go the same way in the future. Of course, because I am talking to a minister who says he knows something about regional Australia, he would understand the import and the impact of selling off these little bits of Telstra bit by bit and then charging full costs to clients when these bits are sold off in such a way, and what it means in terms of the cost structure of small business and of community based organisations such as those that predominate in Aboriginal communities. The answer is pretty simple. Telstra has got to assert its right to ensure that its technicians are compelled to and can fix Commander phone systems, whether by licence or by agreement with PlesTel. They ought to do it as soon as possible. This is one of the very reasons why people in remote Australia will not tolerate the further sale of any bit of Telstra.

What I say to the government and the minister, is that, if they believe that somehow or other the community believes it is advantaged by what they have done with Telstra and the fact that Telstra is now selling off little bits of itself to companies of which it is a part owner, I think they are sadly mistaken. The community is not being advantaged by it; it is being handicapped by it.

To my way of thinking we ought to be contemplating what `universal service obligation' properly means. I do not believe it means the right for Telstra to withdraw services and then compel people in these remote communities to pay full costs. Something must be done about it immediately. (Time expired)

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
Mr McGAURAN
talker.role: Minister for the Arts and the Centenary of Federation

talk.start.para: —I was unable to be here for the entire debate as I was detained in the House on a totally spurious matter of public importance on the ABC. Some of the themes have been rehashed here again this afternoon during this particular debate. So I was spared the ill-informed, totally mischievous contributions by Labor Party members. Sadly, I did not miss them entirely, as I had to endure the members for Charlton, Shortland and the Northern Territory. I will work backwards as best I can and look at each of those members' contributions.

speech.para: The problem with dealing with the member for the Northern Territory is that he believes his own misrepresentations. He is one of those people who rewrite history to suit their own political point of view. ATV, Australia Television in Asia, was Michael Lee's and David Hill's biggest folly. I have not looked at the files—even if they were available to me—but Michael Lee, as communications minister, must have signed off on the contractual aspects of that. That was in deep financial trouble long before we came into government, and it was the ABC that unloaded it onto Channel 7. You make the accusation that as soon as the coalition government came to power, we disbanded or transferred—or some generalised accusation like that—ATV broadcasting into Asia. So there you go. It is a very good thing that the government believe that there should be a presence now.

I am not going to get sidetracked. I want to deal with the one serious matter that the member for the Northern Territory raised, and that was on behalf of a constituent body, a remote community, that is at risk of losing their postal services. Isn't it interesting that he raises this a week before it happens? The member for the Northern Territory comes into the Main Committee and says the government have a deadline of one week to save the postal services of this remote community, which I want to do. What has he been doing on this issue? He has been asleep at the wheel—one week! What sort of local member are you to just unload it? Where are the papers? Has the member done anything with Senator Alston, the relevant minister? Of course not; so much grandstanding. How unlucky are they to have you representing them? That is total negligence on your part. We will do what we can as speedily as we can, but, at the moment, apart from the brief notification you have given, we know nothing about the issue.

The Labor Party gave the usual generalised criticism of Telstra. The interesting thing about Telstra is that the Labor Party will not come clean on this. Just what is it that you plan for Telstra? Will it be by way of direction? Will the Labor Party do something that they never did in 13 years in office and direct Telstra under legislative powers to allocate resources in certain areas or for certain purposes? Of course not, they are bluffing. It was the Labor Party in 1990 that required Telstra to act as a commercial entity, as a business in competition with competitors. The Labor Party are just grandstanding.

Let us move on to the member for Shortland, who started by saying that she is disappointed by the budget's treatment of the ABC. It seems that $17.5 million new, extra funding for the ABC is not enough. How much is the Labor Party going to give the ABC?

talk.start.para: —You will not say because you are not going to give the ABC anything. I asked the member for Perth the same question in the House this afternoon and he would not say. What we do know is that the Friends of the ABC—or the friends of the ALP, ACT chapter—have published a newsletter in which they paraphrased Bob McMullan. He tried to distance himself from their representation of this comments after question time by way of personal explanation. That was not very convincing at all—a very gobbledegook explanation. What they said is that he opened a meeting by telling them not to expect `too much too soon'. That is typical Labor Party strategy—giving the impression of promising the world to one and all but not committing to any specifics.

speech.para: With regard to the comments from the member for Shortland about the ABC, all who cherish the ABC know that the $17.5 million extra per year is a good thing. It is in addition to the $15 million extra announced today for each of five years with regard to television broadcasting into Asia. The bottom line on this—and just one phrase says it all—is that the coalition's funding for the ABC is $96.5 million more than Labor's last budget for the ABC. (Extension of time granted) Is there anybody on the opposition side who would like to contest that figure, that the coalition's funding for the ABC is $96.5 million more than their last budget?

The member for Shortland pleaded with the government not to interfere with the independence of the ABC. She believes the ABC should be equally critical of the government and the opposition. In fact, the ABC is more critical on this issue of independence of the Labor Party than it is of the coalition. I presented a statement by Brian Johns, the then chief executive officer, to the House in February of last year. The headline read `ALP attacks independence of the ABC'. He went on in the statement to criticise severely, in unambiguous terms, the member for Perth for threatening the independence of the ABC. The problem is that the ALP has form on this issue. Whether it is Greg Turnbull, press secretary to Kim Beazley, personally intimidating Mark Willesee of A Current Affair and warning him that the ALP will remember this in government or whether it is the ALP's policy of tied grants to the ABC, it is the ALP threatening the national broadcaster's independence.

The problem with this whole ABC debate that has been generated by members of the ALP and the Friends of the ABC is that it is so much hype. It is exaggeration built upon generalisation. Tell us, member for Shortland, where there are examples of a coalition threat to the independence of the ABC. Give us some examples. At least do us the honour of telling us what actions of the government threaten the ABC's independence.

talk.start.para: —Take a look at the board for a start, and its appointments.

—In regard to the board, Rod Cameron, David Hill, John Bannon and Brian Johns are all paid-up Labor Party strategists. The member for Lilley must be smiling because he would have had a lot of experience with Rod Cameron, who was the party's pollster for many years and who profited very nicely from government contracts. He knows very well that the ALP interfered at board level with the ABC.

speech.para: On the departure of the last remaining ALP appointee to the ABC board, a Mr Bates, he said on 6 February this year in the Sydney Morning Herald that he did not believe that the coalition appointments to the ABC board meant that political considerations were placed ahead of the interests of the ABC. So you might like to find some examples of how we have acted politically in terms of our appointments to the ABC, which were necessary because we have been in government for five years and some of the board members' terms had expired. I am afraid the member for Shortland is like everyone else on the other side; she just makes generalised accusations and thinks and hopes they will stick. With the help of the CPSU and the Friends of the ABC, you believe that they will.

The member for Charlton—this was a great classic—said that, because the possibility of the full privatisation of Telstra is included in the budget papers, that means the government must be committed to it. Does she realise that all privatisations by this government have gone to reducing Labor's $96 billion debt, which has now been reduced by $60 billion, and that we do not take it off the recurrent funding? In other words, no privatisation affects the funding of the budget. Do you understand that? Every time the Labor Party privatised a government business or entity, they would use it for recurrent funding.

talk.start.para: (Mr Quick)—I would remind honourable members that the Speaker has issued a general warning in the other place, and that is transferable to this place. Standing order 55 says that members are able to stand and speak without interruption.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I have just remembered one other phoney piece of grandstanding by the member for the Northern Territory in regard to Telstra. He said that the universal service obligation should be employed to greater effect. Upon coming to government, we strengthened the universal service obligation very considerably, and we have instituted the customer service guarantee—both things that Labor did not do in their 13 years in government. No doubt it was another 14th-year-in-government initiative which was on the member's and the former government's agenda.

speech.para: I think the Minister for Community Services is getting impatient. I am just beginning to warm up. I have got a lot more to say about a lot of other things. (Extension of time granted) I undertake to my colleague and friend that this will be my last five-minute session. Let me keep dealing with the member for Charlton. So with respect to the debt of $96 billion left to us by the Labor Party, we have reduced it by two-thirds, using privatisation as the major mechanism to achieve that necessary outcome.

With respect to Telstra, I notice every now and then we read in newspapers that Labor Party strategists are predicting that Telstra is a winner; that Telstra is red hot out there and they can use Telstra as an issue to attack the government. We have seen a lame attempt by the member for the Northern Territory and the member for Charlton to do that here today. Country people are very pragmatic about Telstra. They remember Telecom and the PMG. What they want are legislative and regulated minimum service guarantees and the like. Don't worry; if you think you can whip up a scare campaign simply by employing the rhetoric of fear, you are going to be sadly let down.

The member for Charlton attacked the government for claiming any credit for the call zone benefits that Telstra announced over the weekend. So it is all the government's fault when anything happens in communications, as evidenced by the attack by the member for the Northern Territory today in regard to Telstra. It is all our fault if there is some decrease in service, some failed connection, some delayed repair, but when they announce a major initiative that will benefit hundreds of thousands of country people, it has nothing to do with the government. You can't have it both ways.

Let me deal quickly with the comments by the member for Calare. He spoke at great length about aggregation. This was entirely predictable. I was part of those debates in the late 1980s. We pleaded with and begged the government of the day, `Don't aggregate.' They gave in to their big network mates. Make no mistake about this: anyone who was around at that time will tell you what was driving this policy, and I do not think it is talking out of school to say that the minister for communications at the time, Michael Duffy, was never very comfortable with the special deals that Hawke and Keating struck with the broadcasters at that time. We knew what aggregation would do to regional broadcasters, and it all happened within a matter of years. I do not know why the member for Calare, in the year 2001, 10 or 12 years after the event, expresses concern. We predicted this at the time; it happened very quickly. What is happening to Prime's local TV service at the moment is very regrettable.

He had a go at Countrywide. He is wrong on Countrywide, and I am happy to work to convince him otherwise. I have had Countrywide in my electorate for about six to eight months. It is the best thing that could have happened. Peter Ward heads the most dedicated people. They criss-cross the electorate; they visit people in their homes. It does not matter how remote you are, they will go to your doorstep and help you with connections or with mobile phone coverage. They are a great organisation. We have just announced the upgrade of 53 exchanges throughout Gippsland. I do not get many chances to speak about Golden Beach, which is a small community of about 300 people, but we launched the first upgrade of those 53 Gippsland exchanges there only last week. I implore the member for Calare to give Countrywide a chance. It is the real McCoy.

With respect to the comments by the member for Lowe, we have heard all of this before—the ABC's independence, concentration of media by Packer and Murdoch. Well, fine, but the trouble is there is only so much breast beating allowable before it gets very repetitious and you devalue the currency.

I should really have dealt longer with the remarks by the member for Fraser, because he is the shadow minister for the arts. But the problem is that I have heard it all before. It was a very unoriginal contribution. Of course, money was not mentioned; he just listed the problem areas while providing no solutions in policy terms, let alone in funding terms. You are not going to get away with this. You try to be all things to all people; you promise the world and there is never a dollar figure attached to it. As the Treasurer said not long ago, he is going to remind opposition members of this day in and day out. In that he will be aided by each and every one of his colleagues.

The member for Fraser spent some time on the book industry and parallel imports. He has once again allied himself to special interests, against the interests of consumers. Parallel importing of books is in the interest of consumers; parallel importing of CDs was also in the interest of consumers. We were told the world would collapse; it has not. Quite frankly, the member for Fraser is just a mouthpiece for special interests against the interests of the broader community. Apart from that, I thank the member for Calare for his contribution.
Proposed expenditure agreed to.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Family and Community Services

quote.para: Proposed expenditure, $2,833,202,000.

talk.start.para: —The gaping hole in the middle of the government's recent budget was its failure to do anything for struggling Australian families. As we know, families provide the learning and caring environment for children that enhances their chances of success and our economic stability. But our families are under threat.

speech.para: First of all, I think they have been hit for six by the GST. Under the government's GST, families are paying more for the necessities of life—things like children's clothes and electricity. They are also paying more for many other goods. The ABS consumer price index shows electricity is up 12 per cent, gas is up 10.4 per cent, insurance is up 35 per cent, telephone bills are up seven per cent, whitegoods are up 5.8 per cent, medicines are up six per cent, sporting fees are up 12.2 per cent, children's shoes are up 7.3 per cent, kids' glasses are up 6.4 per cent, bread is up four per cent, kids' haircuts are up 11.7 per cent, petrol is up 7.8 per cent, books are up 9.2 per cent and education is up 4.5 per cent. The budget ignores these pressures on families that arise squarely from the imposition of the GST, and the government did not take the opportunity to address the looming family payments crisis that will see debts raised against low income families from July.

This appropriation bill contains no item that will address the very real problems that lie at the heart of the government's family payments system. The government claims that it is family friendly because it will index family payments on 1 July, but in a mean clawback the government is going to recoup much of this amount by hitting struggling families with many family payment debts that will come out of their tax returns. As always, what John Howard gives with one hand he takes away with the other.

Families whose income has changed during this financial year face debts at tax time of up to $1,000 because of the legislation introduced with the GST. There are three family payments that are affected by the government's new system which was supposed to be simple and fair: family tax benefit part A, family tax benefit part B and child-care benefit. The appropriation for these three payments will total approximately $11.5 billion in the coming financial year, so it is important that the money is fairly administered but it is not.

For each of the three family payments, families have been asked to estimate their income a year in advance. These are the only government payments that operate on a yearly estimate made in advance. Because the government's new system is a zero tolerance one, every dollar they underestimate their income by will produce a debt, as compared to the previous system where a 10 per cent tolerance was allowed. The government now has a zero tolerance family policy, which is going to be very tough on many low income Australian families, and if a family contacts Centrelink to revise their estimate of income during the year, this will not necessarily prevent them from incurring a debt after 1 July this year.

To give you the size of the potential problem, you need to look at how many families are getting these payments and how many have changing income over the financial year. There are 1.8 million Australian families getting family tax benefit A, while 1.2 million families get family tax benefit B and 500,000 families receive child-care benefit. Senator Vanstone's department has said that up to May 833,000 families had registered income changes during the present financial year, and so many of these people do not yet know that after July they will face a hefty bill from the government. You can safely assume from the department's advice that some of these 833,000 may have changed their estimates more than once. Families in which there is a shift worker or someone working casually are likely to have a great many fluctuations in their income over the course of a year—something the government's payment rules try to ignore.

The trouble is that the government will not come clean on how big the problem could be. The department has admitted in estimates hearings that around 200,000 of the 500,000 child-care benefit payments may produce debts, but they are unable to tell us how many of the three million FTB A and FTB B payments will produce debts for customers at tax time. They guess it is less than 40 per cent, but they are not sure. So all we know is that they expect less than 1.2 million payments to be affected. If history is any guide, the problem is big.

The minister's own departmental annual report records that there were 51,000 debts raised against families in 1999-2000, an average of $955 per family, and that was before the government's zero tolerance family policy was introduced. The government could have addressed the problems at the core of its zero tolerance approach in the budget, but it did nothing and actively chose to do so. Instead, Centrelink officers, at the direction of the government, are telling families who come in to change their income estimate to falsely overestimate their income to try and make a dent in the debt that they are going to get at tax time. It is just another tricky approach for the government to avoid its responsibilities. (Extension of time granted) In some cases, they are telling them to cancel their payments so they can avoid a debt at the end of the year. Put simply, the government is encouraging families to mislead to save its own political hide, and they have to sign the form to cement the government's deception. It is quite a unique situation. You have Minister Anthony only a few weeks ago crowing about Centrelink fraud detection figures, which include families who innocently incur family payment debts.

It is not just Minister Anthony. The government has been very tricky and sneaky all along when it comes to family payments. Senator Vanstone insinuated in April that only families rorting the system would receive debts because of massively underestimating their income. She falsely claimed that a family would have to underestimate their income by $18,000 to receive a debt of $1,000. However, a yearly income estimate from a family could be out by as little as $1,500 to incur a $1,000 debt for one child. For a family earning $30,000, this amounts to an error of just five per cent. For the government, being 95 per cent just is not good enough. That is a direct result of its zero tolerance family policy. Debts accrue against each payment the family receives, not just the child-care benefit. Either the minister is not across the detail of her portfolio or she was being deliberately misleading when she made those statements. So you have ministers out there trying to paint the families who are innocently caught up in this system as fraudsters to ease the political pressure from the debts that they have created through their new system, and you have Centrelink, on instruction from the government, telling families to falsely estimate their income. The problem is that, for too many families, the government's family payment system is very unfair. It is a dog and it bites.

Olaf Meier, from Crestmead in Brisbane, has had his income increased from $32,700 to $35,950. He is facing a debt of around $700. He and his family are doing it pretty tough. They have just bought their home and they cannot afford not to be receiving family payments through the year. But now they face a debt approaching $1,000, courtesy of the Howard government's zero tolerance family payment rules, and there are tens of thousands of families like the Meier family. These families cannot afford to provide an overestimate of their income, as Centrelink is directing, because they just cannot make ends meet day to day, week to week. These families, the ones who are doing it toughest, are at the top of the list to get $1,000 or more in debts in July or August this year. Many more families do not know about the debt problem, and they are going to find out for the first time what they owe when the tax office comes back to them with a bill instead of a cheque in July and August.

Families receiving family tax benefit B, a payment to help a dependent spouse caring for a child, are also a real problem. It is this payment that produces the debt for families when a spouse moves into the work force during the financial year. Just today, Professor Peter Macdonald has come out in a Monash University journal to explain the consequences of this payment on the lives of Australian families and the implications for Australia's birthrate. Peter Macdonald's work makes very clear why the government should have done something about the family payment system in the budget. He explains how the family tax benefit B payment penalises dual income families, which many young families are these days, forcing one parent to remain at home. Macdonald points to the case of a couple with a young child where the husband is earning $45,000 and the wife wants to return to work for 12 hours a week to help with the extras. From the $204 she would earn each week, the wife would lose $16 in tax, $20 in transport costs, $30 in child-care costs and $50 in family tax benefit B. Put simply, she would be working for $88 a week. If, however, her husband takes on an extra 12 hours a week, the family gains $225 a week in extra income. According to Macdonald, this means the payment rewards families where the husband absents himself more and more from his family. How perverse can you get. Our Prime Minister's world and the world of Minister Anthony and Minister Vanstone is the world of the 1950s, where wives may have stayed at home while fathers worked nine to five and had constant incomes. But the rest of us, Minister, are living in the 21st century, where Australian families are trying to survive with intermittent overtime, casual work and a 10 per cent GST.

So despite all of the admissions by the minister's department in estimates hearings and all of the families coming forward with evidence that they are about to be saddled with debts, the government continues to pretend that anyone getting a debt is some kind of cheat, and that is deeply insulting to these hardworking Australians. Just a week ago, Senator Vanstone claimed the government was very family friendly. She put out this statement saying `Family friendly government'. (Extension of time granted) She claimed that her system of family payments `is a fair and equitable policy that will enable families to receive what is rightly theirs'. She said that it reflects the Howard government's commitment to pay people what they are entitled to—no more, no less. Once again, there is the clear implication that people who receive debts are doing it deliberately. Once again, there is the smear that these people may be defrauding the system and are not victims of this government's system.

The fact is that this minister is determined to prop up an unfair zero tolerance family payments system by blaming the struggling families who fall victim to it. The fact is that Australian families do not have crystal balls to predict their future income and most do not have the accounting software to deal with the government's complicated zero tolerance family payments policy. John Howard is not supporting battling Australian families; he is out there creating more of them. Tens of thousands of families are being put under extreme financial pressure. Only someone as out of touch and cold-hearted as our Prime Minister and his ministers would introduce a family payments system that punishes families who work harder and punishes parents who return to work after taking time out to care for a child. John Howard's zero tolerance family payments system is just another mean GST compensation swindle. John Howard's zero tolerance family payments policy sits proudly alongside his other achievements—the bogus savings bonus and pension clawback—in the coalition's GST compensation hall of shame.

talk.start.para: —This is a high taxing government, a government that has delivered a tax to the Australian people that is really affecting their lives. It is taxing families in a way that they have never been taxed before. I visited one of the schools in my electorate last week. When I arrived at that school the students asked me about the GST. When they asked me about the GST they identified the fact that they had started paying tax. They also identified their feeling that this was not the way it should be; rather, that you should start to pay tax when you started work. They felt it was very unfair that they were being hit in this way.

speech.para: Probably the greatest disappointment to me in this budget was the fact that the government failed to acknowledge that they had dudded people who live in residential parks and caravan parks. They continue to impose this 5½ per cent GST on these very vulnerable people who are generally on fixed incomes. The Minister for Community Services, who is present in the chamber, knows about this, because he, like me, has a lot of residents who live in these parks. These people have made the decision to have this lifestyle. They are people who own their own homes. They are people who have invested significant amounts of money—some nearly as much as $200,000—in buying their homes.

It was really brought home to me last weekend when I was talking to residents who were living in parks how hard it is for them. When the GST was introduced, a number of owners of parks imposed a rental increase; others imposed the GST. Now we are finding an about-face by some of those owners who applied the GST because they can see the writing on the wall. They see that the government may lose the next election, and if they lose the next election they know that the Labor Party has promised that the GST, that unfair GST that has been charged on people who are living in residential parks, will be removed. Because of that, I am finding that within the area that I represent park owners are sending letters to the residents saying, `We've decided the GST's not the way to go, we're going to put in place a rent increase.'

I think that the government should have admitted that it made a mistake. In admitting that it made a mistake, it should then, in this budget, have remedied that situation. (Extension of time granted) It has already rolled back the GST on excise. It has already had to introduce rollback in a number of areas—or, should I say, as I think it is more appropriate when I am referring to the government, rollover, because it is only when they have the pressure put on them through the polls and the ballot box that they actually revisit any of these issues.

The minister should be very aware of this because of the electorate he represents. I would have thought that he would have been leading the fight for the residents of these parks because it will have an impact in his electorate. Even putting that aside, I think that on moral grounds he should be fighting for these people. I honestly do not see how members on that side of the House can live with the fact that the government is spending $20 million a month on advertising whilst, at the same time, it is hitting the most vulnerable people within our community with taxes like the GST on people in parks.

The shadow minister spoke about the debts that are being levied against families. I have already seen some of those families—they are coming into my electorate office. The zero tolerance on debts incurred on the family benefits A and B is hurting families and will continue to hurt families. This matter needs to be revisited, Minister. You need to re-introduce the 10 per cent leeway. Because of the way this government has attacked the job market, more and more people are working in part-time and casual jobs and being forced to work long hours, and that does have an enormous effect on their incomes. It is very difficult to estimate how much you are going to earn when the hours you work vary from week to week.

This is not a family friendly government. It is a government that uses all the rhetoric. It says, `We care about families. We are there for the family. We support family values,' but it is nothing more than rhetoric. What it does support is being re-elected. What it does support is an outmoded picture of what it thinks Australia is and should be, and then goes about trying to achieve it by hitting the people that it is supposed to be supporting. I feel that the government has failed miserably in the area of family and community services. It has not looked after the people. It has not provided the support for the people in our community that are most vulnerable.

The other area I should quickly touch on is the number of breaches that are being imposed by Centrelink. The simple fact that a large percentage of these breaches are administrative has been borne out by some of the answers that the minister has provided me with to questions in relation to the Shortland electorate and the people who have been breached there. Every day we have people coming into our electorate office who have been unfairly breached. It takes time, both within our office and within Centrelink, to actually turn around decisions that have been made by Centrelink. I think that the minister would do well to provide extra staff and extra training to Centrelink. Probably if he could give a little bit more support in that area it would be appreciated, not only by the staff at Centrelink but by the people that rely on Centrelink for their payments.

talk.start.para: —I would like to identify myself with the concerns expressed by some of my colleagues about the very great problems that are being caused to Australian families as a result of overpayments of family payment. I would like to raise a particular area of that collection procedure and that is the interrelationship between it and the Child Support Agency. This is a matter that I have already written about to Senator Vanstone and to the Treasurer and I will briefly outline the problem for the benefit of other members.

speech.para: The person who brought this to my attention had custody of her two children for most of the year. She had been claiming a full family tax benefit. Relatively late in the year, the residential arrangements for one of the children changed, so that that child then resided with his father, giving his father an entitlement to part of the family tax benefit for those two children for the year. That father had a child support debt to the mother of many thousands of dollars. Her concern was that her ex-husband would claim his share of the family tax benefit through Centrelink, and a debt would be raised against her, and Centrelink would not take that money and apply it against his child support debt. She had correctly assessed the situation, as I have subsequently found out from my own inquiries.

talk.start.para: —We have some legislation going through to solve that problem.

—I hope you have got some legislation going through to solve the problem. The thing is that, as the minister has just said, presently there is no legislative arrangement that links the Child Support Agency with Centrelink as far as debt collection goes.

speech.para: I then explored the issue of what would happen if the father claimed the money in his tax return. I thought, `There are links between the ATO and the Child Support Agency in relation to the resolution of child support debts.' However, I found that the administrative arrangements are not as I would have expected. The father could put in his claim but, because the mother had claimed a full family tax benefit, the claim would be rejected. At that point, his income tax assessment would be issued. If, for other reasons, he had a repayment due to him of any tax, that would be applied against the Child Support Agency debt. However, in a lot of these cases fathers are in circumstances where they are not necessarily going to receive a refund and, therefore, the child support debt is not going to be dealt with at all.

The next step is that the father has to apply for a review, so that he can get access to his share of the family tax benefit. When he does that and it is processed, a debt will be raised against the mother and the money will be paid to the father. At that point, there is no link between the tax office and the Child Support Agency for the purposes of clearing child support debts. So, the mother who is owed several thousand dollars by the father continues to be owed several thousand dollars by the father. He receives part of the family tax benefit—that is paid to him in his hand—and she has a debt raised against her. I think that is an extremely inequitable situation, and if the minister, as he has said, has some legislation coming forward that will resolve the problem in relation to overpayments claimed through Centrelink, that is great. Then I would hope that he would also follow up the issue of the payment system with the tax office. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —This is part of a speech I had prepared for the main debate, so it may be a little fragmented. However, I would suggest that the reaction out there after the budget is one of some cynicism even among those who have enjoyed some of the rewards of that budget. I think the general feeling is that, stung by the impact of the goods and services tax on pensioners, the government has moved to placate that sector with a targeted election year handout. I think that, if governments continue to use that sort of tactic, more and more people will gravitate to that 20-30 per cent of the population who are looking for candidates other than those from the major parties to represent them.

speech.para: You just cannot sit back and say, `Those preferences will drift back to us anyway so we do not have to worry about it.' I think the political system has to worry very sincerely about the fact that there is a disillusioned 20 to 30 per cent out there who, I believe, will only be reinforced because of a repetition of a variation of the whiteboard hand-out mentality, if you like.

I said on budget night that the one-off $300 handout for each person receiving a pension or part-pension looked like a blatant election bribe, and everything I have seen or heard since confirms that analysis. Those who got it can perhaps pay off their winter fuel bill—or part of it—in my electorate, where four per cent, with a sunset clause, compensation for the GST in the first place was never going to be enough, particularly in a rural cold winter electorate where fuel prices for heating, although not the government's fault, have indeed gone through the roof. The costs have risen significantly post GST—some of it no doubt unexpected with those skyrocketing fuel prices—but just like the fine print had to be read with the famous promise of that $1,000 bonus to pensioners to compensate for the GST, so too the fine print had to be read with this budget bonus. Many missed out on the $1,000 and many have missed out on this.

Disability support pensioners and non-pensioner carers or non-pension age carers also feeling the post-GST price hikes have angrily contacted my office to ask why they did not receive this payment. One constituent says:

quote.para: The recent announcement of a one-off payment to pensioners of $300 is (like the $1,000 GST bonus promise) again misleading and hurtful to many gullible enough to take the leader of the Australian people at his word. I am unaware of the ratio of aged pensioners to the sum of all other categories of pensioners, but that figure would closely reflect the number of vulnerable Australians hurt and disillusioned by the continued misrepresentation of the truth.

speech.para: He goes on:

quote.para: I am a disability support pensioner. That I can recognise the existence of the ambiguity/deception inherent in the continued misuse of the term `pensioner' when it is intended not to apply to all pensioners, should at least call into question the candour of those so cavalier with its use.

speech.para: These words, among others, are from Paul Collins in my electorate. If there is one thing clear to me after six budgets in this place, it is the fact that all too often measures announced as black and white with such conviction on budget night, and reported as such the day after quite uncritically by the media, turn out to be ambiguous or deceptive on further analysis. As another example, self-funded retirees could have been forgiven for thinking after budget night that they would all benefit equally from the government's proposed changes to the low income rebate system. But that was not the case, with income cut-offs meaning many self-funded retirees will receive no benefit whatsoever.

In the same way as the much heralded scheme to allow farmers to pass on their property to their family failed to live up to its promise to enable 10,000 farmers to access the pension—and it would have if that rate had been of $800,000 value instead of half a million, but it delivered for only 2,000—so, again, measures promoted as helping many will only aid the few. That real or perceived deceit is undoing much of the positive reaction the government might hope to gain from these initiatives and any amount of advertising will not turn this around.

talk.start.para: —I rise to be part of this debate on the budget to express concern for an organisation which has not been guaranteed funding in this budget—that is, the Women's Emergency Services Network. Today, I met with people from WESNET, the peak women's organisation working to eliminate domestic and family violence. Some three years ago this organisation had its funding threatened. A lot of other peak organisations—such as AYPAC, in terms of the youth sector, Shelter in terms of social housing and the Australian Pensioners and Superannuants Federation—have had their funding withdrawn by this government. WESNET's funding runs out on 30 June and it needs the support of the government. I call upon the government and the minister to give it its funding, which is pretty minimal. The organisation has, for the last three years, been getting $110,000 per year. This amount was given after some pressure on the government but, nonetheless, it has enabled it to carry out its very important role. A letter to WESNET dated 18 May 1998 from the then Minister for Family Services—the then federal member for Bass, Warwick Smith—states:

quote.para: WESNET has a role in advising the Partnerships Against Domestic Violence Taskforce on national priorities for work to prevent domestic violence and he is well placed to maintain and build on the momentum generated by the partnerships. In addition, I believe WESNET has the capacity to embrace the opportunity provided by these particular funds to conduct projects in research that may advance the work of the Taskforce in order to reduce the incidence of domestic violence and encourage better practice service responses to both victims and perpetrators.

speech.para: Having established the Australian Federation of Homelessness Organisations, it would be extraordinary for WESNET, as one of the bodies which make up AFHO, not to have its funding. That would leave a gaping hole; one we cannot afford to leave. Domestic violence is a crime and it is something all governments should be working towards eliminating. It is an issue which causes great pain and suffering to families in this nation. This government, through this measure, is showing what a compassionless government it is. WESNET currently only gets $13,000 in funding from the Australian Federation of Homelessness Organisations. This is funding specifically to have two conferences, as the national peak organisation, per year.

The loss of funding will mean the expertise that WESNET has built up through its personnel will be lost, and once you lose those skills and that experience it is very hard to rebuild and get it back again. The government has not even notified WESNET or responded to correspondence from it over a period of months as to what it will do. Given it is just 10 days before that funding runs out, I call upon the government to find a heart, to take up the rhetoric of the Leader of the National Party in the joint party room yesterday. He raised domestic violence as a very important issue, at the same time as the government is defunding the peak organisation. This is an outrage. It is an outrage because of the impact that it will have. It is an outrage for what it says about the lack of government priorities and it is an outrage because of the failure of the minister, Senator Amanda Vanstone, to respond to correspondence that WESNET has sent. WESNET's program is designed to ensure the safety of women and children, empower women to live free of violence and to improve the social, political and economic status of women. Surely, this organisation deserves the support of government.

talk.start.para: —I know that quite a few contributions to this debate today have been made by members of the opposition, but perhaps I can start with some of the contributions made by the member for Lilley. He started with an almost confected indignation regarding the GST and what sort of impact that has had, particularly on families, and of course he was being very indignant about the dramatic increase in assistance that we have given, particularly to families, through the new taxation system. Part of that has been the substantial increases in family tax benefit. There was $2.2 billion of new money that came through after 1 July this year to compensate families for any possible price increase that might have come about due to the new taxation system—$2.2 billion. For low income families, particularly for some of those receiving family tax benefit, that was an increase in the order of $40 to $50 per week in family tax benefit.

speech.para: We also increased family tax benefit part B. This was done to give families choice when one of the primary carers might not wish to enter the work force, and assistance is now given to those individuals. We do believe in choice, which is fundamentally important in the new taxation system. We have given them a substantial increase in funding through the family tax benefit, but there are also benefits to families, particularly through reductions in income tax rates, which are also substantial. But the best thing that this coalition government has done to assist families has been our stewardship over the last five years in ensuring that there has been a reduction in interest rates. These major reductions in interest rates—which are now at their lowest levels for decades—have meant that the cost of living is far more manageable for families, particularly mortgages. When Labor was at its zenith, particularly when the Leader of the Opposition was minister for finance, interest rates for home mortgages were at 17 per cent. So this has been a very family friendly budget, and these measures are certainly pro-family.

He also commented on the issue of reconciliation. Yes, we do have a policy to ensure that families get their estimates accurately. That is why we have now put on a lot more staff at Centrelink—to ensure that, if their circumstances do change, families can make contact either through their customer service centre or through the call centre to ensure that the estimates they get are correct. Under the old system, the Labor Party had 12 different types of payment for families—very complex and very confusing. We simplified that from 12 to three: family tax benefit part A, family tax benefit part B and child-care benefit—in which there has been a substantial increase. If we talk about child care, the last ABS statistics show that there has been a 10 per cent fall in the cost of child care. This has made it far more affordable than it ever was under the Australian Labor Party. Under reconciliation, for the first time if families underestimate their income—and they did not have this under the Labor Party—they will receive a top-up of up to 10 per cent.

But we are conscious of the need for families to have their reconciliation accurate. That is why, through all the campaigns that we have run over the last couple of years, families are being educated about such things. Because they are receiving a lot more in taxpayers' money through family tax benefit, we must ensure that their reconciliations and their estimates are correct. There are 2.2 million Australians who are receiving family tax benefit. Of those, 1.2 billion will receive family tax benefit part B, which is up to $108 per fortnight—and that is substantial.

Regarding the comments made about fraud and detection figures, it is certainly this government that wants to ensure that taxpayers get their correct entitlement—not more, not less. We certainly will not tolerate individuals who deliberately go out of their way—not through wrong estimates—to try and defraud the Commonwealth and other taxpayers. (Extension of time granted) That is precisely why—because we have spent $56 billion in this budget—we have to ensure that taxpayers' money is used accurately and appropriately. We do not step away from that, in contrast with the ramshackle days when the Department of Social Security was administered by the previous Labor government, where there was very little accountability.

The member for Lilley also spoke about an article by a leading academic that appeared in the paper today—again, an article about family tax benefit. As I mentioned before, what I believe has failed to be acknowledged is that family tax benefit, particularly part B, is there to give families choice. It is there to give families an option in the event that both parents want to return to the work force or perhaps one parent wishes to stay at home, particularly when their child is young. And yes, we have weighted it. If one partner wishes to stay at home and look after their child who is under the age of five, then there is a substantial increase. But, of course, if that particular partner returns to the work force, there is a reduction there. I believe that is very family friendly, and I disagree with some of the content of Peter Macdonald's article in the paper today.

Talking about the savings bonus, it was this government that, for the first time, compensated older Australians for a reduction in purchasing power through the introduction of the new taxation system—and that was never ever done when the Australian Labor Party were in government, particularly with their constant increases in wholesale sales taxes. These were hidden taxes that continued to go up: from 10 to 12, from 20 to 22. On it went, a plethora of hidden taxes, with there being absolutely no compensation being given to any Australians. What did we do? We were quite deliberate, when the new taxation system came into place, in stating that if you had a certain amount of savings, if you had been thrifty—particularly an older Australian—you would be entitled to a saving bonus. And I might add that the average payment for the savings bonus is around $743 and, from memory, that went to about 1.8 million Australians. That was substantial. There was also recognition given to self-funded retirees through the supplementary bonus, and that was payable up to $2,000. The previous government never gave any compensation for any of its failed tax policies and its broken promises with income tax cuts that occurred in 1983-84.

talk.start.para: —I will take that interjection. Was there any compensation when wholesale sales taxes were introduced? Absolutely not.
