The member for Shortland, as well meaning as perhaps she is, comes in here preaching virtues; she says that there has been a lack of attention to the job market. Why is it then that we have created 840,000 new jobs since our stewardship here? There have been more jobs created now. There is lower unemployment; it is now under seven per cent, and it was well over 11 per cent when the Leader of the Opposition was minister for employment. She talks about breaches. At least we have a gradual regime in place for Centrelink—it was never there under the Department of Social Security, which was administered by the Australian Labor Party. They had a one-breach policy: you got breached and you lost your total entitlement. Again, from memory, there were about 80,000 breaches in Labor's last full year, with people losing their total entitlement. What we did was to introduce a gradual system whereby you had a number of warnings before you lost your total entitlement. That was part of a recommendation that came to us from ACOSS and other welfare groups because of the draconian types of policies that existed in that area before.

speech.para: As far as Centrelink is concerned, a comment was made about extra staff. We are putting on extra staff. There will be substantially more staff going on under Australians Working Together, which is the core package of this appropriation bill. This is a very good thing, because we are starting to tackle some of those individuals who have been left behind—mature age workers, long-term unemployed, and particularly those people who are on disability support.

The area that the member for Kingston spoke about, which I thought was a constructive contribution—unlike some of the others—was the interrelationship between the Child Support Agency and the new family tax benefit scheme. I think he was perhaps also referring to elements of shared care. We do have amendments to legislation now—(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —One cannot help but stand at some time during the minister's dissertation and raise a few issues that he does not seem to have addressed in his own comments tonight. I will speak very briefly because it is getting late, but I will make a couple of points first. The main area of employment growth that appears to have been occurring under this government in recent times is that of advertising executives. We are talking about something like $120 million over the next six months being spent by this government in terms of advertising things that they have done, wish to do, or are misrepresenting. We are certainly talking about unchaining the wallets in this case. I bring up a particular example which relates to this portfolio area: some $4.1 million around the question of advertising for older Australians. The minister mentioned that there were different benefits going to different individuals and types of individuals. I will raise the issue about carers between the age of 55 and aged pension age, some 15,000 people. If we took the money that is being spent on advertising the government's activities to older Australians, we could easily ensure that the $300 bonus went to those carers.

speech.para: We are not only getting TV, radio and newspaper ads, we are also getting a personally addressed letter from Senator Vanstone. Now, I ask you: what older Australian deserves an addressed letter from Senator Vanstone? They will receive a copy of Centrelink's Age Pension News. Age Pension News is sent directly to people in these circumstances and, basically, it outlines these same benefits. Surely that is enough. But not happy with actually sending letters out to people to explain once, twice and three times what they are getting, they also sent a bunch of letters to people who in fact were not getting anything. They went out there and basically sent letters to a range of people who, because of their age, were not going to receive the benefits that were outlined. So they are not only causing them to suffer by sending them a letter, they are also misinforming them in those letters. I think the minister ought to look at some of those issues and see that that is really what this government has been doing in recent times—wasting money in a profligate manner.

talk.start.para: —I had not intended to impose myself on this debate but the contribution just made by the member for Bruce requires me to make a few brief comments. There has been an awful lot of hypocrisy flying around the joint lately on this business of government advertising. I have to say, first of all, that I do not accept the figures as put forward by the member for Bruce for the expected advertising expenditure over any future time span. Secondly, he calls into question the government's credentials in terms of the need for advertising. I have to say that to the best of my knowledge the government, aided by the Public Service, which has a statutory requirement to follow guidelines, follows the advertising guidelines which were brought down in, I believe, 1993 by an Australian Labor Party led government. If those guidelines were good enough for Labor in 1993, I have no reason to find them suspect in 2001.

speech.para: They are good guidelines. They require honest responses. They require there to be a demonstrated need for the advertising. They require research to prove that this advertising is required. It needs to be budgeted, done properly and not be party political. The Australian Labor Party can crawl all they like and try to make cheap political points about government advertising. But there is a need to clearly explain to the community new services and new processes, not to deceive the public but to make sure they understand what their rights and their entitlements are, and what government programs have changed so that they know how their lives are going to change as a result. I wanted to put that on the record. We have had enough of this hypocrisy from the other side of parliament on this issue. Let us get down and debate substantive issues, in this case about the budget for the Department of Family and Community Services.

talk.start.para: —I wish to raise the substantive issue of the fact that post this budget there is still a GST on caravan park rents. I want to refer specifically to one quote, because the member for Page is in this chamber and the Minister for Community Services, the member for Richmond, is in this chamber. On AM on budget day in the lead-up the Courier-Mail had had a front-page story that the GST, this unfair tax, this discriminatory tax, against these residents was going to be removed.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order, I ask you to ask the member what line item he was talking about in the budget.
(Mr Mossfield)—There is no point of order.
—The revenue stream that is going to the government from the GST on site fees: that is the revenue stream that I am talking about.
—I raise a point of order. Which government is the money going toto the state government?
—There is no point of order.
—It is no wonder that the member for Page is sensitive about this issue, because he went on AM on budget day, on Tuesday 22 May, and was asked this question by Alexandra Kirk. She said:

quote.para: But he is now looking beyond the budget—

speech.para: referring to Mr Causley—

quote.para: and like many in his party believes the government still has a problem with the GST on caravan parks ...

speech.para: Then the quote from the member for Page was:

quote.para: The GST on the rental of caravan parks, I'm still hopeful. We've been pressing. Larry Anthony and I have been pressing in this particular area. We don't know. We'll have to wait and see.

speech.para: We have seen. It was not fixed. It shows how pathetic and hopeless the member for Page and the member for Richmond are at representing their constituents. Maybe the Minister for Community Services might respond now about why he has been so inadequate in representing the 6,649 residents in his electorate and the more than 3,000 in the electorate of Page. It is pathetic and it is the reason why Labor will win both Richmond and Page at the federal election.

talk.start.para: —I will respond to some of that diatribe later on. I want to come back to some of the thoughtful contributions that the member for Kingston made regarding the interrelationship between the Child Support Agency and the family tax benefit. One of the things that we are trying to do now, which unfortunately is not getting the support of the Australian Labor Party, is to integrate the taper rates, one should say, between family tax benefit and child support. The changes that we put into place for family tax benefit, particularly for shared care, now mean that if you care for your children for more than 10 per cent of the time that will be reflected now in the family tax benefit. Under the old system of family payments you had to have 30 per cent care before you were recognised for any type of Commonwealth payment. That is the criterion that is also used in the Child Support Agency: you have to have care for more than 30 per cent of the time to see any reduction in your child support liabilities.

speech.para: We made a number of very sensible contributions and legislative changes to bring child support thresholds of 30 per cent down to 10 per cent, but they have been knocked back and not supported by the Australian Labor Party. I cannot understand the reason why. I see the member for Shortland is here, and she seems at times to be a compassionate lady. Why can't we have the two systems integrated? If yours are among the 860,000 children going through the Child Support Agency, if you are the payee or the payer, but particularly if you are the payer, and you have care for your kids for more than 10 per cent of the time, why can that not be reflected in the child support formula, because it does cost? Or how about 20 per cent of the time? But no, the Labor Party are opposed to that, which is bad policy, bad politics and bad for those kids growing up in these families, as many more families now seem to separate for all sorts of reasons.

The member for Kingston acknowledged an issue in relation to the family tax benefit, and we are making changes to amend that. If you do not pay your child support payments and you have debts then you should not be entitled to the family tax benefit. These amendments will be debated in the Senate, if not tomorrow then certainly by the end of next week, and will ensure that, if you are not making your child support payments—you will be given the chance, of course, to rectify that—you will not receive your family tax benefit. The FTB is distributed through the Department of Family and Community Services, and we are trying to ensure that there is a relationship between the payments that are made from there and the Child Support Agency—which is ultimately an independent agency, but there is obviously a relationship there.

It is sad because none of the speakers have contributed anything about the budget. There have been red herrings or references to particular social issues, but it is a shame that there has not been a contribution on the budget. The member for Calare, in his usual style, said how bad it was that we gave $300 to older Australians of pensionable age. What is wrong with that? It is a great thing. Actually, by tomorrow, up to 2.2 million people will be entitled to this, but at least 1.8 million pensioners will receive that $300.

talk.start.para: —You won't buy their votes, though, Larry.

—It is about compensating. It is about rewarding them for their efforts and for the contributions that they have made to this country. Of course, the other contribution we made was the $25,000 payment to war widows—something the Australian Labor Party never did. Then the member for Calare went on to talk about other price increases, particularly electricity price increases. He is probably best to look towards the state government in New South Wales, because they are controlling electricity. He also talked about fuel prices. It was this government that removed indexation, which was introduced by the Australian Labor Party 17 years ago. But, of course, many of the costs for fossil fuels are caused through their relation to international prices. He went on to talk about savings bonuses—which I have mentioned before—and about the disability support pension. The old age bonus was never intended for people on disability support pension. The bonus was age related: you had to be over 65 and of a certain income level. We have done an enormous amount for people with disabilities, and that will be happening in this budget. We believe it is important to focus on their abilities rather than their disabilities, and there have been substantial new places through the Australians Working Together program. (Extension of time granted)

speech.para: In conclusion, this has been a terrific budget as far as family and community services are concerned: $56 billion. There has been a major contribution for older Australians. There has been a big revamp of, and greater assistance to, Centrelink, which is doing a terrific job and I congratulate the agency. Of course, all the other reforms are making this country a stronger place. God help us if the Australian Labor Party were ever to regain the treasury bench.
Proposed expenditure agreed to.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Health and Aged Care

quote.para: Proposed expenditure, $2,796,146,000.

talk.start.para: —There is one issue that I want to raise with the minister, because I understand that he will not be here for long: that is the provision of MRI machines in public hospitals. In some hospitals they are not available at the moment. This matter came to my attention because a former constituent of mine had a son with a brain tumour who was airlifted to Adelaide. He rang my office very distressed because he had been told that his son had been placed on a waiting list for an MRI in order to find out the extent of his ill health.

speech.para: I spoke to the patient's doctor, and he said, `Well, the problem is not that there is a waiting list. The problem is that there is no MRI machine at the Women's and Children's Hospital in Adelaide'. I was surprised at that. We have had a considerable increase in the number of MRI machines in Australia. According to the Auditor-General, we have had an increase of about $50 million in the costs of MRI benefits over what was anticipated in the budget a couple of years ago, yet we still have not got them in the places where they are most needed—public hospitals like the Women's and Children's and the Queen Elizabeth Hospital in South Australia where an MRI machine is in a position to do the highest valued work that it will probably do and provide the most benefit to the community. Instead, we have them in radiological practices all over the country and they are probably doing lower valued work.

I have had a look at the Blandford report and I found that it did not recommend putting an MRI machine in the Women's and Children's Hospital. I have had a look at the annual report of the minister's own department, which has some discussion on this matter and points out that there are particular difficulties in relation to the provision of MRI services for children because it requires more sensitive care in relation to anaesthetics. This was confirmed to me by the staff at the Women's and Children's Hospital, who said that when they send a patient to the Royal Adelaide to have an MRI scan they have to send a team of anaesthetists with them. They are away for several hours, which obviously disrupts the rest of the workload at the Women's and Children's Hospital. I am greatly concerned by this absence. I have raised it with the state health minister, Dean Brown, and he seemed to be fairly oblivious to the problem. He was aware that the Women's and Children's Hospital or the health commission had put out a tender for one of the private MRI machines to be bought into the hospital, one that had benefits attached to it under the arrangements. What he was not aware of was that, despite cabinet having made that brilliant decision, when the tenders were called there was absolutely no interest.

So there has been no progress. The state government does not appear to have a plan to correct the situation. I have people in my electorate who are extremely concerned about the issue, including a young lad named James Bodin who was the best friend of the child who was ill. He `was' the best friend, because the child, Lachlan Wasley, died about three weeks later. He had an inoperable, malignant tumour on his brainstem and died within a week of surgery. It is a very emotional issue. There are an awful lot of parents around South Australia who are deeply concerned about it. James Bodin has been out there running an absolutely wonderful campaign. He has raised more than $10,000 for childhood cancer research and it has been put into a fund in the name of Lachlan Wasley, his best friend who died and brought this matter to my attention.

talk.start.para: —I will speak briefly regarding a matter that relates to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, in particular a leaked copy of the Productivity Commission's work in progress report into international pharmaceutical price differences, which showed that complaints by the pharmaceutical industry that the Australian pricing system for new drugs is too tough are largely unfounded. The purpose of the study was to compare prices that manufacturers received for pharmaceutical products in Australia under the PBS with those obtained in countries with similar and dissimilar arrangements. It was commissioned by the Commonwealth government and arose out of discussions with the pharmaceutical industry working group. There were seven comparison countries selected: the US, Canada, the UK, France, Spain, Sweden and New Zealand, with France, Spain, Sweden and New Zealand considered to be similar to Australia.

speech.para: The preliminary results show that manufacturer prices in Australia for the top 150 pharmaceuticals are much lower than those in the US, Canada, the UK and Sweden, but manufacturer prices in Australia are closer to those in France and about the same as prices in Spain and New Zealand. However, it also made some points about the types and classes of drugs within that. For example, prices paid by the Australian government for truly innovative drugs—new chemical entities—are similar and in some cases higher than in comparable countries. The greatest price discrepancy is in this area of me-too drugs—that is, newer drugs that are more expensive but have similar therapeutic outcomes to older and cheaper drugs, where Australia pays less than comparable countries. The highest prices paid for pharmaceuticals are in countries where there are no real government controls on pricing, such as the US, where prices are almost double that paid in Australia.

I believe this shows that under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme companies are awarded for true innovation and that prices for drugs that show little benefit over existing medications reflect their real rather than marketing benefits. It also shows the sort of cost-effectiveness controls established under the Hawke Labor government in 1998, which ensured that the high prices paid by consumers in the US are not being afflicted on the Australian taxpayer.

The report, I believe, proves once and for all that, if the government sticks to the PBS pricing process and stops interfering at the behest of industry, the industry will be rewarded for real innovation and Australians will be rewarded by having a manageable scheme that provides effective and safe medicines to all at affordable prices.

talker.name: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP
Dr WOOLDRIDGE
talker.role: Minister for Health and Aged Care

talk.start.para: —The member for Kingston raised a serious concern. I will attempt to give him a serious reply. One of the difficult things about being minister for health is that, even for someone who might be medically qualified such as me, it is hard to form a view about technology. It is hard to form a view on highly technical matters. Similarly, the PBS, which I will come to in a second, is another highly technical matter.

speech.para: What you tend to do is take the view of experts. This is proper. You set up expert committees. You try and get a range of views and then you try and force an expert committee to come to a consensus and give you a view. There will always be another expert who has a different view. We have seen it recently with the listing of the pharmaceutical Zyban and a researcher in Sydney getting a lot of publicity for taking one point of view yet the balance of opinion on my expert committee was to the contrary.

The whole MRI process has been debated at very great length. But I guess, given the way it played out and given the behaviour of some in the area, the capacity for me to do anything other than take expert advice is very limited. I set up an expert committee under Professor Blandford. At no time did I seek to influence the outcome of that committee's deliberations. I asked them what their expert view would be on the further extension of this new technology. We have substantially increased it in the last five years, even if some of it was by accident rather than design. Off the top of my head, I think you are looking at around $3 million per machine. The demand is limitless, so the only way you can try and put some cost control on it is to put some controls around the supply.

South Australia has three machines. Had the expert committee said to me, `Every children's hospital in Australia needs one of these,' I would have done everything I could to have implemented that. But that is not what the expert advice was. Again, unfortunately, in health care you find professionals who will use the public or use a particularly compelling case to try and argue for their own personal benefit. I am sure every radiological department in Australia would like one of these, but they are not going to get it unless the Commonwealth is prepared to chip another $100 million or so into radiologists' incomes. I am not sure that is the best use of public money.

In the specific case of South Australia, there are three funded machines. I accept completely what the honourable member says, that it necessitates a trip from time to time from one hospital to another to get a funded scan. I think that is probably a lot cheaper than putting a whole lot of extra machines in. I am sorry to hear the story the honourable member tells about his constituent child dying of cancer. It is an enormously traumatic thing. It does sound, in this case, given that he died three weeks later, it would have made very little difference one way or the other.

I would be very roundly criticised by the opposition were I to act other than in accordance with the way my experts have advised me. So I am damned if I do, and damned if I do not. I sleep okay at night because I know that I have not attempted to influence a committee. I have asked for the advice of experts and this is what they have given me. It is always open another time for another committee to come back.

On the issue of the state hospitals, of course it is open to a state government at any point in time to put a machine into its own hospital. It does not need Commonwealth authority or approval. There are a few spare machines going cheap around Australia if a state government wished to do that. I do not mean to single out South Australia because all the states behave similarly in this—they would rather blame the Commonwealth—but they could have a machine in a week in that hospital if they saw that as being the highest priority in the state for their health care. On the honourable member for Bruce's comments about the PBS, I agree with that study. Of course, he can point to no single occasion in the 5½ years I have been minister of my having sought to interfere with, or alter the outcome of, expert committees' deliberations.

talk.start.para: —I will just raise one other issue with the minister while he is still here. It will be a bit disjointed because it is about one issue but it is off a range of points. I am not asking for any action at this time, but I think it is an issue that he will recall. It is currently in the news and therefore it is worthy of some further consideration.

speech.para: I suspect the minister will remember that in something like September 1999 there was an issue regarding, the month before, a 15-year-old boy in Melton in Melbourne collapsing after drinking an alcoholic food essence. The minister came to parliament on that day with a bottle of the essence and announced several degrees of action which he was taking. One was to write to the ATO to ensure that these essences were actually reviewed in terms of the excise duty paid, so that they would actually pay the excise duty of full alcoholic drinks rather than be treated as a food. He referred the matter to ANZFA regarding the labelling of such products to ensure that there was a better labelling regime put into place. I think he also wrote to state and territory governments alerting them to the issue and seeking to ensure that such products were put into the licensed areas of premises in order to minimise the opportunity for minors to actually access such material.

At the time I commended the minister for his action, although I did raise a question several weeks later about the fact that I thought the matter should have gone a bit further because of the concern I had that I had gone to the same supermarket several weeks later and the material was still in the open area of the supermarket. I fully understand that that is an issue for the Territory with respect to that. Frankly, the way I got it removed was actually raising it again a week later with the management of the supermarket and saying that, if they did not remove it, I would be calling the police.

I would just like to update the minister on some aspects of this. He may or may not be aware that the actual inquest into the young lad's death is currently under way in Melbourne, and there has been a range of issues considered and covered in the media over the last couple of days about what has actually occurred. For example, although the minister's expectation—and I must admit it was also mine—was that the change in excise duty would in fact lead to a situation where the alcohol essences that we were talking about were largely withering and dying on the vine, there appears to be significant anecdotal evidence that they are still out there. Partially I think that is a situation of old stock still being sold. The action that was taken was not going to take that into account, and I understand that.

There are also some issues being raised about the question of duty being avoided on imports rather than product produced in Australia. That appears to be a problem with Customs, which has also been raised recently and could partly explain why some of those sorts of essences are still available. I would certainly urge him to comment—and I may well make some public comment myself in the next few days—about the fact that the labelling issue perhaps needs to be looked at again. I have some concerns about the decision taken by the ministerial council in this area and I would ask him to acquaint himself with that, because ANZFA made some recommendations to the ministerial council, which, with some reason but probably not sufficient reason, adjusted that decision. There is also the question of whether further action should be taken to remove these products from state and territory locations all up.

The minister, at the time I raised that aspect of the issue, made the point that that is a state and territory power and responsibility. I raised the point at the time, though, that I believe there may well be, under the Trade Practices Act, a capacity to act federally. I am not saying necessarily that that is the most appropriate way to do things, but I do think that we probably ought to have another look at the incidence of this product.

Obviously there is an inquest going on, so I think we also need to look at what comes out of that inquest. I do think that there are some issues there and I certainly offer our support to look at what might be done. I think we would both agree that these particular essences ought not to be available publicly, in my view not even in licensed premises. I made some inquiries at the time at some 10 or 15 stores in the area that I represent and spoke to people about it. Essentially what was said was that two types of people were getting it: people who appeared to be buying it for minors and people who were pretty much derros. For those reasons I think these essences should be banned. (Time expired)

talker.name: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP
Dr WOOLDRIDGE
talker.role: Minister for Health and Aged Care

talk.start.para: —It is truly a question without notice and I am without my question time brief pack, but I will do my best to answer. I do recollect the case and I have noticed some of the publicity in the papers in recent days. I gave several undertakings at the time and they have been carried out. The first is that we have reduced the size available. The honourable member is correct. Two or three years ago you could get 500-millilitre bottles of black sambuca essence, and I am not quite sure why one would want that. One of my staff told me the other night that she actually bought a bottle and tried to make some rumballs and she could not understand why anyone would bother to buy it to eat either.

speech.para: Today you are limited to 50-millilitre bottles, or 100-millilitre bottles in the case of vanilla essence. The Australian Taxation Office has changed the taxation treatment of this and it is now taxed as any other form of alcohol. That removes the price incentive to buy such a product. ANZFA has adopted the labelling. That took a while but it is now in place. I noticed—I cannot remember whether it was today or yesterday—that the Age newspaper did a survey of a number of stores in Melbourne and found that in fact there was no old stock. It is possible that there is some old stock in other parts of the country, but I was heartened to find that they could not locate any.

We do have a food ministers meeting coming up in a couple of weeks that I will be chairing. I would be happy to give the honourable member an undertaking to raise it with state and territory ministers, because they are the ones that are very easily able to deal with a consumer recall like this—because that is effectively what we are talking about. On the issue of duty on imports, that question would have to be directed to the minister for customs. I am afraid I have no knowledge of that.

talk.start.para: —Whilst the minister is here, I will raise one issue and then go on to some other issues that I want to raise. Maybe he could just take on board what I am saying and consider it a little later. In the area that I come from—the Central Coast, the southern part of Newcastle—there is a chronic doctor shortage. It is an area where there is quite an elderly population. In fact it is the 16th oldest area in Australia, according to the ABS figures taken at the last census. What is happening there is that elderly people are having to wait between seven and 14 days to get a routine appointment with their local GP, particularly in the Central Coast area of the electorate.

speech.para: Some submissions have been sent to the department, and they have been rejected without even being considered, because of the classification of the area. It is classified as a RAMA 1 area. Those submissions have been sponsored by the local council and by the GPs in the area. They have the support of the Central Coast urban division of general practice and of the local pharmacist. They have my support as well, of course, as well as that of the local state member. To refuse to look at a submission just because of a classification and to refuse to allow some overseas doctors into the area—which is what we are hoping will be allowed—is a restrictive method of assessment. Minister, if you could look into that, I would be grateful. I will now move on to the other part of my contribution.

The other thing that is a problem in the area that I come from is the shortage of GPs who bulk-bill. I was really disappointed that there was no move in the budget to encourage GPs to bulk-bill. We have a situation where we have an elderly population and a large number of people who are dependent on some sort of Centrelink assistance living in the area. The simple fact that they are unable to access a general practitioner who bulk-bills creates enormous hardship for them. When you add that to the fact that there are no local Medicare offices and people have to travel long distances, it is easy to see that the lack of a bulk-billing GP really does create problems for these people, especially those in the Central Coast section of the electorate where there is only a private transport provider. Therefore, I feel that the government really needs to act and to demonstrate a greater commitment to Medicare than just lip-service. The real commitment comes from ensuring that the pensioners in my electorate—and in every electorate, for that matter—can access bulk-billing. I find it very disturbing that we are seeing so much money being put into advertising which is directed towards the private health industry, while in my electorate I have a chronic shortage of doctors and many people who are missing out on being able to access bulk-billing.

I would quickly like to move on to the issue of aged care. I am pleased to see that the minister is here. I want to hark back once again to the point I just made: the Shortland electorate is the 16th oldest electorate in the whole of the country. It is the 16th oldest electorate in the whole of Australia, and there is a problem with a shortage of beds in that area. I know that, if you look at the Hunter, it can be said that there are sufficient nursing home beds there, although there is a chronic shortage of hostel beds for people living in the Hunter, and the figures bear that out. If you look at the Central Coast, you find once again that there is a real shortage of beds within that area. You also have to understand that area to see that, even if you look at Lake Macquarie, which falls within the boundaries of Shortland and Charlton, for an elderly person to be given a bed in a nursing home on the western side of Lake Macquarie—(Extension of time granted)

I will quickly conclude by saying that this is an issue that needs to be looked at urgently. I feel that beds need to be allocated fairly and evenly throughout the electorate. I would also like to express my concern about the fact that the beds that are being allocated within the area are being allocated more to private providers than to the community sector. I feel that the minister needs to take seriously some of the concerns that were raised with her when she met with providers in Gosford recently. They understand the area, and they understand the issues, and they were really disappointed that their concerns were not taken seriously.

talk.start.para: —I have a couple of things to say about the last speaker's comments. First, I was very pleased to meet with providers in Gosford fairly recently and to get some very positive information for them. I do think they felt that their concerns were certainly being listened to.

speech.para: With regard to some of the points that were raised by the last speaker, I would like to make the point that in 1998 when the Auditor-General did a review of aged care he found that the previous Labor government had left a deficit of 10,000 places. He found that this was systemic, that it had occurred over a number of years and that, in order for the situation to be remedied, there was a need to inject an additional 10,100 places, in addition to providing for growth in numbers. I have followed the Auditor-General's report, and in the time that I have been minister I have issued 32,000 places, counting the 9,500 places for the year 2001.

With regard to beds, the Auditor-General also found that, in order for those to come on stream, it takes something between two and 2½ years for infrastructure to be made ready for the beds to go into but that it is necessary to release the beds so that the providers can then build the infrastructure knowing that their funding is guaranteed. The problem was that through the 1990s the Labor Party failed to release the beds, thus failing to get the process of building infrastructure to begin. We are having to deal with this as it was inherited. We can fix it prospectively but not retrospectively. Releasing those new beds means that the places are guaranteed, and they will bring them on as quickly as they can.

With regard to the Central Coast, that area does need attention paid to it. The initial announcement was about how many beds were being released, and it showed that that was just over 9,500 for the year. With the allocation that will be advertised very shortly, the coming advertisements will show which areas are to be targeted. So that you understand the way in which the department recommends to me which areas should be the targeted areas, I will explain the process. Each state has a committee called an ACPAC, which is an aged care planning advisory committee. Each of those committees meets and considers the ABS figures, with five-year projections. Each committee considers the special needs groups, which are listed under the legislation. Each committee considers special issues and special pleadings that may come to them. Each committee then makes a recommendation to the department which then makes a recommendation to me.

I would very much expect the Central Coast to be on that list, because the figures clearly show that it falls behind the ratio we strive for of having 100 places per population of 1,000 people aged 70 and above. That ratio was set by the Labor Party, but they never met it. Indeed, from 1986, they ran it down. We have actually allocated enough places to meet that benchmark, but they are now having to come on stream. As soon as the infrastructure is built and a bed is ready, the money flows automatically. That is why I say that, once the beds are released, they are guaranteed. That is the job we have had fixing up the legacy that was left to us, and we are doing it. As I said, the Auditor-General found that the legacy was that the previous Labor government had failed to issue 10,100 places.

talk.start.para: —I also want to speak about aged care policy. I think this government can be praised for taking a difficult area of policy and embarking on quite radical reforms, but I think perhaps it runs the risk of promising far more than is actually delivered, or at least of creating that impression in the aged sector. Therein lies the problem.

speech.para: Perhaps I have the germ of a solution. There are four nursing homes in the Lithgow district. They came to me recently to point out that they believed they had had an allocation of what the media were starting to call `phantom beds' where they were given places but they did not have the resources to create the infrastructure. Having listened to that—and I think the minister would agree with me that I have been fairly constructive in my approach to the aged care dilemma over the past four or five years with the three ministers I have dealt with—there seemed to be a need to bring together all of the aged care providers in Lithgow, as an example, to discuss their particular difficulties, to see whether they could find common goals and whether there was a duplication of demand with the same people on each other's lists. It turned out that there were people on more than one list.

Having said that, one of the really worrying things as far as I was concerned was that with one of those providers—Tabulam Cottage at Portland—the community had been assessed as being able to self-fund the accommodation required for a number of awarded places when it was quite clear that it could not. The department recommended that it was vulnerable, yet when its application for capital funding was rejected it was told that it was because it had the capacity to raise funds, which the department admitted at the meeting the other day was quite incorrect. The very competent trio of departmental people sat and listened to each of those providers and then I joined them at the end of the day to work over those difficulties. So it looks like we will have to review the Tabulam Cottage situation. The other provider is Three Trees, a brand new-facility, which has been granted 12 places—I think it is. Three Trees has no history of capital raising. It is left with places and not much prospect, it believes, of raising funds when other providers in this not affluent area are trying to do the same thing.

Despite the 100 per 1,000 formula for aged care places for those over 70, it seems to me that there is a substantial unmet demand across my electorate. Perhaps part of the answer is to run these interfaces between all providers and the department community by community. I know it sounds cumbersome. If the minister wants to speak to me later, the people from that department were, I think, very enthusiastic about the model as a way of working through the problem. They identified perhaps some over demand and duplication and some people who could get together to share facilities and resources. It might be something as simple as laundry and it might be something like looking at whether or not they can be converted into community care packages rather than going down the costly infrastructure route.

I think a lot of this demand can be satisfied in a non-capital investing way and I certainly would like to see more of the sort of exercise that we organised last week in Lithgow to bring that aged care community together, to work for the common good of the communities, not for individual demands within the community group. I had Catholic and Masonic people who started these places and who, historically, have not talked to one another about aged care delivery now doing so. That is some progress, I can tell you. This model may be too cumbersome but I think it is the way to go.

talk.start.para: —Thank you for some of those comments, because I found myself that, by bringing homes which are in a geographic region together, there are things they can do to minimise costs, such as sharing laundry, being in a cooperative for buying food and so on. Indeed, it is being done in certain areas across Australia. One of the things I noticed when I took over this portfolio was that it grew up as a cottage industry and that good management is very important, because good management gives good care.

speech.para: Regarding the comments on Portland, I will check with the department on their outcome. The capital stream that has been put in place—being the money that flows from bonds and the accommodation charge—is money that can be used for repaying loans which you can get from the bank. This is bankable. After all, this money is paid monthly in advance; it is a constant and guaranteed stream of money which is very bankable, to use those terms. Many homes are taking this up and, in good management terms, are able to fund the infrastructure for the new beds and the recurrent stream that flows from that. I have been concerned that in parts of rural Australia there are some management problems, yet when I visit the home in Yeoval, which is run by the community, I see that the work they have achieved and the outcomes they get are just tremendous. It is a multipurpose service with acute beds as well as aged care beds, and the way it is managed by the community can be held up for a lot of other people to follow and copy.

There is provision for conversion to community aged care packages. They can apply under the round—and the 2001 round will be advertised, I expect, within a couple of weeks—to convert places to community aged care packages. Allowing people to remain at home, where they really want to be, is a very strong part of the policy that I am pushing, developing and administering. The member for Calare said that there is often the same name on many lists for different homes, and this is perfectly true. I was told by somebody who actually is close to the industry that a family had met together and decided they would put their mother in a home, so they put the mother's name down for 12 separate homes. The only problem was that, when the mother's name came up, the mother said, `I'm not going into any home. I'm staying in my home.' That became a statistic.

The thing that has been very important to me in the last few months, and which I am promoting very hard, is the Commonwealth Carelink Centres. These centres provide information about the range of services we provide which enable people to remain at home. Up until now, this information was so hard to find. If you suddenly found that you needed services to help you bathe and dress in the morning, to help with the shopping and all those sorts of things that you need to remain independent, how would you find it? By ringing Commonwealth Carelink—1800 052 222—people can now find out where those services are. I hear from my 32 partners around the country who manage those Carelink Centres that the most plaintive plea is from people who ring and say, `They want to put me in a home. What services have you got that will keep me in my home?' That is why community aged care packages are so well regarded and sought after. There were 4,000 of them when we came to government; we now have 24,000. With regard to the people who might want to look at that option, there is the provision to apply in the round when they are applying for whatever it is they might decide to do.
Proposed expenditure agreed to.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry

quote.para: Proposed expenditure$478,850,000agreed to.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs

quote.para: Proposed expenditure, $865,685,000.

talk.start.para: —I am pleased to make a contribution to this appropriation on migration expenditure of $865 million plus. Mr Deputy Speaker, as one of the naïve, out-of-touch members without a life and lacking life experience who put their name to the report on visits to detention centres, I would ask the minister that some of this $865 million go to dealing with an increasing problem that we are having in Australia with those hell holes that we now call detention centres. I ask the minister to, instead of having a knee-jerk reaction to one recommendationwhich, incidentally, I stand bylook at all the recommendations—the other 19 made in that report. As everyone is saying, no-one is wanting to send signals or green lights to people smugglers, but the system is not working and that is the hard, cold reality.

speech.para: The world is facing a new reality today of people's movements. There are people moving for all sorts of reasons around the world, through ethnic cleansing, through fear of persecution, through actual persecution and through wars and upheavals. Some, God forbid, are even looking for a better economic future. Call them what you will—boat people, illegal immigrants or asylum seekers—they will continue to come to this country. But always bear in mind that the number of people who come to this country is minuscule compared with the number of people arriving in many other parts of the world. How we are dealing with that is an absolute disgrace. We are out of tune with expectations and realities.

This country has a good record, built up over many years of dealing with refugees and resettlement, but we are tarnishing that record before the international community today. Other countries are dealing with much greater numbers of people. They are dealing with them in a more humane way and they are not having the riots. I have seen the film of the riots in Port Hedland so many times and yet no-one ever asked what caused that riot. Of all the media reports, there has never been a report from a detainee there. We only have the minister's view. We only have the departmental views or the views of the thugs who run these centres.

Most of the people who run these centres are ex-prison officers. I have spoken to them, and most of them come from a prison or corrective service background. They bring that whole custom into that society, and you wonder why there are riots in there. Go and spend a day in Woomera, Curtin, Port Hedland, Maribyrnong or Villawood and think about if you were there for eight, nine, 10, 12 months or two or three years whether you would not riot after a while, too.

These people are stressed for all sorts of reasons. I know that the guards and everyone else have to be protected, but we are going about it totally the wrong way. It always amazes me that there have been so few riots; I would have expected that there would have been many more riots there. Now that the minister has joined us, I say this: there will be many more riots in those centres. There will be many more people coming there, and we are dealing with it in a completely inappropriate way.

If I see those photographs of those weapons again! When I went round the detention centres the only weapons I was shown were a few bits of wood in Curtin. I ask: who found those weapons and where were they from? It is too convenient for the same people—the minister and the people who run those centres—to always appear on the television after a disturbance and that same photograph of those same weapons always appears. I do not envy the minister his job; it is a very difficult portfolio. It is a very difficult issue. I know the minister is, once more, going to label me naive. Well, that is fair enough: history will show who was naive, whether it is me or the minister. But I say with the greatest possible respect to the minister: we are dealing with it in an inappropriate way. We are just building up. It is going to happen time and time again until we change the policy as it affects these people.

talk.start.para: —I wanted to agree with the comments the member for Throsby has made in relation to detention centres. Unfortunately I do not have time tonight to go through the comments I had on detention centres, because there is another matter that I want to address. It relates to the treatment of people who are HIV positive who apply to come to Australia in the interdependency category. I am pleased that the minister is here, because I know that this issue has been raised with him by a number of my constituents. I want to refer to a letter that was written to me. Obviously I will not use the constituent's name. He wrote to me on 27 February 1999:

quote.para: I met the man I will spend the rest of my life with. We are a defacto couple, very much in love and sure of our future together.

speech.para: My correspondent's partner is a Canadian physician who is working in Sydney as a doctor. The man himself is also in the health care profession. Both of them are employed currently. Both of them have been contributing to the tax system. Both of them are keen volunteer workers. They are members of their local tennis club and go to yoga regularly. They are people who are contributing to the Australian economy and making a contribution as well to society. Let us call my correspondent's partner `D'. He writes that D and he:

quote.para: completed all of the requirements set out so that he may become a permanent resident of Australia including a medical whereby he declared his HIV status. According to information that we have received from our case officer at DIMA, and an immigration lawyer working on our behalf, it is likely that our application for—

speech.para: D's—

quote.para: Permanent Residency will be rejected on the basis of his HIV status. We have been advised that the current government considers that applicants with HIV pose an undue burden of cost on the Australian health care system. I want to point out that neither of us has ever been symptomatic of HIV illness, nor ever hospitalised because of this diagnosis. We are both on anti-retroviral medications that are working well to keep us both healthy. In fact—

speech.para: D—

quote.para: has an undetectable viral load and his T cell count has only improved since moving to Australia.

speech.para: The key point is that when DIMA make an assessment of how much someone who has the HIV virus is likely to cost the Australian community, they are working on figures that I presume were developed in the 1980s when HIV inevitably progressed reasonably quickly to full-blown AIDS. Of course that is not the fact at all these days, with the more sophisticated drug treatments on the market. The Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs assume a cost of about $239,000 over an unspecified but shortened lifespan for someone who has HIV. I have spoken to a number of specialists in this area, and their figure for drug treatments is $11,000 to $12,000 a year. The point I make is that both of these men are employed. They are in the work force. They are paying much more than $12,000 a year in tax, I am sure, and they are making a very important contribution to the community. There are also non-economic factors that must be taken into consideration when we are making decisions about whether people's interdependency visa applications should be agreed to. This couple own a home together. They have shown a great commitment to one another and are accepted by one another's families as their life partners.

This brings me to another matter when it comes to carers for people who become ill. Many people who are HIV positive do not have blood relatives who are willing to come to Australia to take care of them. DIMA has to consider that the definition of `family' should also include people who have shown a genuine long-term commitment and, if they are prepared to come to Australia to care for an Australian citizen who is sick with AIDS, that that should be something the Australian community applauds rather than discourages on the basis that they are not a blood relative but are, in fact, just someone who is in a relationship with someone who is sick. I am pleased that the minister is here because these are two areas where perhaps the thinking of his department is somewhat out of step with new treatments in the area of HIV and AIDS and out of step with the general community.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr RUDDOCK
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs and Minister for Reconciliation and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I do not want to exclude other members, but others will speak no doubt on the same matters that the member for Throsby raised. Essentially the health criteria have to be addressed in three contexts. The first is whether or not somebody has a disease which is contagious. AIDS is not contagious in that sense, if people manage their contacts appropriately. The second matter is the extent to which people's requirement for services might prejudice the needs of the Australian community. There are certain areas in which we have limited facilities and resources and in which, if you take people with a particular condition, it could prejudice the extent to which an Australian might be able to access those services. The third is the ongoing and potential cost. The assurance I would give the honourable member is that, in relation to HIV status, people are not automatically excluded. The costs are looked at very closely because there have to be briefs prepared, many of which come to me for a judgment as to whether or not the circumstances are so compelling that there should be a waiver.

speech.para: In the interdependency cases, the sorts of factors that you have mentioned are taken into account. We do take into account the nature of the relationship. We do take into account the extent to which people have resources to be able to assist the particular individual and we weigh those factors against the potential cost. I have not sought to draw attention to these matters, but the fact is that, even with amounts of the order of $1 million or so, grants have been made where it is seen to be compelling. One of the things I have been concerned about is that people might see me as being unduly soft in relation to these matters.

talk.start.para: —We will defend you from that accusation.

—I am glad to hear that because I saw on the last statement that was published in some Senate estimates that I had acceded to something like 41 out of 43 applications that had come in for a health waiver. I am glad to hear that I have not been unduly soft in relation to those matters. I would say to the honourable member that there is not an automatic bar to people who have HIV.

speech.para: In relation to whether we should establish for people who have certain medical conditions a wider group of carers than a close relative—which is really what you are asking—you would have to look at the implications of that for migration generally. Are you establishing a category of entry which the very creative profession of which I am a part—the legal profession—would find to be another gateway to providing access to a wider group of people? Generally speaking, I would say in circumstances like that that it would be best to push an application to see whether or not the circumstances are such that a minister would exercise discretion in the particular case.

talk.start.para: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker, for affording me the first opportunity I have had in this chamber to speak on a report on visits to immigration detention centres. I wish to defend all of my committee member colleagues, particularly the coalition members, against some of the savage accusations that have been levelled against them, such as that we have not done the hard yards. Minister, ask me and I will seek the committee's approval to release the eight hours of transcript of evidence from your departmental officials and ACMs that occurred after those visits. Ask me, because I wanted them published. I did not want to have in camera hearings. I wanted them on the public record. If you think the hard yards have not been done then let us release the transcripts. I am surprised that Alan Ferguson can be accused of being anything other than a loyal defender of your government.

speech.para: It is true that on three days we sat to discuss what we had seen, what we had heard and what were appropriate recommendations. Minister, I did not get every recommendation up that I wanted. I believe the biggest problem with detention centres is the lack of scrutiny. In our own state, Minister, we have an inspector-general of prisons who can do inquiries at the direction of a minister, who can do his own motion inquiries and who can hear complaints; and the Ombudsman's role is not interfered with. You have that additional protection. We have an official visitors procedure. I would have liked to have seen an official visitors person for each detention centre. We did not follow that model, but we followed an independent one—one that you have so much disparaged. I believe that it is in all of our interests that we lift the lid on detention centres. Minister, you ask what message we are sending through the proposals that we offered. You are piloting a family—

talk.start.para: (Mr Jenkins)—The honourable member will refer his remarks through the chair.

—Minister, through you, Mr Deputy Speaker, you are proposing a pilot scheme for families. We supported that. I wanted to go further, but the committee members said that you were taking action. I endorsed that, but you will note that the report said that the condition and treatment of families was a critical priority for the committee. We proposed that a target be set—and I can see that you have done a lot to reduce the processing time—of no longer than your current funded processing time. But we linked another recommendation to it that you have conveniently ignored: sponsorship, so that, yes, people can be released provided they are sponsored by an appropriate organisation. If they do not have a security clearance, if they are not sponsored, they are not let out of detention centres. Why has there been so much dissembling on this issue? Why won't you give that a try, Minister? You ask what message softer treatment of people in detention centres sends back. What is the message, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the minister sends back by having 58,000 overstayers in this country? It is not bringing the country to its knees, Minister. In the year 2000, there were 2,800 people who arrived by boats and who were held in detention centres. What was it in the Netherlands? It was 50,000. In France it was 75,000. It was nearly 100,000 in the UK. Good luck to you. We have a minuscule problem compared to other countries. I congratulate you on that. But why can't you and your departmental officials get it into perspective? Why do you deceive the Australian people so much?

speech.para: I only have 50 seconds left. This is a good report. It was honestly arrived at by men and women of goodwill from all political parties. It deserved consideration. I can understand when a report or its recommendations are not agreed to by governments. But what was most hurtful was the government's attack on coalition members and the fact that the report did not receive careful consideration. I know that we should act according to conventions, but the strongest imperative here is Australian standards—the Australian sense of a fair go about what is right and what is wrong. I have confidence in the Australian people in the long term. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I am not a member of that committee, but I did go to Port Hedland and I visited 18 of the people who are now in Hakea Prison, in Perth, for allegedly inspiring a riot in relation to these matters. As the honourable member for Chifley said, the recommendations of the committee are very moderate compared with the need for action. Let us just mention one fact. Not only is the policy, and its implementation, quite wrong at the moment but we are spending more than $100 million in these detention centres. To achieve what? It is supposedly to send a message back to people that Australia is not a soft touch and that people will be treated in a certain way in relation to refugee status if they come in a boat—or if they are desperate enough to end up having to come in a boat. This is one of the biggest wastages of public money in social policy that we have had for a long, long time.

speech.para: The minister well knows that more than 90 per cent of the Afghans and more than 90 per cent of the Iraqis will be or have been accepted as genuine refugees. Notwithstanding this, we have had people in detention—and they have not merely been in detention. In talking to the people in Port Hedland and in Hakea Prison, I was stunned to hear that about 50 per cent of those who were allegedly accused of various incidents in relation to the 11 May event had been in the notorious isolation cell in Port Hedland prison—or Port Hedland Detention Centre. I used the word `prison' but it is worse than a prison. The conditions in Hakea Prison are much better than the conditions in Port Hedland Detention Centre, there is no doubt about that. What did this isolation policy mean? It meant that people could be in this isolation centre for seven or eight months—and, in the case of one man, 16 months—before they had their first interview. I do not know who authorised this policy. I cannot believe that the minister authorised the policy that people would have to wait for seven months before they even had an interview—never mind how long they had to wait before there was a judgment about whether or not they were going to be given refugee status. That was before the first interview.

We know from the parliamentary committee and from what we have been told by others—including what I was told—about the conditions of the especially notorious Juliet Block. I was not able to see Juliet Block and nor was the parliamentary committee. There is a very good reason for that: it is a total disgrace. It would in fact be condemnatory in international terms—not only the physical conditions but also other conditions, including not being able to contact their own wives and children for more than seven months. That is your policy, Minister. You may not be aware of all this. I think that you are not aware of this. I think you have been misled. You have been told lies. I am sorry to say that you have been told lies by officers and by people in the ACM who are trying to cover up.

I was shocked at the atmosphere in Port Hedland; you could cut it with a knife. And the tensions and hostility between the two groups, the detainees on the one hand—and I am talking about all the detainees, not just the trouble makers—and the ACM people on the other hand, were really unbelievable to me. But has the minister really understood this? Is he really interested in resolving this? Is this the heritage that you want to go on with, Minister? I think that you should answer the questions that I have put to you that will appear in the Notice Paper tomorrow.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr RUDDOCK
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs and Minister for Reconciliation and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I thank the honourable members for Throsby, Calwell and Chifley and acknowledge also the member for Sydney—I made some observations on her comments earlier. In relation to the members who spoke and who were part of the Human Rights Subcommittee of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, there are times when it is important that you read in context fully what people have had to say. I did read your report.
—In question time.

—I read it very quickly, and some of the comments I have made should reflect that reading. I have not said that, in relation to every recommendation you have made, I have dismissed them. I did focus very much on a number of recommendations that had been tried and failed. I may have misunderstood what was mentioned, but the words used were clear. The words used by the committee in the recommendation made it clear that people should be released within 14 weeks, provided they had had a security clearance. The word used was `should'.
—Two recommendations had `should'. It's a majority report. The two are together.

—All I was going to say about that—and I will repeat it—is that it is not a matter of trialing it; we had a trial. When I came in as minister, I was still having to defend accusations about false imprisonment that occurred under a policy where there were time limits and where the courts got into the business of deciding that certain clock-stopping events had not been effective and that people were falsely imprisoned.
—There is a way around that problem.
—I do not believe there is, member for Calwell.
—Why don't you have a discussion, or a debate?

—I am happy to have debates and discussion. We were on a committee together and we dismissed those sorts of propositions at that time. I have not dismissed all of the recommendations—I make that very clear—and I will look positively at those. I make the further point and it is relevant to what the member for Calwell and the member for Throsby have had to say: I am not about having an inhumane policy of detention—it has to be humane. There are certain expectations and people do have entitlements to complain to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission—and they are advised that they do. They do have an opportunity to complain to the Ombudsman. I believe that there should be an independent monitoring of what was happening, and that was the reason I set up the detention advisory group, which included two former ministers—John Hodges and Gerry Hand. It has included a number of the members of the Refugee Resettlement Advisory Council: Mr Paris Aristotle, who deals with torture and trauma issues; Professor Harry Minas, who is a leading psychiatrist; and Major-General Warren Glenny. The status of those people is beyond doubt.

speech.para: You raised the issue of sponsorship. My concern about what is happening here is not in relation to finding refugees—I think we do find refugees. The member for Calwell talks about Afghanis. The real problem is that we have probably been finding many who are not refugees to be refugees. If you look at what the Afghani community is saying at the moment about the extent to which Pakistanis are part of the caseload, I think we still have a major problem in relation to those matters. A lot of people have come who have relatives in Australia, and I suspect that many of them are looking for family reunion outcomes. They would find sponsors. If you are going to bring people who are looking for family reunion outcomes and link them with their sponsors and have them in the Australian community, if what they are looking for is migration outcomes, then they have achieved it. That is one of the concerns that I have about those sorts of suggestions.

I cannot comment on everything, save to say in relation to the member for Throsby's comments about the people who are misbehaving that, in general, that occurs because they have reached the end of the road; they are being held for removal and there is a certain amount of desperation. I understand that. They are more difficult to manage and I appreciate that, but I do not think any degree of amenity is going to alter that possibility or probability. I will conclude by saying that I will ensure, as I have before, that the honourable member's questions on notice are properly and quickly dealt with. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: (Mr Jenkins)—Before we proceed further, I ask that the honourable member for Chifley apologise to the Main Committee for allowing his mobile phone to ring.
—Yes, I do apologise. I did not realise my phone was on.
—I might take the unusual step and seek some guidance from the Main Committee about how it wishes to proceed, because there was a loose understanding that we were to sit through until 7.30 tonight.
—I just want to make one statement. I do not want to detain the Main Committee much longer.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, do you need an extension of time?
—No, there is no extension of time, but I could use a device which would close down things fairly quickly. I want to seek some guidance about where we are at.

—I will be very brief. I accept, if you like, a degree of fault in the committee, but I will say that recommendation 10 should be read together with recommendation 12. I think then you get a better understanding of where the committee was coming from.

—I just want to notify the chamber that I am writing privately to the minister about some concerns which I think have to be dealt with in relation to my visit to Port Hedland. I want those matters to be looked at. The other issue is: when will the minister actually formally reply to the committee, as distinct from the media response?

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr RUDDOCK
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs and Minister for Reconciliation and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —There is a requirement to respond within three months. It will be a whole of government response, and I will do that as quickly as I can. It will get a normal and full response, and it will not be dismissive of those recommendations that can be sensibly and easily implemented. I just make that point clear. I thank the honourable member for Chifley for his suggestion that I read recommendations 10 and 12 together. I was conscious of both of those recommendations, but I did not read them as being dependent upon each other.

speech.para: Let me say to the member for Calwell that, when people are endeavouring I think to use the opportunity to win an argument in relation to the detention system, they want to see the demise of it, and they are putting us under duress in relation to those matters. That is how I see it. If there are serious allegations about inappropriate behaviour, they should be properly and fully investigated and we should have a situation where we can establish what the facts are. I do not like dealing with allegations that are made in the media which are not always clear and precise as to who they apply to and which are not capable of immediate and appropriate response and investigation. If the member receives serious allegations and he wants to put them to me, I will ensure that they are fully and properly investigated; I will ensure that happens. I think it is a far preferable—

talk.start.para: —No, I don't think you should be naming people at all. I think it is a far preferable way of dealing with these issues. Let me just say to the honourable member that, when I facilitate a visit in good faith to enable you to hear what people have to say and when I explore with you how we might follow up those issues later by a proper investigation of any allegations that might be put to you, I do not expect, particularly when I am away, as I was last week, to then find those matters that are raised as allegations traduced in the media as generalised comments which I then have to deal with by way of response. I do not think that is fair to me, and I do not think it is fair to the department.

speech.para: If we are going to facilitate visits, which I am more than happy to do, I have an expectation that, if you receive complaints, you will enable them to be dealt with properly and fully. I do not expect to see one side of the case put in the public media, in a situation where we cannot respond and we cannot deal with them appropriately. I think—and I have said this to the honourable member face to face—that there was a lack of good faith in terms of the assurance I gave you and the way in which you dealt with it.

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I thought we were going to conclude this, but the minister has raised an inappropriate comment in relation to this.
—Is the honourable member raising a point of order?
—You stated one side of the case in the media. I stated the other side of the story. I did not say that I believed the other story. I simply said—
—Order! The honourable member for Calwell will resume his seat. There is no point of order.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Reconciliation and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

quote.para: Proposed expenditure, $1,164,143,000.

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 22 May 2001:

quote.para: Does the Australian Government have a position in respect of the Chinese Bear Farming Industry and in particular to bear bile and associated products; if so,
(1) what is that position.
(2) has he, or will he make any communication with the Chinese Government in respect to bear farming and the trade in bear bile and bear bile products.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The Australian Government views with concern the issue of cruelty of animals and concerns about reports of ill-treatment of bears in the Chinese Bear Farming industry, in particular reports concerning the ill-treatment of the endangered Asiatic black bear. Under the Commonwealth Wildlife Protection (Regulations of Exports and Imports) Act 1982, the import of Asiatic black bear products, including bile, is not permitted unless they are taken under a captive breeding program registered under the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES). There are currently no bear farming operations in China registered under CITES.

(2) Australia has made representations to the Chinese authorities under CITES about traditional medicines containing prohibited products, including those of endangered bears, and will continue to do so. Separately, the Australian Government has strengthened legislation governing the trade in products derived from endangered species to make it easier to prosecute infringements of the legislation. It has also conducted a targeted public education campaign to promote awareness of wildlife conservation issues in order to reduce the demand for traditional medicines containing products of endangered species and to promote more appropriate farming practices.

subdebateinfo.title: Foreign Affairs and Trade, Department: Representation in Ramallah
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2564)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 22 May 2001:

quote.para: (1) What is the cost of the building of an Australian Representative Office in Ramallah, in the areas controlled by the Palestinian Authority.
(2) When and who made the decision to build such an office.
(3) What is the size of the Palestinian economy, in terms of GDP per annum, that this office will service.
(4) What is the size of the Israeli economy in terms of GDP per annum.
(5) How many Australian embassies or consulates have been opened or closed since 1996.
(6) What was the size, in terms of GDP per annum, of the economies served by Australian diplomatic missions that have closed since 1996.

(7) How does the Australian Government justify the cost of operation and construction, as well as future expansion of the Australian diplomatic presence in Ramallah, compared to the missions that have been closed.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The office is a leased floor of a seven storey commercial building in Ramallah. The lease commenced on 29 September 2001 for a period of 5 years. Rent is A$48,580 pa.
The office fitout, including furniture and fittings, is scheduled for completion in October 2001 and has been budgeted at A$450,000.

(2) The decision to lease premises in Ramallah as office accommodation was taken by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade in September 2000. The decision was taken in accordance with standard Commonwealth property guidelines for office accommodation and followed a survey of accommodation options, other mission practice, and available office space in Ramallah.
(3) The Economist Intelligence Unit (1999) reports that the Palestinian GDP is USD$4.75 billion.
(4) The Economist Intelligence Unit (1999) indicates that the Israeli GDP is USD$100.8 billion.
(5) Since 1996, 7 posts have opened and 4 have closed.
(6) The International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics, May 2001 and the Economist Intelligence Unit, report the GDP figures as:

answer.para: · Copenhagen, Denmark USD$151.23 billion (1999)
· Damascus, The Syrian Arab Republic USD$16.2 billion (1999)
· Almaty, Kazakhstan USD$16.9 billion (1999)
· Nauru USD$50 million (1998)

quote.para: (7) Decisions on overseas representation reflect many interrelated considerations. They focus on maximising Australia's economic and political standing to influence regional and global developments to advance Australia's national interests, and take into account various strands of external policy, including foreign, trade, defence, immigration, and development co-operation considerations.

Other factors may include the expansion of commercial contacts to help generate inward and outward investment, and the need for consular and passport services to Australians travelling and living overseas and to their families in Australia. Considerations of efficiency are relevant, both in terms of comparative costs in different locations and configurations, and in maximising our investment in the existing network.
In relation specifically to Ramallah, the decision was taken following the Prime Minister's visit to Israel and the Palestinian territories in April 2000.
I regret that the honourable member does not support the opening of this Post in contrast to the views of the Member of Kingsford Smith.
